133687146.review:
Hogwarts Legacy is a video game that has been highly anticipated by Harry Potter fans all over the world, and it does not disappoint. From the immersive gameplay to the breathtaking graphics, this game has everything a fan of the Wizarding World could want.

What makes Hogwarts Legacy even more special is the fact that it was created with diversity and inclusivity in mind. The developers made a conscious effort to ensure that people from all backgrounds would feel represented and included in the game, and it shows. The characters are diverse and complex, and the story line is both engaging and inclusive.

It's important to note that while the game was created by a company that has been criticised for its handling of trans issues in the past, there are better ways to fight transphobia than boycotting a video game. Hogwarts Legacy is a labour of love, and the people who worked on it put their hearts and souls into creating an immersive and inclusive experience for all players.

Overall, Hogwarts Legacy is a fantastic game that is sure to delight fans of the Wizarding World. It's a testament to the power of inclusivity and diversity in gaming, and a reminder that we can all come together to create something truly magical.

From the point of view of someone who doesn't even like Harry Potter franchise, this was a welcomed surprise!

overall its a perfect game, i experienced no stuttering, lag or graphic glitches on medium settings (which was still gorgeous) on my older laptop alienware i7-8750H.   im at 60hrs and havent entered endgame yet.

133686276.review:
Sitting at 72 hours in this game--it has been fantastic. When I started, I was blown away by how much is in the game. I said it was my favorite open-world game next to Breath of the Wild (which still holds the torch). Does that still ring true? Yes, but with some caveats. There are some performance issues with this game, but I will be covering the gameplay aspect of the game here.

So, how does it fare? Well, I was really worried at first because the story opens up with your character giving you the answer to every single puzzle without allowing you a moment to think for yourself. Then we're shown pointless dialogue trees, a disappointing sorting, and WAY too much HUD information. Every enemy has a healthbar and a level, and we have our health bar and magic meters, and look! Waypoint markers and a path marked on your mini-map! Objective markers hover obnoxiously over NPCs that you need to talk, too, and the worst offender of all, enemies scale with you throughout the game making upgrades effectively limited or worthless.

So, this open-world is really just taking a page out of the more generic ones out there. Repeating tombs and secret areas that don't really unlock upgrades but just give you unidentified gear as a reward which might slightly up your stats. It's novel at first but wears thin when you realize that it's all the same and loses its appeal quite quickly.

With all of this negative stuff in here, why am I giving it a positive review? Well, for a few reasons really! Because this game is actually REMARKABLY fun!

First, this game is banking on the player being a Harry Potter fan. If you're in love with the wizarding world, then getting to run around Hogwarts and the environment is an absolute treat! I can't tell you how giddy it makes me to see the paintings moving, ghosts sword fighting and floating through the castle, Peeves up to his shenanigans, suits of armor moving out of the corner of your vision or interacting with each other. Oh my god, it is SUCH a treat. And the intricacy of Hogwarts itself is SO fun! It can be almost overwhelming at first, but things fit together in such an intricate and nice way, it feels like I really am exploring a magical castle with tons of secrets within its walls! Although I wish they could have made the Grand Staircase more faithful to the books and movies, everything else feels like its selected the best of both worlds. Certain aspects of the castle are more faithful to the movies while others pull a page or two from the books, and it's wonderful to see

Second. Accessibility options. Normally, this is a source of contention for me because I usually see accessibility impede the vision of the creator and game rather than support it. But the options they have here (while there is room for improvement--where the hell is my one-stick broom control?) do give you a range of customization. And the first thing I did? I turned off the ENTIRE HUD. I kept things up long enough to learn how they work, but I was able to turn off:

-The minimap
-My healthbar
-Enemy health bar/level
-Wand Spells

I did that all while keeping the display for items that I pick up and EXP notifications. The problem I have with this game is the problem I have with other Action RPG games. They're not RPG games. They are on the surface level, but they're really more Action/Adventure games. RPGs have a very certain feel to them, and I'm not a fan of western RPGs with scaling enemies. It loses that sense of working hard to get stronger which is ESSENTIAL to an RPG experience. All of the combat has to lead to something and make you stronger. And enemies that scale with you take away from that experience.

However, as an Action/Adventure title, this system is PERFECT. And you can achieve that feel by removing the levels and health from enemies. You'll get talents that unlock different effects for spells, learn more spells, get better combos, be able to mix and match combos as you want, and that sort of system works SO MUCH BETTER when you remove the arbitrary health values and levels that enemies have. It puts the focus on you, your wits, your spells, and your positioning rather than on whittling down a red bar until it disappears. I understand that this isn't for everyone, nor do these mechanics bother everyone, but scaling enemies is something I take issue with because of how repetitive it makes games feel, and I'm glad there was an option to turn these elements off.

To go along with that, most games that give you those sort of options are unplayable without them. Sure, Witcher 3 might SAY that you can remove the minimap, but the core gameplay relies on it, so if you don't want to pull up your map every two seconds and ruin the flow, then you need to have it on. I would say that this game does a really good job at being the best of both worlds. You can disable these HUD elements, but still have the game be playable. Oh, don't have your mini-map and are lost? Not to worry! We have a pathfinder similar to Dead Space that you can activate and follow to your objective without too much clutter on the screen. It really is wonderful.

Third. The combos. Oh my god, the combos. The game gives you a rundown very quickly of it's combat. Attack and shield. Attack and shield. Ohp. Super attack. But this is quickly added onto with spells that you learn in class. You start to learn various spells that you can put into your combos. Hit the enemy, levitate them, hit the enemy, pull them toward you, set them on fire, push them away, hit the enemy, thrown an object. Want to sneak up on that enemy? Do it. Wanna throw that guy off a cliff? Have fun! Oh, man. There's some guys below me but I don't really feel like fighting a lot of them. I'm pretty high up though. I'll just pull them to me and let them fall to their death. I have had SO much fun with the combat in this game. Elements of it remind me of Batman: Arkham Asylum. It's not exactly the same, but you have combos that you do while watching for dodge and counter symbols that flash around your character's head (rather than the enemy's). I willingly look for fights because of how much fun I have playing the game.

Fourth. The stuff I wasn't expecting. The extra stuff can wear thin, but I was just expecting a game where I ran around a castle and shot some wizards now and then. The fact that I was provided more than that has been thrilling, and quite an enjoyable experience.

And that's my review for the game. There's some faults with it, some things get old, and at the end of the day, the world and exploration is like a lot of other open-world games out there. But the gameplay, accessibility features, and the fact that I'm in the wizarding world have made the experience one that has put a smile on my face the whole way through.

133683829.review:
I'm gonna nitpick because I like the game a lot, so these parts are annoying me.

20 gear slots, every quest has tons of chests, and you have seven equip slots that take up those gear slots. That means you only get to pick up 13 pieces of gear before you have to sell. They give you a destroy option so you can deprive yourself of gold in a game where everything you need for quests/items is super expensive. There's not a lot of options to earn gold either.

I wanted the Chinese Chomping Cabbage but there's literally no way to grow them until you are almost ~10-15hrs into the game despite them being introduced to the player around the 2-4 hrs mark. 

Really wish they had the spell slots open at the start of the game. Having to spend talent points for a basic feature is disgusting. Since you don't have a lot of spells early game this isn't that bad, if I only had one more bar at the start I wouldn't be complaining. As it is I have to swap out spells if I want to do well in combat early game, punishing me for daring to use the stealth spell that was given to me to start combat. 

Loved the appearance system, especially since the gear is freakish to comical. I came from playing LotRO to this so I felt right at home. Really wish they had an appearance set option, as it is everytime I equip gear I have to set the appearance again. This is doubled by the annoyance that the gear is so wild, I briefly get to see my beloved character look like a clown.

Besides these gripes, the game captures the spirit of movies down to the details. Combat is snappy, enemies remain a threat despite the power of the player character. Love how the melee enemies like Goblin Assassin can close in on you so quickly, allows a lot of player response. 

Playing on hard everything seems to four shot me, but I'm almost never using healing pots because of the after combat health regen, and combat ends pretty quickly either way at least in early game.

133681986.review:
Great game and one that is definitely worth paying full price for. In fact, I'm glad I did because I want to do everything possible to support the creation of games with this level of quality. I give Hogwarts Legacy 92 / 100 for the following reasons:

What I liked:
1. The graphics and world detail - this is right up there with Witcher 3, Cyberpunk, Mass Effect and Dragon Age. You know how I judge when a world is A+ quality? When I frequently don't fast travel to locations even though I've been there because I just want to enjoy the scenery. And you don't just get one world - you get four because it feels so different in each of the four seasons - incredible.
2. The music - it's like being in a Harry Potter movie. And it's the best kind of game-soundtrack: you don't so much hear it as feel it. It's always present and enhancing the game without you even realizing it.
3. The sheer amount of cool things to do: like all the open-world RPG greats, this one is full of rocks to turn over and there's always something interesting underneath.

What I didn't like as much:
First off there was nothing in this game I didn't like, but there were some things that made me take away points from House Avalanche:
1. Some of the game elements felt a little shallow. I don't want to do spoilers but you'll see what I mean about 40 hours into the game. All the great A+ open-world RPGs fall victim to this - they try to do too much and then don't tie the loose ends together.
2. The morality of dark magic / good magic leads to some rather ridiculous situations in combat - again no spoilers but you'll see what I mean. Nothing that detracts from the game it just makes you scratch your head, giggle at the absurdity, and it is immersion breaking.
3. I wish there was a bit more variety of enemies - but this is something they'll expand with DLC I'm sure.

A great experience, one that made me forget my life and stay up too late several times. Only the best games do that. Buy this and enjoy it - we need to keep paying the people that make games like this so they'll keep making them!!!

Hogwarts Legacy is a massive approximation of what every HP fan was waiting for in a game. It has the magical dream of walking through Hogwarts Castle at your own pace and not having to follow what the books and movies do. 

Pros:
- I certainly enjoy the little details in the world and the references to the HP saga. I was walking quietly (or maybe not quietly) in all the Hogwarts and Hogsmeade corners.
- One of the best battle systems I've ever seen in an action game.
- An engaging story with lots of rich and exciting characters.

Cons:
- Not much real reason to play with other houses, besides looking at the different common rooms (which are beautifully designed). Only one big mission at the start makes the difference between houses.
- Lack of content at the end. I found myself getting 100% progress relatively quickly and there was not much more to do in the game after that.

I wish I Had:
- Quidditch
- Dynamic class attending
- More potions, plants and spells. (only a few, what the...) 

Overall is an enormous job for developers. There is potential to make the perfect game once they start working on DLC and updated content. The baseline is already here.

133678382.review:
Hogwarts Legacy was one of the most fun gaming experiences I've had in the last year. It provided an immersive world that is a dream for any Harry Potter Fan. The game excelled more than it failed in many retrospects. I beat the campaign and have 38 Hours in the game. Here is my perspective.

Successes of the game:

1. Immersion. Any building is possible to enter, loading screens are minimal, and everything flows extremely well in the world. I felt like I was in the Harry Potter Universe the whole time playing this.

2. The magic system. The way you fight with magic in this game, and interact with the world while using it is amusing and exciting at the  same time. The combat with magic had me on the edge of my seat throughout fighting the various monsters of the world, and the puzzles I had to use my magic on provided entertainment. 

3. Flying. This game did an amazing job with flying mounts and flying on your broom. I enjoyed flying around Hogwarts and seeing the size of the world in this game (it is huge)

4. Character development. The story of this game does an amazing job making you develop relationships with the characters you see that play a big role in the excitement of the game. Personally my favorite characters I became fond of playing this game were Sebastian Sallow and Natsai Onai. 

5. Lore. This game's' biggest strength without a doubt is lore. You see so many creatures described in JK Rowling's films, you see paintings on the walls described exactly like in the Harry Potter books, and you overall can tell the makers of this game took a lot of time to describe the Harry Potter Universe properly.

Failures of the game (although the game is far more of a success than failure):

1. Empty, but beautiful world. The world in this game is huge (which is another pro) but it is extremely empty outside of Hogwarts and Hogsmeade. Some areas had me wishing the developers spent more time adding details. The Forbidden Forest especially could have been WAY better. The world still maintains beauty but is very empty.

2. Slow narration. The start of the game is extremely slow, and it takes a while to get off your feet. Some parts had me thinking that characters were just providing filler in their narration. Some narration was also very boring and had me trying to skim over it as soon as I could.

3. Repetitive monsters/beasts. This game has a very enjoyable combat system and I also really enjoyed the aspect of taming beasts, but a lot of the monsters and beasts you interacted with were repetitive. You mostly only fight wolves, knights (pensieves), goblins, poachers, spiders, trolls, ashwinders, dugbogs, thieves, or inferiuses (zombies). For beasts you have like 6 you can capture and put in a habitat and nothing further. 

4. Side quests versus the main story. I wanted to start the game doing a lot of side quests but had to do the story because if I didn't I would not have all of the mechanics of the game unlocked (especially lockpicking. You don't get it until later in the main story when you should get it early on). The game pressures you to focus purely on the main story and getting it complete rather than doing any side quests which I think is a negative in a game trying to be free and open world. 

5. A game that missed out on a lot of potential in certain aspects. You pick a house when you begin the game, but the house you pick barely affects the plot of the game. I would have liked to have seen houses play a bigger role in the game. You also cannot do much in your house area. Throughout the game, they claim you can customize your character's gear in a unique fashion (including your wand), but the appearance of gear is extremely repetitive. Your wand customization is minimal, although it does exist which is nice. 

Overall, this game excelled in so many aspects of detail. It's biggest strength in my opinion is immersion and lore. This is the perfect game for a Harry Potter fan. Some points had me wish it went further with care for detail (especially when it comes to repetition of characters, clothes, etc), but it is an extremely great game. I would give it an 8.5/10.

133677824.review:
Overall Rating 9/10.

The game was very good and overall was polished and well made. It was a little "small" content wise to be a 10/10, compared to other games like Cyberpunk 2077 (played over 200 hours in with no DLC) and Witcher 3 (played over 300 hours including DLC). Part of the reason is also that there is relatively little replayability (a NG+ mode would be good to have).

I finished the Hogwarts Legacy main story in about 37 hours on Normal difficulty (was not rushing as I had reached level 38 out of 40 by then, and had spent several hours messing around in the Room of Requirement). It took another few hours to finish off all the in-game Collections and Challenges, and I had 100% Achievements after 44 hours on one character (not counting the additional 3 Achievements for which you need to complete a specific quest while playing a character in each house). This is on par with other single player RPGs I played such as Jedi: Fallen Order and Horizon Zero Dawn.

I enjoyed the story and thought it was good for the target Harry Potter audience. It is not revolutionary, and it's fairly easy to predict exactly how everything will play out. But it is well written with good voice acting, and scratches the nostalgia itch for fans of the IP. Combat and overall gameplay was responsive and fun. Some people are disappointed it's not a full blown simulation game, where you eat, sleep, and go the bathroom in between attending classes repeatedly. I think that would have been boring, and is not in the spirit of the original franchise. You see glimpses of routine school life, but that's all going on behind the scenes. We only saw Harry spending a fraction of his time "doing school" and Hogwarts Legacy is the same.

Performance was perfectly fine for me. I play at 1440p with a RTX 3070, Ryzen 5 3600, 32gb RAM, on an M.2 SSD. Settings a mix of High and Ultra, Quality DLSS, RT Off. I averaged around 70-80 fps with no significant dips or stuttering. The most annoying things were the occasional loading pauses when opening doors in Hogwarts, and items/characters loading slowly when entering a new area. This often happened when teleporting into Hogsmeade and running into invisible NPCs on the street who hadn't loaded yet. Neither of those should be happening to the extent that they are. I saw some minor graphical glitches, including students T-posing on a rare occasion, but nothing game breaking.

133676687.review:
Open World and Harry Potter works. It really does. What Hogwarts Legacy gives you is a large game, with a huge map to explore, and exploration really pays off. There's challenges all around the map, and just exploring Hogwarts alone is just fun. There's things to find everywhere in the castle, so much in fact that it's worth opening up every toilet stall.
The storyline is interesting, as are the side quests, the visuals are stunning, the music is lovely.

Warning: the following part contains spoilers.

You can tell that the makers were familiar with the movies and the novels, and they know how to cater to fans. There's nice little easter eggs, such as what happens to the humming suit of armor, or students getting screamers. And also just fan service, such as getting sorted into a house or what happens when you get your own wand.

I like the fact that you can customize your clothing however you like. You'll be able to use the look of every clothing item you ever found, even if you sell the actual item. So that's nice. There's also clothing items that have no other purpose than being cosmetic.

Sadly, the game is not without its fails. For one thing, the character you play is rather flat and one-dimensional. Always friendly and polite, even the way they habitually fold their hands. You get no background on them, and they have little in the way of personality at all. Even their way of speaking is pretty much always the same, no matter the situation. Being admitted as a fifth year student, you're apparently able to catch up  to your peers in little to no time (either that or the curriculum in Hogwarts is rather meager). You're also some kind of wunderkind who is able to basically not only master every skill first try, but also excell in it.

I mentioned that I like than you can change the look of every item of clothing. However, it can be a bit frustrating if you finish a challenge that takes a long time to complete (looking at you, daedalian keys!) and all you get is a special cosmetic item. Most of these challenges are, of course, optional, but there's one or two such challenges that you want to complete in order to gain access to more parts of the game (literally).

It would also be nice if the wand had more meaning. Sure, it's customizeable, but it's purely cosmetic. It would be nice if you could modify your wand to, for example, be stronger at destruction skills, or cause more damage with force skills, stuff like that.
The spells themselves are okay, but the spell slots are annoying. You get way more spells than you can equip at the same time. Especially since interacting with beasts or spells used solely for puzzle solving also take up spell slots. Even with the 16 slots you get in the end, I found myself constantly switching out spells. Maybe the devs introduce some sort of spell mode switch at some point, allowing to switch between damage slots and utility slots.

Your house doesn't really matter either, it only changes up a few dialogs a bit and slightly alters one or two quests.

Also, and that is a big shame, there is very little replay value. The story, as well as all the side quests, are almost completely linear. Your decisions simply do not matter and have very little to no effect on the game (other than perhaps a certain character being available or not, or learning an optional spell or not). Wether you choose to be nice and helpful, demand additonal rewards, keep stuff you're supposed to retrieve, support someone or refuse to do so, it doesn't matter. Even learning and using unforgivable curses has no consequences.
In fact, one of the biggest differences you'll get to experience is the comments enemies during battle, as they change depending on your tactics. Frequently use dark magic in battle? Like to throw militant vegetables at your opponents? They actually change their taunts according to that.

Also, I have to mention this, even though I'm not sure what to think of it. The game plays some time in the 18th to 19th century, so over 100 or even close to 200 years ago. I don't know what Great Britain looked like back then, but apparently the wizard society was rather... inclusive back then. Certainly more inclusive than muggle society at the time.

Still, the game is certainly a must-have for every Harry Potter fan, especially considering that the other games of the franchise, which were based on the novels or movies, well... they're a category in itself.

133676671.review: To be clear, this game is getting a positive review despite some significant performance issues still present. Mostly because it hits the HP aesthetic perfectly and the gameplay is fun. There's plenty to do without being overwhelmed. Audio is great. Graphics great with some fantastic scenes.

133676408.review:
[h1] Hogwarts Legacy is nearly the masterpiece that Harry Potter fans needed.[/h1]

I'm not the biggest Harry Potter fan, but I once watched a bit of the movies and, well, to say the least, thoroughly enjoyed them - this game reignited my want to enjoy Harry Potter and the Wizarding World once again. There's a lot to do, and much to explore in the open world that the game provides; the graphics of the game are beautiful, and I commonly found myself sitting in the air upon my broom and gazing out over the Highlands. 

However, while this game is almost perfect, there are still a few things that I'm not a fan of. To make things easy, I'll compile a full summary of my opinion in a list below -

Pros:
- Easily navigable menu system with efficiently-done tutorials and helpful pop-ups when needed.

- Combat is easy to learn, though somewhat hard to master, to an extent. Stringing spells isn't difficult, but timing the switching of sets can be a bit distracting.

- Hogwarts itself and the characters within, as well as around, in all the hamlets and down to the coast, are quite alive and feel like actual people. While you can still tell it's a game, they aren't badly done and are what you'd expect of the Potterverse.

- Utility of spells, potions and herbology items is well-balanced and smooth; large variety of spells too, making for a relatively expansive capability for different builds.

- The open world is expansive, and flying around it is extremely fun; another note on flying, too - while it is fun, the broom can be quite stiff on the controls sometimes. This isn't much of a problem though.

- Overall enjoyable game, and definitely replayable if you're the sort who enjoys seeing things again and noticing new things about them, such as foreshadowing, or if you'd just like to experience the magic of Hogwarts Legacy once again. 

Cons:
- Horribly optimised for PC, required me to do extensive modifications to game files as well as switch the graphics API in order to just stop the game from freezing. Extreme stuttering and lag upon first start, but after playing for about 5-10 minutes, it alleviates and the game actually becomes playable.
-- ^ I've personally discovered this to be an issue with the game's rendering engine, and this should be fixed within the next few patches, if not the next one.

- Excessive repetition in combat/ambient dialogue; while I understand NPCs are NPCs, hearing an Ashwinder go on about how I stole their Hippogriff or "I'll get what I'm due", in whatever fashion it's said, every single time I fight them is... boring, to say the least. Some more variety in the mid-fight trash talking would make things a bit nicer, and perhaps even some witty lines from the playable protagonist as they defeat enemies would've been a good inclusion too, as is done in the PlayStation Exclusive Spider-Man.

- Deaths in the game can feel a bit... empty, and rushed. To avoid spoilers, I won't be mentioning any, but to say the least, prominent side characters who die aren't typically mourned for long, if at all. The game feels pretty remorseless, especially with how the protagonist can so easily learn Avada Kadavra - especially under the conditions it's learnt - and overall just takes away the empathetic bit that we're used to seeing in Harry Potter. 

- Seemingly high-tier enemies, such as Trolls, become fodder in face of the Three Unforgivable Curses. While I do know this makes sense, it would just still feel better if they were at least still a challenge - I mean, hell, you can Imperio a Troll and just spam it to death from there, and it can't do anything. 

- Usage of ancient and dark magic is weirdly... [i]normalised?[/i] While it's shown repetitively in the HP movies that any of the Three Unforgivable Curses [TUC] are not to be touched - such is their namesake - and users of said curses are typically evil or seen as such, they are very casually mentioned, used and taught throughout the course of the game. While there are some touches here and there, such as certain characters mentioning their dislike/support of you using a curse against enemies in combat, their comments are empty and meaningless, and there's no effect on morality with any of the protagonist's friends. Furthermore, the TUC are heavily frowned upon for their harmful nature while ancient magic is casually brandished by the protagonist to... explode people into what seems to be pure magic, slam people into the ground thrice in one go, summon lightning bolts that eviscerate people from existence and destroy them with fireballs that send them soaring meters back - and, as evidently shown by the protagonist's monologues thereafter, said ancient magic attacks [b]kill[/b] these enemies.
So... if Avada Kadavra is so heavily guarded, kept secret and frowned upon when used due to being an instant-kill technique, then why can the protagonist of this game so casually use their ancient magic - an extremely overpowered, unique and rare ability - on literally any enemy they face, no matter who they're with? There's no sense in this, considering the ancient magic is basically doing the same as the TUC, but to an even more brutal extent. 
-- I do understand this is mostly for the sake of epic gameplay things, but there's still the fact that it's extremely nonsensical, especially considering the importance of the curses and even more-so Avada Kadavra.

[h1]My Overall Opinion[/h1]

While I don't think anyone has stuck around for this excessively long review, if you have, thanks! Or if you just skipped to the end for the TL;DR, that works too.

[b]Hogwarts Legacy, in my opinion, is a good stepping stone for the studio behind it to set up something more well-thought out, detailed and... for lack of better word, richer. They did an amazingly good job with this game, and I find myself getting lost in the visuals, exploration, combat and social scenarios that the game has to offer, and I don't believe that my problems with the game are intolerable. They're able to be ignored, to an extent, though when I find the game is a bit lacking in certain areas, I'm usually already dealing with something new and have forgotten about my problem from before. Overall, if you're a fan of large areas to explore, interesting things to see, callbacks and references to canon material, beautiful visuals, fast-paced and ragdoll-esque combat and would enjoy a fresh take on the Potterverse, this game is for you. Otherwise, even if you just enjoy RPG games with fluid combat, open areas and fun exploration, this game is also for you.[/b]

[u]I, personally, give this game a solid 8.5/10.[/u]

As an avid gamer, I am always on the lookout for games that can provide a truly immersive experience, and Hogwarts Legacy certainly delivers on that front. From the moment I started playing, I was blown away by the game's visuals - the attention to detail is truly stunning, and it really feels like you are exploring the magical world of Hogwarts.

But it's not just the visuals that impressed me - the story is equally captivating, and I found myself fully invested in the world and characters of the game. What really sets Hogwarts Legacy apart, though, is the way that small tasks and quests are seamlessly woven into the story progression. I usually find these kinds of tasks to be tedious, but in this game, I actually enjoyed doing them - they added depth and richness to the world and helped to flesh out the characters and story.

One of the things that really stands out about Hogwarts Legacy is the passion and love that the developers clearly have for the source material. This is a game that was clearly made by people who care deeply about the Harry Potter universe, and that passion shines through in every aspect of the game. The attention to detail, the lovingly crafted environments, and the richly developed characters are all a testament to the developers' dedication and love for the world of Harry Potter.

Overall, I cannot recommend Hogwarts Legacy highly enough. It's a truly remarkable game that manages to capture the essence of the Harry Potter universe in a way that few other games have been able to do. If you're a fan of the series, or just love immersive, story-driven games, then this one should definitely be on your must-play list. Five stars, without question.

133671011.review:
INGREDIENTES
MASSA
1/2 xícara (chá) de óleo
3 cenouras médias raladas
4 ovos
2 xícaras (chá) de açúcar
2 e 1/2 xícaras (chá) de farinha de trigo
1 colher (sopa) de fermento em pó

MODO DE PREPARO
MASSA
Em um liquidificador, adicione a cenoura, os ovos e o óleo, depois misture.

Acrescente o açúcar e bata novamente por 5 minutos.

Em uma tigela ou na batedeira, adicione a farinha de trigo e depois misture novamente.

Acrescente o fermento e misture lentamente com uma colher.

Asse em um forno preaquecido a 180° C por aproximadamente 40 minutos.

COBERTURA
Despeje em uma tigela a manteiga, o chocolate em pó, o açúcar e o leite, depois misture.

Leve a mistura ao fogo e continue misturando até obter uma consistência cremosa, depois despeje a calda por cima do bolo.

INFORMAÇÕES ADICIONAIS
Uma deliciosa receita de bolo de cenoura de liquidificador
 

Você poderá seguir ao vídeo ou a receita escrita, o resultado sairá perfeito dos 2 modos.

 

Para fazer seu bolo de cenoura de liquidificador de uma vez só é preciso um liquidificador potente, mas se achar a massa pesada para o seu aparelho, corte a cenoura em pedaços bem pequenos e só bata no aparelho os ingredientes úmidos. Depois que estiver tudo homogêneo, incorpore a mistura líquida aos ingredientes secos, mexendo bem e delicadamente. Além de poupar o seu liquidificador, misturar os ingredientes secos delicadamente com a mão também é o segredo para o seu bolo de cenoura não solar.

 

A receita de bolo de cenoura pode ser complicada porque exige alguns pequenos detalhes que garantem o resultado perfeito. Uma delas é a proporção de cenoura, que precisa ser correta para a receita que você está fazendo. Por isso, para ter certeza de que não irá fazer um bolo solado, você pode utilizar a mesma medida da nossa receita de ovo bolo de cenoura, cerca de 250 g de cenoura para 2 copos de farinha de trigo.

 

Para garantir o seu bolo de cenoura fofinho, lembre-se de testar o fermento antes de adicioná-lo à massa e peneire a farinha de trigo! Isso vai garantir que um bolo de cenoura fofo, leve e ainda mais delicioso!

 

Se você prefere um bolo de cenoura cremoso, faça uma calda para umedecer seu bolo! Basta adicionar 1 xícara de açúcar e 1 xícara de água em uma leiteira e, assim que levantar fervura, desligue o fogo. Quando esfriar completamente, você pode regar seu bolo. Se quiser incrementar essa mistura para deixar ainda mais gostoso e dar um perfume ao seu bolo de cenoura, você pode adicionar raspas de laranja, essência de baunilha ou um pouco de canela. Dessa forma, você vai ter um bolo de cenoura molhadinho e delicioso!

Quer ir além do bolo de cenoura simples?
 

O bolo de cenoura é delicioso de qualquer jeito: se quiser um bolo de cenoura simples, daqueles que vão bem com um cafezinho, basta não fazer a calda. Mas se você não perde a oportunidade de comer chocolate e não abre mão da calda para bolo de cenoura, confira nesse vídeo 3 receitas de cobertura de chocolate para bolo e escolha qual vai você quer colocar no seu bolo de cenoura com calda de chocolate!

 

Se você está de dieta e está morrendo de vontade de comer um bolo de cenoura, que tal conferir outras opções de bolo de cenoura do TudoGostoso como bolo de cenoura fit, bolo de cenoura vegano, bolo de cenoura low carb, bolo de cenoura com aveia, bolo de cenoura integral e mais!


Essa receita de bolo de cenoura fácil é perfeita pra quem precisa de uma receita rápida, mas se você tem mais tempo que tem fazer um bolo de cenoura recheado ou bolo de cenoura vulcão? Ninguém vai resistir!

133670762.review:
There's quite a lot of JKR (original author) controversy surrounding this title, rightfully so. I'm not going to go in to it, suffice to say, google it yourself and decide if you want to boycott or purchase this title.

This is probably the most enjoyable 6/10 title (by this I mean that it's a heavily flawed game, no objective numeric x/y score exists) I've ever played. The game has some major flaws, the writing being inconsistent, at times lazy and a lot of plot elements suffers heavily from "idiot plot". The game also loves giving you the illusion of choice, but in actuality it's more the case of "do this with a smile", "do this but snark and demand money the entire way through". Most of the side-quests are glorified delivery / fetchquests. The story is also poorly paced, frontloading the mainquest plotpoints then forgetting them for the midpart of the game, only for needing to speedrun the last points for the climactic finale. There are some RPG elements that feel forced into the game because that's what other open world systems have. While the levling system works as a guide, encouraging you to keep within level appropriate zones, the gear and gear-improvement system feels vestigial. The gear system basically boils down to bigger number better and the upgrade system merely exists to justify the pokemon esque catch em all type of activities. The flying controls also feels very clunky, basically your character exists on a set plane and you're not as much navigating a 3 dimensional area as you're navigating through a 2d area with more accessible through increasing/decreasing your height.

*But* I could not put this game down. It does the HP-verse justice by having the same feeling of wonder and wimsy around it. Having to go to class to learn spells, some homework assignments for you to do before learning the next spell, Hogwarts as a whole. All of it feels spot on. The collectibles that litter the place feels more enjoyable to search out compared to any other open world in my recent memory. The combat feels fluid and punchy, and while it doesn't make much sense in universe the rock paper siccors type of shielding fits in well. The combat controls does feel a bit too "console" adapted, but I'd suggest rebinding some of the spellslots hotkeys to mouse4-5 (and other mousebuttons you may have) as I personally found the scrollwheel to be too easy to pick the wrong scrollslot. While the gearcrafting system feels vestigial, the potioncrafting and herbology systems fit in perfectly with the original Universe.

All in all I'd give this a recommendation, especially if you like the Harry Potter universe. 

TL;DR, babies first witcher but with less story writing chops

133668610.review:
- To play this game for me personally was a childhood dream come true. It's fulfils that itch of being a wizard.
- Riled up people on social media should not stop you playing this game if you really want to.
- All the complaints I have about this game are minuscule, like the removal of Quidditch.
- Never the less, I think they will probably add Quidditch in DLC, then we will have the complete package!
- So let's go over some of the things I like and the minor inconveniences the game, first the negatives:

- We have all probably noticed, the game lags at higher graphics, even on good systems, why is this?
- Over all my searching, it seems like there is severe memory leak issues with this game.
- More over, there are some backend bugs due to how the source code was implemented into the game.
- Everything you can do to limit this won't fix that, you need Ascendio mod to have a chance to fix it.
- Not sure if this will be fixed in future, but if you are fine with mods, there is at least a good fix for it.

- As for gameplay itself, I wish you could reset talents, also I hope we get an increase in spell variety.
- Really, the gameplay is fine, very fluid, could do with some touch ups in dodge indicators, seen it bug a bit.
- Evil characters wont have THAT much consequences either, like Avada Kedavra is just like saying a swear.

- Not seen much bugs, I did fall through the floor once which was weird, it didn't let me open my map either.
- On top of that, sometimes rolling and climbing are a bit... inconsistent, you can end up in unintended places.
- Take the Witches Tomb, there is a platform you can climb up, only a specific angle.... for some reason...???

- Bugs and weird gameplay aside. They seem fairly minimal, let's talk about the forced "representation":
- Every dialogue option refers to you as "They", I get it's due to 'modern times' but it feels very out of place.
- In some dialogue it just doesn't flow well, it's like they intended the dialogue to have he/him and she/her.
- Now I don't mind if they was an option, but the other two options should also be a thing.
- Guess they wanted to avoid drama from the mob, at that point, was just a futile effort, same with Sirona.

- Kindness and empathy may be the intention of the developers, but it just comes off as pandery after a while.
- I do admit though, these interactions are not that bad and are far between. Doesn't impede the game really.
- Let's talk about the unforgivables: OP, not as OP as you think. You will run Avada Kedevra all the time.
- Learning new spells sometimes is a waste since you wont use them but more variety is always good tbh.
- Every spell has a use but some overlap. I wish the Room of Requirements spells didn't need to be hot barred.
- Difficulty is pretty decent, but you could go through this entire game without being hit once I think.

- Oh also forgot, the stealth system is a bit  bare boned but it's also not the worst, needs expanding to be sure.
- Very nearly every situation can be overcame with brute force, there are small required stealth parts tho.
- Even then, these are scripted parts, not something you would naturally use in the open world as much.
- Really... overall, these are BARELY nitpicks at all.

- The combat is excellent and so many combos, load outs and rotations I've seen on youtube.
- Hitting people with certain spells feels so punchy. The fantasy is there for being a truly powerful wizard.
- I personally like to use expelliarmus to disarm opponents then use Magic to throw their weapons at them.
- Sound is also great, every spell has a unique feel and puts you into that fantasy of being a wizard so well.

- Game of the year contender to be sure. Though I suppose it isn't all that revolutionary, it's just plain fun.
- Another open world game, but at least this time, you have a true feeling of fantasy and role play.
- Minus some of the forced dialogue, the script for the game ain't bad, funny moments too with students.
- Every npc seems to have some trigger that makes them say something at certain times or do something.

- To me as well, the characters are great, already seeing people thirst over the Herbology teacher, jeez lmao.
- Overall the charecterization of each house is spot on, I love the clothing, the areas and the students designs.
- Until they allow Quidditch or house points, this can be expanded on, it's mostly cosmetic at the moment.
- Common rooms too look nice, not any customization there, but that is what the room of requirement is for.
- Hufflepuff has the best Jackdaw mission btw, they go to a very well known place in the wizarding world.

- Great game.
- Reccomend to anyone who loves the wizarding world.
- All the things you expect are here, not rocking the boat but what we need right now.
- Salazar.
- Slytherin.

133666919.review:
Is this game worth your money?
I think the answer to this question boils down to this. Are you a harry potter fan? Or atleast have some love for the world this game is set in. Then this game will not disappoint. The environments in this game faithfully recreate the wizarding world with few exceptions. Such as the forbidden forest being in the completely wrong place.

As a long time harry potter fan I do have some criticism on some of the choices. The story itself is a bit simple and leaves a lot to be desired. Personally I would have liked something more grounded, but this game just had to go with the chosen-one ancient magic gimmick that gets old pretty quickly. It also doesnt seem plausible to me that all these huge ancient magic structures are just forgotten about after this time period. The ancient magic dungeons make hogwarts look like a pretty stupid building in comparison.

The story itself however is acceptable though disappointing in some ways. It seemed the developers wanted to include some choices in your playthrough. And included things like unforgivable curses and allowed you to be a bit of an asshole in dialogues. But I feel they shouldve left these out. They don't make sense to me. If you are going to include evil choices in your game then let my character be evil and dont switch my character to talking like goodie two shoes five minutes later.

The characters aren't quite there. They're just.. not that interesting. Harry potter is a series about friendships with other characters. And they certainly tried to accomplish it by having a few students with specific questlines which you become friends with. The problem however, is that outside of these questlines you never interact with them, they never accompany you, they never interact with each other either. I think I read a lot of people say the same. This game feels a bit lonely. Despite this there are some shining stars. The sebastian/ominis questline having the strongest characters by far.

The world itself also doesnt make you quite feel connected to it. It's like you are a ghost walking through hogwarts but no one can actually see you. When night time comes the castle is mostly deserted and prefects dont even come after you anymore. Even during cutscenes you will find the great hall only with a handful of students.

The audio is probably this games biggest sin. No hate towards the voice actors, I am sure they tried. But nothing killed the excitement for my own wizard character more than the voice performance. I couldn't stand the voice acting on him. (i dont know how the female one sounds) and then the pitch correction just makes your voice sound metallic likely because they use a broken in game filter. The sound design itself is pretty good, but the voices, the dialogue just has not been done well at all. A lack of integration. it feels like the voices are just put straight into the game out of a studio.

This game also cannot help but to fall into the trap of countless open world games. They create a certain gameplay loop. Puzzles, bandit camps, you name it. But then overdo it. I cannot tell you how many times I found the EXACT same treasure vault in different places around the world. Or the IDENTICAL puzzle I had to do again and again. Whilst yes, a lot of this is skippable. Why do game devs keep doing this? Quality over quantity. This game couldve done by cutting down the map size 3 times over. The further south you go the less interesting it becomes.

Despite all these criticisms this game is worth it in 2 cases in my opinion:
1. You are a harry potter fan and love the world of HP
2. You like standard run of the mill open world games

This game is no more special than any other open world game I've played. A 30 hour or so main story+side quests with 10-20 hours of filler. If thats okay with you. Go for it.

133661126.review:
A fairly solid game that gets infinitely better if you are a Harry Potter fan, because the best thing about it is being in the wizarding world and Hogwarts. If you are not a fan, I imagine it might be hit or miss. 

The open world is quite vast and not limited to Hogwarts and close areas - I was honestly quite shocked when I saw the size of the map. You get your broom to fly around fairly early so I imagine it had to be huge to make it feel big enough for it. It is full of points of interest that give you stuff to do there, most of it however I felt was uninspired and mostly the typical open world "map puke" padding. I understand they needed wider world to make some quests and not making all center just around Hogwarts, but on the other hand I'd bu quite OK to just have Hogwarts, Hogsmead, Forbidden Forest and surrounding areas accessible and still think of it as big enough.

Main story is.... okay. For me the side quests were the stars, especially those centered around my classmates and which I'd call "main side quests". There are your filler side quests there too, but the questlines where you develop friendships with other Hogwarts students, alongside the "quests" that simulate classes to learn new spells are very well done and simulate the Hogwarts feeling perfectly.

Talking of spells: there. Is. So. Many! And it's great balance too - some from books, some from movies and there is even Flipendo for those who remember the now ancient Harry Potter movie tie-in games. While it gets difficult to juggle all of them as time wents on and your arsenal broadens, the combat is overall really good and each enemy has specific combo you should use on them to exploit their weaknesses. Combat was one of the great surprises for me as I never really imagined it being so good.

All in all, this is a good pick for anyone that loves open world games RPGs (though theRPG elements are on light side) and don't mind the now typical open world design of "lets puke points of interest with almost coppied challenges all over the place". But it's an absolute must for any Potterhead out there purely for the cheer joy of wandering Hogwarts.

133658360.review:
If you like Harry Potter I'm sure you'd get something out of this game, except for quidditch.

After ~75 hours, the art and attention to detail, especially in Hogwarts is quite simply the best thing about this game, there is a reason the art team is first in the credits, award winning with this level of quality and detail. 

Elements of this game are fun, but are pulled down by a number of design decisions which I'll go through.
1. Enough spells, but you're restricted to 4 at any given moment and due to the Protego defense mechanism if you have only one of the spells and waste it you're running around until it resets or you have to clunkily change menus to get another defense break spell. I would put combat into clunky, but OK.
2. Story, the story drags and that's a real bad thing because the magic of Hogwarts is diminished at every hour past 25-30. The story and how it plays out is as clunky as the combat, a lot of back and forth completing inane side missions to proceed with the main story line.
3. NPC story lines, I never felt anything or any connection with them, they're forced on the character and you go through it like a hamster runs on the hamster wheel.
4. Travel is good, they have fast travel, beasts and brooms.
5. The upgrade system is medicore, I never felt more powerful with any of the upgrades.
6. The room of requirement and beast collection side game was just a time wasting chore.
7. I chose to have may character not learn unforgivable curses, this had no effect to my knowledge on reactions, how people treat you or ending.
8. Due to the length of clunky story a lot of the fighting, discovery, Merlin trials all become either mundane rote, or just not worthy of your time. Killing the same thing for the nth time has no capture by the middle of the game.

Gamers could be forgiven to play about 30 hours of this game and drop it, which I assume a lot would.

It really needed the Rockstar's Bully element to have enough edge to make it a unforgettable game. You're in  what amounts to private(public in the UK) high school in England and yet none of those tropes were examined, which is a missed opportunity for immersion, replayability and general world building.

Why I do recommend this game, even with its issues, is that Hogwarts art and design are so good that it alone is worth a play, but definitely get it on a massive sale. This game is not work $80/$90 which is what I paid in AUD.

133658293.review: Amazing story, great for any harry potter fan. Combat is interesting and engaging. Overall worth buying, especially for the amount of content you are getting.

133657968.review:
What an absolute magical experience.

When I first saw gameplay for this game I was sceptical, this just looked too good, it will never live up to what the developers showed off.. but to my pleasant surprise it did. As a Potter fan this is a must play, the game you've been waiting for!

The best thing about the game is 100% the world, a great open world with lots of things to do. Each area has it's own unique feeling, from the spooky atmosphere of the forbidden forest to the open, airy feeling of the southern coast. Hogsmeade is a delightful wizard village, brimming with life and Hogwarts itself? Oh my..

What they did with Hogwarts is nothing short of amazing, it's so big and detailed, every room is different and there are secrets everywhere. 30 Hours into the game I was still finding parts of the castle I hadn't discovered yet. Truly a labour of love of the developers, it shows. Not even speaking about how they did all this without any loading screens!

The combat is fluid and easy to learn, reminding me a lot of the arkham combat system. It also provides a lot of variation with the 30+ different spells you can use. There's also a stealth system if one would want to go that route but I find that it is quite basic.

The main story is nothing amazing but still very enjoyable, the characters are all really likeable and you really feel like a student in the wizarding school. But the game's story really shines in the side quests, some of the 'relationship questlines' are really memorable. 

TLDR, this game is a dream come true for every Potter fan, a game made with a lot of love by developers who really care and it shows. And for people who are not really fans of the franchise can still find a lot of enjoyment in this solid made game.

133654296.review:
This game has some performance issues. I'm not a fan of real life politics getting shoehorned into games, so the lgbt stuff in it did take me out of the game, but it wasn't super prevalent, or shoved in my face so I was able to ignore what there was.
I'm fine with politics as long as it is part of the story and lore. The Dragon Age franchise nailed that part of their games.
Everything else about this game is incredible. My computer hits the minimum requirements, unfortunately, but even then it still looks great. The spells are fun to use, the door puzzles really had me stumped until I sat down for an hour and figured them out, only to find a sort of 'cheat sheet' not long after.

The combat is fun, but there is a bit of clunkiness to it. I think they intended for all of the defensive abilities, the shield and the roll, to be used together, but they made it so the roll was usable for everything and the shield only usable with the basic enemies. Mini bosses and some more advanced enemies can totally ignore your shield and wreck your whole existence.
If you do a spell set to blow through the shields of every color, you can just roly poly through everything and wreck everything. If you're stubborn, like me, you could stupefy through any shield and use whatever spell you want. Problem is, I'm not always ready to roll and I get smacked around a bit. The lag doesn't help. I could get destroyed in a slideshow fight only to respawn and the fight runs perfectly and I get through it without a scratch. Just some issues with performance. 

Inventory space isn't great either. I have upgraded my inventory a couple times, so it isn't asbad anymore, but for the first 10 hours I played the game after the tutorial/prologue stuff I probably spent at least one hour at hogsmeade selling crap because I couldn't hold more than one pound worth of clothing (slight exaggeration)

I was initially a little disappointed by the character customization. I had hoped for a little more freedom with it, something like Elden Ring or Dragon Age Inquisition and it ended up being more like Monster Hunter World. Not that MHW is bad. I have around 400 hours in MHW so I can live with a similar character creation. I did love the wand creation though. I was able to find a design I liked and even themed it. I also found a beautiful handle for it early on and have stuck with it since.

I'm also a huge fan of the Victorian Era style of the clothes. I know it takes place during that time, but I found myself thinking many times "Oh this look old fashioned and really cool...Oh wait, it's actually the style of the time this takes place in" 
I'm not sure that's actually a good thing now that I think on it. If it takes place in Victorian England and I have to remind myself of that when I'm looking at the clothes, I think they might have done too many of the clothes too modern for the time.

It is a great game, it's holding my attention and I'm already planning a second playthrough and I'm not even to the second trial yet.

133654080.review:
I'm not a big Harry Potter fan and I'm very picky about spending money on games. So when I say to immediately buy one I don't do so lightly. This is the first case of me getting excited for a game and not being let down, with my hopes and expectations actually being exceeded entirely.

Pros:
- The setting, world, details, rules, and general function of everything on a lore level mesh beautifully
- The music is fantastic, changing between quest moments to flying to combat seamlessly to match every given moment
- The combat is incredibly fun, almost as if someone on the team said "What if our wizard was a gunslinger?"
- The exploration of the world as a whole is generally incredibly charming, streamlined by multiple forms of travel and interactive objects and challenges at nearly every turn. The world is packed with content.
- Unraveling the mystery behind the motives of the protagonists and antagonist of the story is interesting and keeps you wanting more
- The primary side characters and their plotlines are interesting and moving, albeit sometimes inconsistent

Cons:
- Collection activities and achievements are tedious. Merlin trials are the prime example, being repetitive and time-consuming to complete for their achievement, with about two dozen needing to be completed after getting the final unlock from their completions in order to get that achievement. Ancient magic challenges are similar in this regard, requiring more effort with less to complete.
- The writing gets slightly shaky at the end of the main quests, with characters who haven't shown prominence in the story showing up at the climax to help while the ones who did have prominence are nowhere to be found.
- The choices you make don't make a particularly huge difference in the grand scheme of things. There are two diverging "endings" after the climax depending on your choice right before the final battle. Everything else isn't meaningful and characters don't do much other than offhandedly mention your accomplishments and actions in passing idle lines.
- On the performance side of things: Frame dips are common, especially in Hogwarts itself and Hogsmeade. I experienced a single crash during a scene change in a quest, but none other than that. The game is stable overall, but the frame dips can be jarring.

Neutrals:
- It is incredibly easy to build your character into an unstoppable one-man magical army, especially when you have the perks for Crucio and Imperio unlocked. Avada Kedavra gets memed to death, but is acquired so late in the game that you're likely to already be annihilating legions of enemies with ease. Still, the game gives you that option - don't want to have to DoT, debuff, and burst down a big enemy in a few seconds? Have the instakill spell instead.
- Certain aspects of the game are left almost intentionally open-ended. Quidditch is omitted from the game, an entire section of the Room of Requirement stays closed, and at least one companion story has an ambiguous future to it. This could be seen as a way for DLC to get added, or it could be seen as places where the devs fell short. I hope for the former.
- The animations in dialogue are reused over and over and are almost always just you and the other NPC standing, never leaning or sitting. It can be seen as somewhat unnatural.
- You can't have a pet cat, but you can pet all the cats

Overall I give the game a 9/10, it could easily contend for GOTY if recency bias doesn't rear its ugly head later this year for a different title. 

P.S. - I want a puffskein

133650702.review:
THIS REVIEW WILL CONTAIN MILD SPOILERS.

Computer specs:

- Desktop PC
- Nvidia GeForce 2060
- i7 9th Gen
- 16GB DDR4

I cannot begin to describe how incredible of an experience this game is but I will do my best. 

I will start with criticisms/cons so I can save the best stuff for last:

- This game desperately needs a karma system. You can run around casting as many unforgivable curses as you wish and there are no repercussions outside of a few comments made by your companions if you use them on companion quests. You'll also absolutely loathe some of your fellow students and want to be mean to them or see them continue to be "villains" but every character comes around to the good side eventually.

- The Merlin trials (and the other puzzles for that matter) are quite frustrating and can be buggy. I've taken to always having my phone nearby to look up walkthroughs, which I don't particularly enjoy doing.

- Glitches! Oh boy. The stuttering glitch was absolutely insane but there are ways to fix it, mainly by lowering your graphics settings. Also I really do recommend playing this with more than 16GB of RAM. It is an extremely taxing video game and while I do not identify as an attack helicopter my computer most certainly does. I have had to literally put my headphones on because of how loud the fan got. Might just be my hardware and I will be expanding my RAM.

- You only have to deal with Prefects in the school twice and I think it would be a lot more fun if every night you had to deal with them and sneak around. It would help with the immersion a lot.

- Again this may be just something on my end but your character's voice may sound like the lines were recorded in a tin can. 

- The spell slot system can be a bit weird to get used to at first but after a few hours of combat it feels very intuitive.

- The skill tree really doesn't need to be invested into more than halfway, a lot of the perks are absolutely useless.

- Oh, and don't plan on a 100% run any time soon. Several of the quests are glitched. However you do get to explore the world as much as you want after you finish the main quest so you will be able to go back into your save once those are patched.

Now on to the positives!

- The graphics are positively gorgeous. Even when I had to run on the lowest settings for a while, because of the stuttering issue, it was still a lovely experience.

- Unlike what the keyboard warriors on Twitter will say, this game is incredibly diverse and trans friendly. Sirona is a delightful character and I wish we got to interact with her more. The controversy around her name is also very funny to me as well considering we make jokes about our names all the time or adapt a differently gendered version of our names. You can customize your character's gender expression, voice, and choose which dormitory they stay in. You are not bound to a binary system at all. Additionally, your character is referred to with gender neutral pronouns through the entire playthrough. And while your character obviously cannot engage in any romantic entanglements, you will run into the occasional queer character here and there who speaks highly of their partner. The people who criticize this game as somehow falling in line with JK Rowling's beliefs are absolutely insane.

- Another note on what critics are saying: this is not "literally a nazi simulator". The goblins in this game do not take after Jewish people, there is no appropriation of Jewish culture that I could personally find, and this goblin rebellion does not revolve around a true liberation of the goblins or an equal rights movement. It revolves around Ranrok who is only using his followers for the purpose of gaining power for himself and he has cursed them and other creatures so that they will do his bidding. You will run into the occasional character who hates goblins but you will be able to sway their minds and get them to see reason. And, for the most part, the characters are not bigoted whatsoever. Of course, you will hear the occasional line going against mudbloods or half bloods but that's to be expected with Headmaster Black's reign. Also, there are rumors that mods in the official Discord are banning people for being Jewish but I have yet to find any real evidence of that. This controversy was 100% blown out of proportion.

- The purchase of this game does not directly support JK Rowling either. She received a licensing fee but does not receive loyalties.

- The combat is lots of fun and extremely challenging on higher difficulties. It is a bit funny though how you can run around murdering countless enemies with other spells but for some reason the Dark Arts are shunned.

_ You can pet the cats.

_ The beasts are so much fun and absolutely precious. I can't quite wrap my head around selling them for a profit even if the shopkeeper at Brood and Peck is rehoming them, though.

- There are tons of easter eggs, hidden questions, trials/puzzles, and places for you to explore. Don't rush yourself because none of the quests expire. 

- It truly feels like you are living in the world of Harry Potter. I could have never asked for a better game. Flying around the castle feels so surreal and getting to walk through/explore all the areas we've seen in the movies has been an absolutely phenomenal experience. 

I cannot possibly list all of the positives here but please do not allow yourself to be bullied into not purchasing this game. I almost did. I have to hide the fact I am playing this game from everyone except one friend and my partner. This isn't even my main steam account. Being part of the LGBT/Jewish communities means that, sadly, JK Rowling's words and the words of her supporters do hurt. It also means that I have to rub shoulders with the people who give our community a bad name. On their behalf I am so sorry to anyone who may have been affected by their actions.

Harry Potter was there for me growing up when no one else was. The books and movies were how I escaped the mental torment of a very abusive family. When I got to visit the Wizarding World of Harry Potter, at Universal Studios Orlando, it was like a dream come true. Now this game brings me that same joy, that same escape, those same good feelings and good memories--except I can visit Hogwarts any time I want without paying an arm and a leg for plane tickets!

Overall I give this game a 9 Puffles out of 10 Quaffles. I 100% recommend purchasing.

For the record: about half my playtime has been AFK.

It's a good game but it really overstays it's welcome. The enemy variety is limited and can become boring after you've fought spiders, poachers, goblins and dark wizards for the 100th time. Where is the creativity when it comes to enemy variety? you have over TWENTY years of lore to draw inspiration from.

The story is interesting but the character animations during cut scenes are stiff and wooden and the voice acting can be very dry at times. You could argue that this is a staple of open world games due to their sheer size and scope but Red Dead Redemption 2 came out almost five years ago...

The reason why I give this game a positive review is in it's exploration and combat. I've always wanted a Potterverse game of this scope ever since childhood so call it biased if you must. I never grew tired of the combat and I enjoyed mixing and matching spells to combine the best combo's.

133644077.review: The game does the HP world justice in the best way possible. I'd consider myself a distant observer, saw a couple of movies in the cinema back when they were released, but definitely not hugely knowleadgable about the lore and so on. And yet, the game works on many levels. Yes, some of the mechanics are known from other major titles (like the Revelio mechanic revealing objects of interest in the player's proximity, just like in Assassin's Creed), and some of the combat and design cues feeling Souls-like, but that's not necessarily a bad thing, especially if the formula has worked so successfully. And, maybe, some of the characters' faces tend to look alike (like in Witcher 3, for example). But, all things considered, Hogwarts Legacy is a great feel-good kind of game that lets you do tons of fantasy roaming around and roleplaying as a Hogwarts student on your own. Plus, it's beautifully designed with so many varied places and objects to stop and marvel at, There's plenty of lessons to be learnt too for younger players if you are a parent. If I had children, I'd definitely let them play to their hearts' content. Lessons of tolerance, acceptance, assertiveness, and about being non-judgemental when it comes to differences. Lessons that some of the keen culture warriors with a purpose could be reminded of, too. The developers deserve cudos for doing it right.

Why can no one get building snapping correct? If snapping is turned off, I expect pixel perfect movement - not snapping to everything next to it and glued to it until you move 90 degrees away. It's ridiculous!

Even when moving, the ghost of the furniture still has collision with your character and the new location. You can place 2 items, try to change color of 1, but the Alteration spell forces a movement because it is no longer in a valid location. Now you can't place it back down where it was and you have to rearrange everything to find and remove the 1 thing blocking it. Hell, even the red "you can't build here" outline disappears 90% of the time, so you are guessing where you need to place the damn thing. Abhorrent. 15 mins into the RoR - how does this get pass so many people to get released in this state? I'd rather it not be in the game than it be this abysmal to work with.

Rest of the game has been fine. Random enemy "shields" coming up and wasting a cool-down is too annoying to be a coincidence - the AI must be programmed to body-block for each other. Using shift/ctrl for vertical flight, instead of - you know - the mouse!!!, is moronic. Waiting for potions does not feel as good as waiting for plants - rather play a 10-20 sec mini-game, honestly.

Map appears to be sufficiently large to get lost in. Some places feel a bit sparse. Hogwarts is 95% hallways and stairs, no one actually goes to school or lives there.

133638113.review:
Tl;dr, If you are a Harry Potter fan then you'll enjoy the game. The gamemechanics are smooth and easy to get into. Dont worry if you arent a diehard gamer, you'll do fine. The world will take you right back to the movies.

I've only ever seen the movies, greatly enjoyed them as the story is fairly welldone. So I thought I'd try the game. Not a dissapointment. 
The graphics are good, even on my now old 1080ti, playing on high. I do get the ocassional stutter but usually its smooth. The countryside looks great, the real beauty in the game however, is the castle itself with its different buildings with different styles. The room interiors are very detailed and furnished.
Cant say the same about houses in the countryside, those are rather small but not a big deal.

The combat in the game revolves entirely casting spells at targets you auto aim. It makes the action rather smooth and for someone who is used to manually aiming, its a bit easy at times. The challenge comes from specific enemies like trolls or if you are completely outnumbered.
The game has lots of puzzles that require the use of various spells. Most of these puzzles arent too difficult and your character will repeat hints(Wish they didnt). Sometimes, the puzzles require that you do some looking around the place but the solution is rarely far away.
The game was designed with a large audience in mind.

The quests are varied, though smaller sidequests are a bit limited. You'll find several in the castle and some in the villages. In total there might not be more than 50 smaller sidequests. Not counting the main questline and major sidequests. Its especially these sidequests that are good and one in particular.
I think my main issue is that after a while, you will have done all sidequests and most of the world is a sandbox with enemies. Many of which respawn. But apart from the vendors, only questgivers will talk to you, until you've done their quest. Thats unfortunate.

The main quest has variation and its unique enemies, aswell as puzzles. This main quest is required to advance the game itself.
HL relies on a levelling system and you will gradually unlock spells as you play parts of the main questline, buildings and tools. Some equipment like brooms level locked aswell. Personally not a great fan of the system but its okay.

The clothing, of which there is a wide variety in this game, is also knitted into the level system. Outfits will have offense and defense qualities. The higher your level, the better the outfits you find. You'll also be able to improve some of these stats if you advance far enough in the main questline.
The game fortunatly has a transmog system, allowing you to use the gear with the best statistics while retaining the look of whatever clothing takes your fancy.
In school I wore the school robes, but in the highlands I picked coats and jackets I liked best. Appareantly in the lore, fifth year students are allowed to wear whatever they like under their school robes when in class.

I greatly enjoy the game and would absolutely recommend it to anyone who likes HP. Feels a little bit Elden Ring though a little bit easier. The game is an experience rather than a challenge.

133638098.review:
i'm a very casual HP fan, as in I've read the books and watched most of the movies only once except for maybe the third and fourth movies a few more times when I used to have cable and they happen to be on TV. But, even I have moments that give me goosebumps. It's not like this is a perfect game, but it's still the best single player RPG I've played in years, especially because it doesn't force me to play in first person.

There are definitely things I would add to the game or give more importance to but it's still a truly immersive experience and I'm already enjoying what changes can be made with mods that give more freedom with character customization etc. Considering this game was made by a team without experience in single player RPGs, and they've mentioned the limitations they faced over the last few years, I'm really excited to see what we get from DLC and future games in the franchise. It gives me a lot of hope that relaxing single player RPGs are here to stay.

133636142.review:
As someone who played this game during the weekend instead of spending their time doing something productive, has not watched the films, has only read half of the first book, has not played any of the previous games, and only bought the game because of the exceptional advertisement done by a certain communities, I feel that I am the most suitable person to give this game a review.

Story - I enjoyed the story and was hooked into it at some point. I wouldn't call it "woah, that's amazing" or "omg, didn't see that coming" type of story. But it was enough to keep me engage and continue instead of sleeping on time. The sidequests seems to influence the main story quest to some degree during the dialogues. However I am able to confirm this.

Combat - I found the combat quite challenging at times. Although it is also not too hard. It became somewhat easier as I got used to the controls, got more spells, and managed to finally achieve my bankai speeding through the combat area. Using potions and/or the herbs does give a huge help on the difficult ones but not necessary.

Graphics - Like my previous reviews this is not my department. I play at low/medium settings and had no issue with it so far. Combined with vast beautiful world to explore, this is where the graphics of the game tend to shine. There are a few random stuttering if I'm nitpicking. But it's kind of a normal for me and it doesn't bother me. No really, it doesn't.

Exploration - What can I say - it's a vast beautiful world to explore. There are 'teleport stations/floo' so walking might be a viable option if you really want to find the nooks and crannies. There is also other modes of tranport like the broom which looks really comfy to sit on. I did find landing difficult to begin with but I realized at some point that you can just hold the button for it.

Other Features - When I'm sneaking, my character will say spells quietly such as "revelio" and I thought that was pretty cool.

I have enjoyed my experience with this game and would recommend it to others and newcomers to the series. It is not often that I play a singleplayer game continuously but have done so for Hogwarts Legacy.
