133635495.review:
The game I've been waiting for finally came, it delivered and exceeded my expectations!

The fluidity of the fights are superb, the bgm in every area I'm in is very beautifully placed, the competitiveness of some side quests from the students are great, the story telling of the main quest was nicely put together, hogwarts itself along with hogsmeade and the other areas are just absolutely breathtaking. A lot of things the devs got right with this game that other big companies with AAA games strived to achieve but failed miserably. Lookin at you cyberpunk.

For me, the game was worth the price and I enjoyed every single second of it. I'm done with the main story as of writing this review but I still have a few side quests remaining and a lot more areas to discover. This will probably be my first ever game on steam to 100%.

My only irks:
Story - A little short for my liking. I thought I'd get to have main quests that'll take me all throughout the areas but nope, you have to explore them on your own.

Game Play - More spells! I have no complaints about the current spell sets but I kinda wanted more. There's no way I'd be a 5th year going to Hogwarts with only a few spells in my pocket. 

Cutscenes - I wish we could pause cutscenes so I can take pictures. That's all I ask for.

Transportation - Faster brooms when?

Bugs - AI gets confused very rarely when you pull them from their designated "work space" as I like to call them. They just run in a 2x2 square feet endlessly and just stops doing anything else other than running in that tiny 2x2 space. It's funny with the bugs so I guess this doesn't technically count as an irk.

With that said, the game is very fun, engaging, immersive and it has some interesting dialogue choices for you to choose from, nothing too game changing don't worry. If you're a fan of the Harry Potter universe then you'll enjoy playing this game and will get most of the references and minute details engraved in everything from hogwarts up to the highlands.

Thanks to the Devs & Publisher for making this game possible and for putting in the time and effort for such a great title release. I know as of now they're not thinking of releasing DLC's for extra content but I really hope they would consider doing one in the future. 

*cough* Reinstating Quidditch Questline *cough*.

133631872.review:
Spoiler-free- 

I wasn't planning to buy this in the first week but Imma be real with yall, the outrage around this game made me do it. I had to play since the trans community from Twitter and Reddit were coping all over this. (Disclaimer: I don't have a problem with LGBT people. I don't dislike them. I only dislike narcissists and assholes. That simple.)  For context, I watched the movies and love the Harry Potter franchise so naturally, I would be drawn to this.

Now onto the review:

The graphics are good.

The story is kinda boring but it's not bad. Could honestly be done better. 

Yes, this place is like any RPG but that isn't bad. The RPG mechanics works really well. 

I like the combat, the powers, and all that. Especially in an open-world environment. The world itself is pretty and it reminds me of the Witcher world without the gory aspect.

I like the side quests. You can fly on a broom and compete against broom racers to upgrade it. Some of the collectibles are pretty tedious to collect. The Merlin trials aren't that challenging, collecting those moon owls was a pain because I needed to collect them to unlock a spell I needed to collect more cosmetics. 

 I love the customization of my characters, clothes, and wand. I especially like it when I can switch the look on a robe so I don't look like a clown.  

I love how through the main story and side quests I can choose what kind of wizard I want to be. Most of all, this game isnt riddled with micro transactions. 

Now the major problem I have is the rendering. When I exit Hogwarts the sun gets super bright like there's a damn light bulb in my eye. Then you can see there are some things that are still being rendered. Trees, walls, the floor, etc.
Overall it's a good game. A fun one in fact. I cant wait for a online feature so I can cast a unforgivable curse on my friends. 

Now I really like this game and I think everyone should try it despite the hot takes on it and the attempted boycott that failed. Please do not be intimidated by the mob. I just wanna congratulate Avalanche Software for making an amazing game. The Trans community of Reddit and Twitter and their "allies" who harass and doxes people who simply play a fucking game should be ashamed of themselves. The only people I feel bad for are the Trans-people (who arent assholes) who've been misrepresented by these self-righteous low-life vultures. Regardless of your opinion of JK Rowling, you are loved and accepted. Hope yall have amazing life :) Now Imma start a new character lmao XD

133631498.review:
Hogwarts Legacy is a Harry Potter fans dream come true, it's not perfect but it hits just about every single mark. A non-Harry Potter fan may not love this game as much as one who is, much of the draw, exploration and awe is connected to one's love for this universe, I was very excited to see things I was surprised they included and seeing the school is amazing (I won't spoil what is there but it's plenty). I could make a whole essay on the little and big incredible things this game does but here is my attempt to condense that.

PROS
The side quest and exploration is plentiful without being overwhelming (despite all the icons on the map, most of which is just a location marker), the story is fairly decent and the side characters (especially Sebastian and Poppy) really shine and Natsai if you're a lore nerd! The game does dish itself out rather slow in the beginning and it takes a while to unlock everything, which was a bit annoying at first but I ended up enjoying how some side content was short and not introduced and meant last the entire game.

Combat was very fun and varied and as the game went on, you get more and more tools. I played on hard and ever so often a Troll would feel like a sponge but for the most part, this was not an option and the game was fun but not difficult to frustration, playing on an easier difficulty for me personally likely would have mad it too easy. The Unforgivable Curses are very strong, but understandably so but this doesn't effect balance and they come pretty late into the game. All-in-all it was fun, flashy, didn't get stale, and you get to cast Bombarda, which is incredibly fun to say, 

The gear system works really well, the transmog being unlocked from the start and being able to customize my appearance/hair in-game was nice. Gear never felt super relevant, just throw on whatever is best and move on, which I actually liked not having to worry so much about the gear. The outfits also look incredible and is some of the best male clothing options I've seen in almost any game. The hair also looks like hair someone from this century would have and whoever made the hair deserves an award. 

The game also looks incredible and ran perfectly fine on my PC. I maybe had 2 or 3 bugs and one was a quest disappearing from the log despite me never finishing it (I didn't even notice until I went finish my collection and I needed one more side quest, I had to go find the NPC and talk to them but never had a quest or marker for it) but nothing major, which was really nice.

I was also really impressed with some small things, like if you tip the musician in Hogsmead and return he will have a new instrument and thank you for donating to get it, and it happens a few times! Students will get howlers from parents when you roam the hallways, which is fun and the paintings moving look incredible and add such life. The music is also incredible as well. 

CONS
The only cons were (and I did my best to not believe this) that the story options are mostly null and mean nothing, You can make some jerk choices and say some pretty messed up stuff but at the end of the day the story ends the same and you can't do anything unforgivable. There is no evil path. 

I think Sebastian's questline ended kind of unresolved fully, I don't know if they anticipated his popularity and have planned DLC for him but it felt weird. 

It doesn't seem like you can finish the collection without DLC, which is really sad for people who like to 100% games but you can finish the challenges 100% and I did but not being able to finish collectibles will be sad for some people. 


If you love Harry Potter, just buy the game, you will love it.

133630639.review:
This is a love hate relationship with this game. Let me start by saying I really enjoy the HP world and this game does a really good job at making you feel like you are in this world. I thoroughly enjoyed the game and the story line, but it's not without it's faults. This game is really banking off the fans of the series buying this game and ignoring some of the laziness of the development. A few examples of this is the fact that this is nothing more than a console port and it's so extremely aggravating how annoying that is. You unlock some 15ish spells but can only use a bank of 4.. yes, 4. You have to scroll or switch to the other banks to use those spells. When you have a mouse with 12 programmable and a keyboard with a few micro programmable keys, why must I cater to the $20 controller with only 4 buttons? I believe there are some modders that are working on that but it shouldn't be a mod. There are several "puzzles" that is really just a rotation of the same 4 or 5, so once you've done about 5 puzzles, you've done all of them.. luckily again, there's mods that help with that now. There's MMO style of color codding clothing but for no reason really? I also don't understand the reasoning to search each chest because 90% of the time all the gear is worse than what you already have after level 20. I never upgraded my gear to max, the most I had is one piece of gear upgraded to 2(out of 3) and even in the final boss fight the items found in the chest were worse off than the gear i found at level 20, I fought the final boss at level 30 but to each their own on that aspect. There's a lot of filler quest that feels like they put it in there just to give you stuff to do to make their game last longer. This really had the potential to be one of the most amazing games, especially for the fans, but it just falls short. 

It ran fine for me, but I ran it on Medium settings. 60 Fps with a 3060 and R5 3400 with 32g of ram . 

Even with all the frustrating flaws with the game I still enjoyed it and loved the main story line and wish they would make it a movie one day. I do recommend it, especially if you are a fan of the HP world, but I say wait for a sale.

133627653.review:
Hogwarts Legacy is an extremely controversial game. 

While obviously being a perfect gift for Harry Potter fans, from the gameplay point of view it's a fairly generic open world action/adventure with role-play elements, pretty much inspired by the similar projects, such as Ubisoft games. 

Overall, Hogwarts Legacy is an extremely well-crafted product. Its large budget has been applied competently. Special awards go to the atmosphere and fanservice. It feels that developers are well-familiar with the Wizarding World and love it. This dive into the favorite universe initially enraptured me so much, that I was not able to see the actual problems this game has. 

But if we slice the aspects of the game into pieces, most of them are relatively primitive or even poorly designed. The plot and the characters are unamusing, open world activities are repetitive and with dubious awards, as game, for some reason, adopted the Diablo-like randomly dropping loot system. Tiny inventory and inconvenient menus together with the above-mention loot system slow down the tempo of the game a lot. 

There are 2 aspects that actually made me leave a positive review: 
1. Combat and puzzle solving based on spell combinations. While combat is designed better, there are some puzzles in the game, which actually require some brain activity. But battles are extremely pleasant and entertaining. I haven't got tired of it. 
2. Exploring. Hogwarts and the surroundings are full of secrets and one needs to spend quite a while to reveal them all. If you enjoy exploration and Metroidvania elements, you would definitely like this game.  

Overall, I had a lot of fun. But I am a fan of Harry Potter since childhood. And if we take away the setting, it's a pretty average game with a lot of aspect to improve.

133624261.review:
[h1]Everything's Magic[/h1]

[b]Hogwarts Legacy is an above-average open-world action-adventure and a unique opportunity to taste the beloved magic universe from Harry Potter books and movies in a video-game format. However, it does come with certain downsides and questionable moments, which doesn't spoil an overall experience.[/b]

First and foremost, the RPG tag is misleading. [b]Hogwarts Legacy[/b] is not an RPG game in any capacity. It has some features characteristic of RPG games, such as leveling up, talents, gear, and dialogues, but it doesn't make it a role-playing game. Name an AAA title that doesn't have at least some of these nowadays. [b]Hogwarts Legacy[/b] does not feature the defining thing which makes a game [i]role-playing[/i] - choices and consequences. You can run around breaking into restricted places and casting forbidden spells, and no one will raise an eyebrow. Sure, you will make choices in dialogues, but your decisions don't matter. The main story will keep you strictly on the rails, and most of the side quests are just about going somewhere, doing something, and coming back. Dialogues here are for pure immersion, which is lovely, but don't expect anything beyond that. There definitely was a potential for role play, given the nature of the story and the setting itself, but it was never realized for some reason.

As for the story itself, it's... okay. It's undoubtedly epic and exciting to follow most of the time. However, there're specific segments when it feels frankly dragged for the sake of dragging. I mean, a dozen of main story quests could've easily been optional. Characters are primarily one-dimensional but still well-written and voiced. If you have a kink for accents as I do, then you would probably find satisfying how diverse the voiceover cast is, which makes every character, even barely presented ones, feel unique. 

In terms of progression, [b]Hogwarts Legacy[/b] is an example for many open-world games out there. Unlocking various side activities, additional spells, and locations is tied to your story and side quest progression, which I found very convenient since the game doesn't overwhelm you with everything it has to offer at once but instead unlocks it step by step. It makes the game more balanced in terms of pace. However, there's one questionable decision, which made my first dozen hours in the game a bit frustrating. You must reach a certain point in the story to unlock talents required to customize your build and grant additional effects to your spells, potions, etc. This mechanic is fundamental for a game like this. However, it's, for some reason, locked behind 5-10 hours of gameplay, depending on difficulty and how distracted you will be by some side activities. Of course, you can speedrun the story until a particular moment to gain access to your talents and then play and explore comfortably. Still, if you're playing for the first time, you're most likely unaware of how long it will take you to unlock the actual leveling up, and without talents, your combat and exploration options are pretty limited. Craft, another crucial gameplay element, is hidden even further behind multiple side quests. This decision is justified from the story perspective but still seems questionable gameplaywise. 

Speaking of combat. Overall I found it fun and engaging, not to mention each encounter looks spectacular due to the variety of spells and other ways to fight your enemies. The game allows you to wield all the most well-known conjures from books and movies, even unforgivable ones, which you can use in combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving. However, I found battles rather exhausting than fun until halfway through the main story due to a limited arsenal. Only after I unlocked most of the spells and upgraded them did the combat finally shine. 

Regarding exploration and the open world, [b]Hogwarts Legacy[/b] is fantastic, especially if you're a Harry Potter fan like I used to be years ago. The devs nailed it with good attention to the details while recreating the magical world we used to know only through books and movies, especially in Hogwarts castle. I guarantee you will spend hours exploring only the school itself, not to mention Hogsmead and dozens of small hamlets, caves, and tombs. Some locations are breathtaking, which makes the lack of photo mode a considerable downside. However, after a certain point, when you'll explore enough and the sense of discovery becomes dull, you will most likely see that it's nothing more than an average AAA open world with question marks and bandit camps, with challenges and puzzles more suitable for an MMO rather than a single-player game. Still, there were enough moments throughout the game, no spoilers, which were done so well in terms of atmosphere and immersion that it ultimately outweighed all the secondariness of the surrounding activities. 

From the technical side, [b]Hogwarts Legacy[/b] is far from perfect. I experienced constant fps drops and stuttering here and there while my rig was more than decent to run the game with the settings I used. Facial animations are weird outside of pre-rendered cutscenes, and most of the dialogues are just talking heads with occasional gesticulation. However, overall, [b]Hogwarts Legacy[/b] looks beautiful, primarily because of design, attention to detail, and visual style rather than graphics quality.

In my book, [b]Hogwarts Legacy[/b] is a great game. I admire how devs recreated the wizarding world and used every advantage of the setting beloved by millions to create a massive interactive experience, which, despite being rough around the edges, is good enough to stand in line with the genre's best.

133621587.review:
A pleasant surprise!

I didn't think wand combat with parry and dodge rolls would work, but it does! It works very well and the effects and combos are efficient and beautiful.

This game really feels like a movie, you go to class, learn spells, make friends and uncover whats going on with the main plot. Its the same pacing as the Harry Potter movies and really adds to the nostalgia. 

The main plot starts slow but really picks up in the back half once you learned all the spells and the pay off was amazing. However, the main plot fails in comparison to the side stories for your friends. Namely Sebastian's quests......Holy, that was epic, frightful and amazing. I felt way more engaged in my friends quests, than I did with the main plot, but overall, I liked both. I would 1000% recommend doing the friend quests prior to completing the main campaign. The writing for them is exceptionally good and fits perfectly with the narrative.

My only negative was that there is no REAL choice in this game. I learned all 3 unforgivable curses, and used them in combat and no one really cared and it also did not factor into the ending at all. There is also no choice in siding with the goblins or not. Its just, you seal up the power or take it for yourself and that's it, that's what defines good vs bad; but the cutscenes for both is barely any different. And if you are at least level 34 when completing the game, then you can get the true ending by talking to Weasley and then attending the grand hall to see a nice wholesome wrap-up to the story - even if you picked to take the power and be evil.....NO ONE CARES! I would have liked to see more world changing for being evil and definitely some reaction from the teachers or something; but other than that, this game was super fun and felt wonderful.

8/10 Story
- Very cool, slow build, no real variance in ending choices or impact.

20/10 Side stories
-Excellent character writing and progression, big impact (Sebastian's choices), you have some choice in what happens for 1 of them.

10/10 Combat
-Fluid, great combo system, amazing visuals, user friendly, FUN, and Avada Kadabra ACTUALLY 1 shots EVERYTHING. Its not an end game, unforgivable OP curse for nothing. If you face a boss enemy, it will 1 shot it, true to its name/lore and reputation. Some people may not like that, but I think its quite fitting. If you don't like it, don't use that spell. However if you feel like playing God, curse every enemy on the field, then use AK on them and (if you upgraded the spell) watch every single enemy disintegrate into oblivion and then revel in your unlimited power.
- You get combat PLANTS! Which sounds ridiculous, but holy hell they are GOOD! Don't sleep on them. Even without learning the spells, if you uses potion buffs and combat plants, you are easily OP within seconds.
- There are many ways to play and anyone can mix and match and have a great time.
-You can stealth too if you wish.

10000000/10 Beast Vivariums
- You can rescue and breed beasts and groom and/or play with them. I didn't think I would care about this but when i saw the baby Fwooper waddle running around, I melted. Absolutely melted. That is the cutest thing I have ever seen. Its also nice that the animals give you feathers/hair to be used to upgrade your gear, so its worth seeing and spending time with them.

10/10 Room customization
- I thoroughly enjoyed changing every single aspect of my Room of Requirement to be exactly what i wanted it to be. You can customize everything! The walls, floors, ceiling, windows, and every single item in that room. Different styles and colours and many many many unlockable options to make that space your own. You can even change the lighting and ambience. I had a gothic mixed with greek architecture, all black, but with moonlight ambience and lighting to make my room have a blue reflection to it - it really suited my dark lord ravenclaw theme.

7/10 World building/Impact from choices
- Its a nice and beautiful environment, but does not change from your play style at all.

8/10 Mount options
- Broom flight actually feels realistic and janky and it doesn't feel bad at all. You need to master the controls to be pro at it, which is a nice touch of realism for me. Beast mounts are okay but broom is definitely the better way to go for efficiency. 

10/10 Character customization is very diverse
- Despite the backlash, you can absolutely look and sound like anything you want. If you want to appear straight, gay, bi, or trans, you absolutely can do that. It might not be perfect, but its close enough to make most people feel like they can personalize their character to match what they want. NOTE: There is a very obvious and clearly trans side character and when doing their quests; you will discover that 1 of the teachers is lesbian and that this character helped them accept themselves and embrace who they are. No matter how you feel about JK Rowling, this game studio did their own thing and made sure every player can relate and feel represented within this game. When you talk to some merchants, you can also see and hear this as well. Its a diverse and beautiful world that we live in and this game tries to match that as well.

10/10 Level progression.
- You only level up by LEARNING, which I thought I was going to hate, but i didn't. Just cast Revelio every 5 seconds and collect all the field guide pages that you can and you will level up super fast. Its not about grinding enemies, its about exploration. There are combat challenges, but that's more for unlocking cosmetics than leveling up. To increase your character level, you fill up your field guide and do quests - which in my opinion, feels logical for this type of setting. You're a student Harry, go to class and do your homework!

Overall i had a wonderful time. I farmed plants, made potions in bulk, raised animals and discovered all sorts of wonders during my time at Hogwarts. This is a new age of magic and sorcery and I hope there are more games to come!

133616516.review:
Hogwarts Legacy is a good game, although it may not be considered exceptional or groundbreaking. However, it delivers an intense beginning to the story, with enjoyable levels of fan-service that reference the Harry Potter and Fantastic Beasts movies. The game's overall atmosphere is positive, and it benefits from almost flawless technical implementation, a rare feat in today's gaming industry.

One of the game's strengths is its strong combat mechanics, which start simple but become more complex and engaging as the game progresses. The graphical design and art style are also impressive, especially at extreme settings at 4K, although a decent PC is required to run the game this way.

On the downside, the game suffers from repetitiveness and an overabundance of points of interest on the map, which can feel like mere placeholders after a while. The Merlin trials also feel lackluster, and the caves and camps become monotonous after the middle game. These factors contribute to the game feeling like a grind, which may not be appealing to non-diehard fans of the series. The sound and music also become repetitive, which can be a turn-off.

The most significant technical problem is the difficulty in focusing on enemies or objects when there are many on the screen. The user interface could also be more user-friendly, with features like a "Sell All" button or the ability to buy multiple potions at once.

Despite these flaws, there is potential for interesting story-based DLCs in other locations, which could make for an enjoyable gaming experience.

133614862.review:
I would say this is a really solid game, however, there could have been maybe some deeper mechanics and story-driven material that would have made this an absolutely fantastic game. After awhile the combat is really repetitive and the fact that you can't get all the talents unlocked is somewhat frustrating by the end. I felt that, though the potions and plants were a great addition, they were not even thought of most of the time when I was fighting (unless I needed to complete a duel feat). I'd say that maybe slowing down the fighting and making it a little more challenging and or rewarding to use the plants and potions would have made the combat feel more satisfying. 

My main complaint with this game is the time-gated collectibles. Man, this is very frustrating to have in this type of game. Sure, the revelio pages and the additional information throughout the castle is welcomed and I think adds to the atmosphere of Hogwarts and the surrounding area. However, this game is constantly like, "oh yeah, collect this now" and after awhile you're sitting there way too overwhelmed and begin to become apathetic to collecting the useless objects. Landing pads, balloons, Merlin trials (oh boy those are very redundant), and my least favorite, the Demiguise statues, are all way too obnoxious and most of these get unlocked later when you've already been through some areas. My biggest complaint of these is the Demiguise statues, not as it pertains to collecting, but the Alohamora spell. I have no real reason as to why they decided to add a utterly soul-sucking and useless minigame to unlocking locks with a magic spell that unlocks locks automatically OR giving the spell "levels." It was bad enough that I had to go through Hogsmeade and surrounding caves and see locks that I could not unlock, but to then be like "oh yeah hehe this is Level 2 and 3 you can't do those yet until you collect more statues" was utterly obnoxious and made me feel like giving up on completing this game 100%. I'm someone who does love collect-em-all games, but the way in which they decided to do it irked me. 

My last complaint is that I wish I would have gotten more character development from the teachers, close students (my friends??? far stretch), and even the main baddie. The end was pretty pathetic and the story was a little underwhelming since it was rushed at the end, even though I thought it started off masterfully. 

Don't get me wrong, at the end of the day this is a solid game. You really do get a feeling that you're at Hogwarts and the spell casting is sleek and well done (even though it could have been harder). I would say anyone on the fence about buying it, wait till it goes on sale and give it a shot.

133614288.review:
Here's my final take on Hogwarts: Legacy after finally hitting ~40+ hours (still haven't finished the game).
A few items to note:

I played on the hardest difficulty
I disabled the minimap function
I'm R/G colorblind, so take any reference to color with a heaping spoonful of umami.

In a triumphant return to the World of Wizardry, Hogwarts Legacy does it's level best to make you feel like you're a student in the titular school. It does this by incorporating a need for education, by serving the purpose of training you in the over two dozen spells in the game. That is to say, that the education system stops there. Any who come to Hogwarts: Legacy expecting a simulation of classroom life will be soured by the experience. Your chosen house makes very little difference in the gameplay experience, in truth, your house really has no value at all in the overall scheme of the game, since most of your time will be spent outside the school performing tasks that are unrelated to education.

However, Hogwarts Legacy does manage to capture what it's like to be a Special Child like 'ol lighning scar himself. You are set against the backdrop of the school, and given the barest amount of instruction in how to handle the myriad of messes you'll find yourself in. I oftentimes found myself stumped or confused as to how to solve a puzzle because I hadn't completed the requisite course to acquire the spell needed to solve it. You'll also be getting attacked by basically everything that exists outside of the many spotted hamlets and towns in the Scottish Highlands; be they brigands or bandits, poachers or dark wizards, spiders or trolls. The fun within this game lies in the combat. Don't get me wrong, the dialogue is great, and the story is damn good. But the combat here is unlike anything I've played in my storied history of playing video games. You'll find yourself frequently rushing to pick the correct spell, or quickly aborting an expelliarmus in order to cast a protego, to avoid being disarmed yourself.

The game does an amazing job of making the combat feel like real wizarding combat, sure. You can possibly survive in a fight against a dozen dark wizards, but you're going to have a difficult time, as every diffindo or crucio cast your way will create a hazard requiring a dodge, and all other spells will need to be blocked with protego. Now, it sounds on the face to be a straightforward think, this combat. The change comes, however, in the form of spell interactions. You see, a hastily cast glacius could lead into any number of others, such as a simple basic cast, or maybe an incendio. However, if you instead opt for a diffindo, descendo, or depulso, you'll be pleasantly rewarded with bonus damage due to the interaction of slamming or slashing the ice, causing it to shatter. These interactions are many and virtually none are explained by the courses, these are the things you must teach yourself. And all this is without getting into the fact that spells can be uniquely effective on certain creatures in certain cirucmstances. For example, cast a flippendo right after blocking a troll's club with a perfectly timed protego? Great, you just flipped that troll's club right up into his smug face. Cast a descendo while a spider is preparing a strike, bam - you've just buried that spiders fangs into the ground. This goes a long way toward making the combat feel real. 

That being said. The game does have some pretty glaring gaps that prevent it from being a complete experience. The lack of depth in the gear system is my biggest gripe, with the lack of quidditch being a close second. But there is one area that the game succeeds entirely, and that is being good. It's hard to remember the last time we had a really good magic-based RPG experience. So Hogwarts Legacy manages to squeeze itself in at the exact perfect time to be appreciated for what it does well.

9/10

Every Potterhead's dream is to explore the castles of Hogwarts and the lands beyond it, and the DEVs delivered. They made sure to have every detail spot on from the books when making this masterpiece. I highly enjoyed taking my time playing this. Word of advice: is DO NOT rush the main quest! Explore. Collect. Side Quests. Then when there nothing left progress with the Main Quest to unlock more side quests and collectibles.

Props to the DEVs for making sure that players can set clothing cosmetics to their liking without having to compromise stats, (I think other game developers could learn from this).

The main story line is well thought out and executed wonderful. Each side-character's development is not only eventful, but also moving as the story progress. (I personally tear'd up at the end of Natty's Quest Lines)

The cherry on top is for sure having your own room to customize with magical beasts to care for. **Gotta Catch Them All** However, I do wish there was more you could do with the beasts you capture. Also having your own cat/owl/frog in your room would be nice as well.

Can't wait to see what other DLC they'll add in the future..

133611520.review:
[h1]Sum-Up[/h1]
[h3]In-depth analysis further down.[/h3]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟩 [b]Pros[/b][/th]
[th]🟥 [b]Cons[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
- A vast, detailed and impressive recreation of Hogwarts and its neighboring regions, packed to the brim with locations to discover, collectibles and activities to clear. A Potterhead’s wet dream made manifest.

- Varied and satisfying combat system that constantly opens up new opportunities as you learn more spells, and stays fresh, engaging in the long run.

- Excellent customization possibilities, featuring a myriad of cosmetics and skins, other than your very own customizable ‘base’ to furnish by hand at leisure.

- Exciting progression that portrays your growth as a wizard (or witch) rather well, giving you new tools and utilities to access previously-locked content and areas.

- Solid roster of side characters; most of them are likable / unique enough, and incredibly, their writing isn’t complete garbage - kudos to that.
[/td]
[td]
- Excessively repetitive open-world activities in the long run, that create bloat and annoyance for those who want to complete all side activities.

- Combat balance issues with potions, ‘healing spam’ and unforgivable curses: especially when upgraded they prove overpowered and make most fights quite too easy.

- Most named foes and quest bosses (but not all) are just normal enemies on steroids, that don’t vary in mechanics and don’t have unique behaviors.

- Some inconsistencies with lore and character behavior. Example: if you use unforgivable curses in public or during quests (with witnesses), nobody will give a damn.

- Underwhelming finale that doesn’t really reflect the importance of what you accomplished, and doesn’t give any detail about how your actions influenced other characters afterwards.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]🟨 [b]Bugs & Issues[/b][/th]
[th]🔧 [b]Specs[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
- Significant frame-drops inside Hogwarts when transitioning between different sections, and also in specific places throughout the castle, regardless of settings.

- In some cases, fall damage doesn’t register on enemies.
[/td]
[td]
- 3900X
- 2080Ti
- 32GB RAM
- SSD
- 1440p
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Content & Replay Value:[/b][/td]
[td]It took me 82 hours to complete Hogwarts Legacy, taking considerable extra time to clear all optional content and find around 90% of collectibles / secrets on Hard difficulty. I don’t see a reason to replay the game once finished, except achievement hunting, as the content is linear.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][b]Is it worth buying?[/b][/td]
[td]Yes, especially if you’re a fan of the saga. This amount of content and quality are more than fair for the proposed 60€ price, expected from an AAA release.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td][h3]Verdict: Good[/h3]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2548409603]Rating Chart Here[/url][/td]
[td]By far the best game ever made based on this franchise, but not a masterpiece by any means. Fans of the series will almost certainly like it, but it’s still drawn back by its issues.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[quote]Follow our Curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41449676/]Summit Reviews[/url], to see more high-quality reviews regularly.[/quote]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2936728702

[h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Setting & Writing[/h3]
Hogwarts Legacy takes place in the iconic Wizarding World setting created by J.K. Rowling, at a time far before Harry & friends were even born. You’ll play as a fifth year student in the titular magics academy, admitted this late because of unspecified ‘special circumstances’. The virtual rendition of Rowling’s works is nothing short of exceptional, with not only Hogwarts itself, but also its environs (like the town of Hogsmeade or the dangerous Forbidden Forest), all recreated faithfully and down to the most minute details. Of course, some things will differ from movies and books, with the game being set in the 1800s. 

The main story follows the classic ‘manifest destiny’ archetype, where your custom-made character will discover hidden potential that ties them to a greater purpose. Despite some genuinely memorable characters and some interesting side- and main-quests, the overall narrative can’t help but fall a little flat and stale, especially towards the ending phases. Nonetheless, many enjoyable adventures await you. Notably, there are no romance or love/hate dichotomies in the relationships you have with side-characters, as your choices will always end up in pretty much the same results during questlines.

[h3]Exploration, Collectibles & Secrets[/h3]
The world is vast and visually magnificent, peppered to no-end with points of interest that often hold collectibles, currency or other utilities. Initially on foot, and later on with the iconic enchanted brooms and even flying magical creatures, you’ll be able to explore at leisure and clear the enormous amount of side-activities. A good portion of these, however, will prove inaccessible until you gain the right spells or abilities, in a sort-of ‘metroidvania’ fashion that promotes meaningful backtracking. Fast travel and an item-highlighting spell prove invaluable in saving time while exploring. Collectibles are mostly cosmetic, enabling the customization of both your wizard and your own private room once you unlock it, to suit various styles. 

Most dungeons and locations have additional puzzles or hidden paths that often lead to collectibles or extra resources; exploration feels rewarding, with a genuine sense of mystery surrounding each new point of interest you’ll find. Despite that, most dungeons and locations play out in the same way, and become repetitive in the long haul.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2933385898

[h3]Combat System & Bosses[/h3]
Magical battles use spells as sole means of offense and defense. Usually against multiple enemies at once, sometimes supported by allied NPCs, you’ll have to time your protection spell right in order to deflect incoming attacks, or dodge-roll away in case of unblockable ones. Enemies are varied and range from magical creatures to dark wizards and goblin soldiers, to name a few. Some of them may be weak to specific charms, others have shields you can break by using specific spell categories (damage, utility, movement) or other special abilities, like immunity to certain effects. 

Combat feels engaging, well-paced and is more than a little gory for this universe’s standards, death will be far more common than in the movies or books. The way you can combine spell effects to your advantage and use the environment further adds to the base system, while the amount of passive upgrades with item traits and spell-related talents you can gain progressively add another layer of depth. In late-game however you’ll become overpowered between potions, passive traits, talents and endgame spells - so much that supposedly fearsome dark wizards will prove little more than a nuisance due to power creep.

[h3]Quests, Minigames & Challenges[/h3]
Quests usually involve retrieving something, talking to a specific NPC, solving a treasure hunt based on visual clues, getting the solution to logic-based puzzles and more, depending on the case. While some side-quests are unique and memorable, most will be fetch chores or dry open-world shenanigans that you’ll have to repeat over and over in the same fashion. Less, but more meaningful and unique quests would have been better than this bloat, for sure. 

Challenges are paramount in unlocking unique bonuses like increased inventory capacity, many cosmetics, and even unique passive upgrades to equip in gear pieces. They often require you to slay X of a specific enemy, finish X of the same activity, and such “long-term” goals. Some of them are a massive grind and will only give you the 25th pair of gloves you don’t need, or other cosmetics that aren’t worth the effort.

133611180.review: For fans of the Harry Potter series, this game is a must play. Seeing Hogwarts and the surrounding areas brought to life so wonderfully is a treat, and the game oozes the charm of the films. The soundtrack has moments of sheer brilliance, feeling like something John Williams himself could have composed. While the combat loop is a bit repetitive, and the game falls into some of the trappings of modern AAA open world titles, the atmosphere, story, and wonder of the game is more than enough to delight new and old fans of the series alike.

133610932.review:
I bought the game on launch and was thoroughly surprised at how well it looked and felt. The excitement was palpable for me once the story started. I'm approximately 2/3rds the way through the game and it's been a blast to play. There's a ton of exploration and customization in-game with how you want to be dressed and look. The combat is enjoyable aside from some rubber-banding from certain enemies. You will spend more time outside of the school than you will inside it since the outside world is so much larger than that of the castle. So if you're looking for a game that you spend most of the time inside Hogwarts then you might be disappointed by how little time you end up spending it there. Graphically speaking the game is gorgeous and they fully fleshed out the school. They have puzzles around the entirety of it and the outside world even if some of them are kinda simple others not so much. The main story is also from what I can see pretty short so that could also be a point of contention for some as well. If you don't mind this then all the power to you, you'll enjoy the game.

My main gripe with the game is the framerate dropping. I've got a decent rig with a 3070ti and 32 GBs of RAM and I'll have framerate drops going from 70-80 fps to 8-9 fps. This is with ray-tracing turned off and most of the settings on either High or Medium. Like any game that has combat in it if your frames drop during it then you start to make mistakes and you get screwed and that can be frustrating so make sure it's turned off and it should be smoother and you shouldn't deal with the drops as much. The other issue I had was after a while some of the exploration feels repetitive but that may also be because I'm dumb and started exploring as soon as I could and am behind in the main story compared to where I am exploration wise. The faces in game show expressions only when the person is talking to you and then as soon as they finish it's back to what looks like an expressionless mannequin. I know in the HP universe there's a thing called occlumency and it keeps your face from showing emotion but it seems like everyone is an expert at it once they stop talking to your character so take that into account. The broom riding is fun and personally my preferred method of travel if not using the fast travel method but the turning is pretty slow but once again that could be chalked up to me constantly being at full speed on the thing as well so it just doesn't handle like I would think it should. There are also ALOT of cut scenes granted you can skip them but take note of it. Also you're choices don't really make much  of a difference in what happens to your character. If you use the Dark Arts nothing bad happens to your character, there are no consequences so that's also a downside in my opinion.

Look, I get it. 
You guys have been starved for a new open world to explore for a good hot minute but this is nowhere near GOTY. Great game in its own right sure but just wait until Starfield. 

If you're a big fan of Harry Potter or magic for its own sake then yes, this is a game you want. Nice, pretty open world to explore but limited in its features and secrets. 

If you want to explore Hogwarts then DEFINITELY get this. Truly a love letter to the fans of the Potterverse. The devs did an incredible job of bringing Hogwarts to life. 

While most of the rewards are either cash or cosmetics, exploring is alright. Flying is ridiculously good.

Devs and warner bros reckon this entry won't be the first Potterverse game so while there is absolutely room for improvement, it's a nice game to screw around in for a bit and have a great deal of fun. Much to look forward to in the future.

DON'T UNLOCK CAGES THAT ARE EMPTY!!

It can mess up a certain side quest and make the quest uncompleted. It doesn't mess up the main story, but as a completionist it was upsetting for me. It will be fixed in the next patch, but since we don't know when that will be, I thought I would throw in a warning about that :)


If you choose to play the game, have fun!! 
If you choose not to play it, have fun playing whatever other games you like!! 

Lets all be respectful of others opinions and preferences! It's ok to disagree with people who dislike or like the game, just do it in a respectful way :D

133605061.review:
Hogwarts Legacy falls short in a number of ways and outright fails in others. It gets compared to Witcher3, Skyrim, Elden Ring and so on. In no way can it rival the writing and scope of Witcher3, the open world and character customization of Skyrim or the combat and sense of accomplishment of Elden Ring. 

To me it has a flair like Fable did and also borrows a page from Dragon Age Inqiusition.
Hogwarts Legacy is fun to play while it lasts, but has an utterly forgettable story and cast. For the life of me I can not remember what Fable was about, only that it was a fun game. I think the same will be true for HL in a couple of years. HL also has the pointless puzzles, collections and side quests that DA:I has. The world in HL is filled with 10 minute endorphin boosts, does not evolve or change and is fairly empty otherwise.

The same is true for many of its systems. All items have 1 of two stats, which are offense or defense. On level up you gain health, which is the only other character stat in the game. Upgrading items adds the missing stat, so upgrading a defense item adds offense. Items can also hold one trait, of which there are many, but only a handful are actually worthwhile. Items come in several rarities, ranging up to legendary. Though legendary items simply provide more of their one respective stat.

In HL everything is present from crafting, critter catching and breeding, talents, mini-games, puzzles, dungeons, mounts, whatever. But nothing has any depth. You get spammed with everything, and barely need anything. The puzzles are simplistic (except maybe the depulso training rooms). The pacing of the talents is way off. Once I had built a character that offered some unique gameplay the game was over and HL does not have a late game. 

So, why is this game still good?
The combat is very fluid and fun, while not being a button masher. Flinging spells feels very rewarding. I played on hard and some of the wavelike encounters and bosses were quite challenging. YMMV of course but I consider it one of the games strong points. 
The world is very, very beautiful. There is a level of detail that is just amazing. Potted plants will periodically transform to another cut. There are flying watering cans or tiny stormclouds that water a field. Magic instruments will play music with students watching, the pictures/portraits all move. Basically much of the charm from the source material is present.  

Take HL for what it is. A fun experience with nostalgia factor that will keep you entertained for about 40-60 hours and then move on. If you go in expecting it as rivaling the top dogs in the genre you will be disappointed. However HL comes almost free of bugs, crashed twice in my 60 hours (windows update forced it to minimize and one random crash) and performed okay (some frame drops in heavy duty areas after fast traveling there) on my 4 year old PC (mostly high settings @1080p).  

If you are not familiar with the movies or books you might want to wait for a sale.

133659721.review:
No Spoilers

So, the graphics are amazing, and it was very nostalgic to be able to play through the game.  And it's an enjoyable game, but as an open world game it falls short.

If you haven't played an open world game it's a good opener into it.  But as someone who has played several open world games, it really falls short.  The only karmic repercussions in the whole game is your own guilt.  Your decisions mean literally nothing with the exception of the final quest with Sebastion.  A lot of the stuff people were looking forward to are practically non-existent, (quidditch, azkaban for literally one cut scene, etc.)  NPCs are completely useless except as background noise until they're needed for a quest.  And frankly the game needs more content.  

The NPCs don't even acknowledge what house you're in.  All you need is 20 extra minutes in a sound room and a basic line of program to pull the appropriate one for the house.  They don't even acknowledge your house when announcing that you won the house cup.  They just say "your house."  There's no way to loose house points like in previous games and risk not winning house cup.  The fact that 30 seconds into a puzzle the NPC and even my own character starts telling me how to solve it (let me at least try and if i'm stuck give me the option to talk to the npc for hints).  Zero repercussions for your character.  Ever.  I used the killing curse? The only thing that happens is NPCs mention it in that battle.  That's it. Nothing else.  No friendship meter that you need to balance out, no morality meter.  The world outside of Hogwarts is nothing but filler material being mostly empty land.  The MMO style looting system is annoying at best and painful at worst.  The only actual decision that matters in the entire game is where to spend your talent points.  And even then, this isn't even multiplayer let alone an MMO, why are we putting arbitrary limits on skills?

Avalanche studios has worked with Bethesda in the past.  They know what to do and what not to do.  And this isn't it.

And that's before I get into the technical with the very frequent crashing, bugs, and weird ass pathmaking for the NPCs.

The combat is the only real entertaining part and even that gets overly repetitive when I'm fighting the same group of ashwinders for the 3rd time with the duelist off in the corner screaming petrificus totalis every 3 seconds.

If you never played open world and want a game to get you into them, this game is passable.  If you want a game to play for the nostalgic factor, go right ahead.  However, it doesn't have much else going for it and if you simply want the game for it's open world don't buy it.

If you really want to buy this game, wait till it's discounted.  If you're on the fence, wait till their sales drop off in another 2 weeks or so and they're forced to include more content to bring sales back.

133652965.review:
NOT AN RPG
This game is a movie that is coplaying as an RPG.  None of the decisions you make really matter past the next line of dialogue.  Witcher and Cyberpunk had better, more involved quests.  It just wasn't enough, even the spell casting is kind of shallow.  XP doesn't really do anything and once you learn a spell, you apparently have mastered it.   You can't refine your skills of being a wizard in any way other than learning new spells- which is a one-and-done sort of thing.  

Also it runs like garbage, crashes on boot, complies shaders over and over (because, go figure, they don't bother testing anything these days).   Also I'm trying to boot it in the background and I've had to kill the process 2x while typing this review because it keeps getting hung up.  Apparently upon release it really sucks for Nvidia cards.  

I really wanted to like this game but it has too much of a "movie turned into a game" feeling - like the lord of the rings games - where you are doing what the designers wanted you to do, instead of doing what you want to do.  So I'm not sure it can be considered an "open world RPG".  The interactions with NPCs is pretty shallow aside from the more important ones who give you sidequest missions (there are like 3 of them).  Plenty of NPCs give you missions but most of them are not really more than "hey go find/kill/discover this thing and come back".  The main quest is good but not anything spectacular, the boss fights are a little repetitive or they're just so weak I instakill them.  I really wanted to have a be your own wizard adventure at Hogwarts but this really isn't it.   

Not horrible, Not great

133652546.review:
Really wanted to love this game. Hogwarts environment is really well done, but I don't want to play a game just for its eye candy. Other than the way Hogwarts looks the game is thoroughly non-engaging. The story is bland and not immersive, the side quests are as well. Too many repeating side activities. Like the Merlin puzzles, which become more of a chore than a challenge. There are no consequences to anything you do as a player, which kills all replay-ability. The "choices" are not true choices as they change nothing. The gear system is abysmal and pointless.

Some final words on the main story: 
Honestly, if the focus of the game was attending classes (where my performance in that class actually mattered) and exploring/doing quests in my spare time this game would be 10x more interesting. Especially because the combat system is quite good. But as it is, once you reach mid-game you are basically a teenage wizard demi-god dispatching whole groups of dark wizards and goblins like its nothing (played on hard btw). And then the story just peters out. My character trained less than Rey and somehow feels stronger than she was....

Environment and aesthetic: 10/10
Actual gameplay: 4/10

133637694.review:
If I were 10 years younger, and grew up on Harry Potter, I think this game would be a dream come true.  For those of us who know the franchise, but didn't grow up living and breathing the franchise, Hogwarts Legacy makes a good first impression before devolving into a very rote and relatively uninteresting slog.  Which is a shame, because most of the parts of a good game are in there somewhere.

Hogwart's is gorgeous, there is no doubt.  Hogwarts itself is a complex maze filled with secrets and little incidental details and flair that make the school feel alive.  Exploring Hogwarts can be a lot of fun... at first.  By the end of the game, you will have roamed back and forth through the same halls a couple of dozen times, and as you do, the cookie-cutter approach to filling this game with content becomes all the more evident.

Hogwarts gets off to a VERY SLOOOOW start, doling out your skill progression slowly over the first 12-15 hours of play.  Early on, you are severely limited to the point that most side quests remain out of reach.  After about 15 hours, the game opens up a bit more, giving you a full arsenal to deal with.  After that, though, it continues to add more and more gameplay mechanics, like room-design, crafting, and animal husbandry, all of which can provide some perks in-game, but few of which have any meaningful use during the game.  All of those dangerous flowers you can grow and use in battle?  Yeah, forgot you even had items you could use in battle, didn't you?

And that's the problem.  This game tries to do so much that it doesn't do much of anything well besides the combat, which itself is degraded by the fact that there are basically only 6 enemy types on repeat.  This isn't helped by the fact that XP and expanded inventory is only earned through completing side quests, which end up being rote fetch quests, or one of 4 simple puzzles on repeat.  

The game forces you to grind, which just feels lazy and designed to distract you from the fact that the story is fairly thin and uninspired.  

The game even blows a major opportunity when it comes to unlocking the broom.  Imagine my disappointment to find that the initial broom is so slow that it's literally faster to walk, and again, the broom upgrades are locked behind a side quest chain that is prone to glitching out and becoming unavailable.

Yes, open worlds can be buggy, but this one just feels beautiful yet uninspired.  The combat deserves a better game surrounding it.

I would wait for sale unless you are a massive Potter fan.

133626111.review:
If you have a deep-seated desire to pretend to be a child wizard / student at Hogwarts, then this will probably blow your socks off.  The game is super immersive and the developers did a great job of making every aspect of the world fit with the theme and vibe of a Harry Potter novel; everything feels right and true to the genre.  

That said, the way that you level up is by pinging the map for hidden book pages and by advancing through run-and-go-fetch type quests; fighting doesn't really net you too much XP unless you are satisfying dueling goals or "murder your 90th goblin" type achievements.  This is neither challenging nor fun.  Also, the game throws locks all over the place in order to keep you from clearing out areas of the map too quickly.  I get why a developer would want to do that (the locks serve to wall off parts of the sandbox), but this approach takes a lot of the thrill out of exploration, as you need to re-explore, and then re-re-explore the same areas rather than advancing into somewhere new.  Finally, the combat is laughably easy; I don't even have all the spells yet, much less the "unforgivable" spells (which, evidently, let you one-shot entire groups of enemies) and I'm already death incarnate, even for mobs that the game warns me are "too dangerous" for my level.  Decisions have no consequences that I can see and the "puzzles" are designed for 5-6 year olds.  

In short, this is not a game for anyone who has blown the dust out of a NES cartridge.  If you've ever felt the satisfaction of killing the butterfly lady in Sekiro, then this will leave you deeply, deeply wanting.

Ultimately, this is a beautiful and immersive game.  I've already sunk 30+ hours into it, and I will probably sink another 20 just to finish it (I'm a tad OCD and have a hard time leaving chests un-opened), but I could just as easily walk and go right on living my life.  I suppose 50-60 hours of play time is decent for $60, but this game doesn't give me the sort of burning "I really hope my wife falls asleep early" need to play like Divinity 2, God of War, Warzone, Cyberpunk, Elden Ring, etc. did.

133609162.review:
So, I really enjoy this game, let's get that out of the way.
Now, do I think it's flawless? No. Do i think it's rewarding? A tad. Do I think it's an open world rpg? Not in the slightest.
This game is very linear, and most of the features are locked behind the main story quest, which is, by definition, very linear. It has set seasons, very little character customization in terms of personality, the choices don't matter besides a few small off handed comments, and the map doesn't seem like it was made by a person who knows how to make maps. It's frustrating in the best of times, and game breaking at the worst of times. There are no permanent companions like was suggested by the trailer, and once you're done with the game that's it. There's hardly any replayability, since most side quests post game are just side quests you missed during it. Overall it felt rushed and unfinished. Not at all like a full open world rpg like they advertised.
Even still, this game is fun. The story has its faults, but it's cute, and i really got attached to the majority of the characters. In fact, I've beaten it 3 times already, and as the hours I've played shows, I've been a bit obsessed with it. I've made 4 characters already, and remade two. I want it to improve. I'm anxiously awaiting updates. I don't want the devs to give up on this game, or shy away from DLC. There's so much more that they can do with this game, and having spent ~70 dollars for this, I hope they do.
I recommend it as it is now at half price (in the very least), if not because it can be fun, then because of the experience playing it. Here's to hoping it lives on, and improves the way I know it can.

133874626.review:
Jaw-droppingly amazing game !

Are you a Harry Potter Fan? 
Are you a fan of open world games?

If the answer to any of the above questions was 'yes', you are absolutely gonna love playing this game.

If you are a Harry Potter fan, this is the game you have been waiting all your life, and trust me when I say that the game was worth the wait. You can just roam the magical world of Hogwarts and nearby places just taking in the scenery and play out the fantasy that you had as a little kid reading Harry Potter for the first time.

If you are not a Potter-head, this is still one of the best open world games currently available. And as all the story happens way before the events that take place in Harry Potter, you can still play this game without knowing anything about Potterverse.

Ratings -

ART - 11/10 | Mind-blowing. This is one of the most beautiful games ever made and if you have the graphics and processor speed to play this at max settings (you wont :D), it is so worth it. Both the castle and Hogsmeade are developed with care and the love that the devs had for this game really shines through.

MUSIC - 10/10 | The game really delivers when it comes to music. They have captured the music to reflect the mood of any particular event in the game pretty well. You will also find some nostalgic tunes from the movies interspersed here and there.

GAMEPLAY - 8.5/10 | This is subjective and will vary from player to player. Some of the combat does become repetitive (I am looking at you spiders), but it is keeping with the story setting which states that goblins and dark wizards have overrun large parts of areas near Hogwarts. The actual combat mechanics are absolutely fantastic, with a mix and match of different spells really keeping the combat fresh. My one complain is that if you keep doing all the side quests, you become kinda too overpowered with the gear and abilities and the fights become kinda easy towards the end part of the game, even at the hardest difficulty.

REPLAYABILITY - 6/10 | The main story line is kinda same, so there is no real need to replay the game with a different house. There is only 1 minor difference in the main story line which is dependent on your house choice,which you can Youtube if you are curious.

STABILITY/BUGS - 9/10 | The game is relatively bug-free in my experience, though I did encounter a random spawning of a merchant on water once. But, hey, this is a game where magic is common-place, so I might have met Jesus disguised as a merchant :).

MULTIPLAYER - 0/10 | This is a single player game.

GRAPHICS - This is a graphics intensive game I was able to run the game on 4K resolution at a stable 70 fps with a mixture of medium and high settings with ray-tracing off and dlss performance. My specs are listed at the end of the review.

RECOMMENDATION - 10/10 | I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this game to anyone who loves Harry Potter or open world games. You will sink hours into this game and it will feel like a few minutes.


My system config -

I was able to run the game on the following specs -
OS - Win 11 (64 bit)
Graphics - 8GB GDDR6 3070 Nvidia RTX laptop card (Mux switch enabled)
RAM - 32 GB
Processor - AMD Ryzen 7 Octa core (4.4 GHz clock speed)
Hard Disk - SSD


TLDR - A must play game for Potter-heads and open world game enthusiasts, with next level graphics. Go for it irrespective of the price, you won't regret it.

133868356.review:
First off I would like to say that Hogwarts Legacy is a must have if you are a fan of the Harry Potter books, movies or universe. Its an amazing feeling to walk through Hogwarts and experience the magical world in this fun yet sometimes challenging RPG.

During the time I played this game, I enjoyed myself immensely. The fact that I get to be a part of this amazing universe and use magic (even though its through a videogame LOL) transported me back to when I was a kid reading the books.

The Hogwarts atmosphere feels real and lively. Students walking the hallways, classes where you learn certain courses like Defense Against The Dark Arts, Herbology or Potions give you a feeling like belong. The game was able to make me feel fully immersed.

The music is great (albeit not masterful) and sells you the feeling of really being in this world. It has some familiar tunes if you have enjoyed the movies and their score before.

The combat is great and sells you the feeling like your spells are really doing damage and have an impact against your enemies. Some enemies are weaker to certain types of spells. The only downside is that sometimes combat can be a little repetitive. I personally didn’t feel this way, but I have seen and read some reviews that mention this particular point, so I thought I would address it anyway.

Graphically the game is beautiful. But it does require a pretty decent system to run it at these graphics. So be aware to check the minimum and recommended requirements before you purchase. Small tip: Turn off raytracing as soon as possible. This will help a lot. (Definitely when you run around in Hogwarts castle.)

Hogwarts Legacy is amazing. But it does have its cons.
I was kind of disappointed (minor gameplay spoiler here) [spoiler] when I found out there was no quidditch. I definitely hoped this would be a part of the game. [/spoiler] There are also a lot of collectibles. And I mean tons of collectibles. A good amount of these are locked behind some really repetitive challenges. So be aware of this. This could be a plus for some people, but I thought it was a little too much. (So heads up for the achievement hunters out there, you have to collect all of these for 100%)

133867281.review:
I was really looking into this game's release, since I'm quite fond of the Harry Potter universe. The game has the majority of concepts you've seen in movies and read in books. The spells have great implementations, fighting is very pleasant, and the environment is brilliant: interiors look like magic, and the castle is just beyond my expectations. The world does feel like it's from a magical universe. Overall in all aspects the game is decent. It's not excellent, but it's decent and I would recommend to play it. It is definitely worth the money.
However, I'd like to leave a list of things that might become a deal breaker for you:

- Performance and overall quality is really bad. This is not only about generally low framerate, but also about weird occasional lag spikes, freezes, fps drops in cutscenes, etc. The game is swarming with bugs that sometimes don't let you start/finish missions, and it becomes really annoying. Not like they are everywhere, but as soon as you encounter bugs, you will definitely remember those unpleasant moments of experience.

- Main quest is garbage. The quest lets you discover a form of magic called "ancient magic", which has no relation to the movie or the book implementation of the world, so it's supposed to be a kind of new type of magic. And the bad thing is that the game fails to explain what kind of a magic it is. All you can learn is that one wielding it, can build nice architecture, change weather, and grow plants. You can also take people's pain, at a particular cost (that you will see in the game). Is that enough to explain the nature of such magic? Clearly no. The only way you can use this "ancient magic" as a character, is to throw objects into enemies (and I have no idea why it's called "ancient magic throw"), and cast a strike onto an enemy with a lot of damage. You can basically take out any enemy with such a strike, but it'll take some time to recharge. Mini-bosses and bosses will need 2 or more strikes. And that's it, you're just left with these two mechanics, without any knowledge of where this magic comes from, and why the heck you need it.
The other part of the main quests is spinning around an evil goblin named Ranrok, who literally: wants to find boundless power and make the world bow to him. Such a cliche, with no taste in it. If Voldermort had some basic ideas that kinda look like fascism, and Grindelwald wanted to ruin the iron curtain between the wizzards and the muggles, then Ranrok simply wants to find a source of limitless power to just... rule over wizzards? Lame. Besides, all quests in the game, which are related to Ranrok, mainly include fights, nothing else. So you just run around, smash goblins and do small quizzes.
Side quests from Poppy (because you get to help animals, who doesn't like that? :D) and Sebastian (will teach you Imperio, Crucio, and Avada Kedavra) have way way way more interesting quests with more diverse game mechanics than the main quest, even though these two are quite short. Maybe you'll like Natty's quest as well.

- Hogwarts staff is lame af. Neither of the professors stays in your memory. Maybe it was a case for the movies, because they span across multiple hours, so you kind of feel anxious for them, but in the game you simply have no reason to give a monkey's left nut: they just walk around the castle and don't talk much. There's nothing that binds you with the professors and develops any feelings to them. The most disappointing was the Hogwarts' headmaster: a guy who has absolutely no clue how to manage the castle and its dwellers. Everyone complains about him, and he annoys you throughout the entire walkthrough. I was expecting some kind of a wise old man who knows what he's doing, but instead got this wanker. Professor Fig isn't less lame, because most of the time he's like "hmmmm, I wonder", "hmmmm, strange...". "hmmm, what does that mean?". Wasn't he supposed to be more wise and powerful than the main character?
[spoiler]Besides, the guy dies in the end of the main quest for no fucking reason at all. A second ago he was helping to hold a giant rock mid-air, and now he's crippling and fucking dying. I suppose the game expected the players to develop some feelings to professor Fig, and by killing him, triggering some emotions. But no, the game doesn't make the professor unique enough. He did nothing to make me regret his unexpected death. That just looks silly.[/spoiler]

- The game lacks proper cut-scenes. Most of the time you will be looking at characters as they speak, from two angles, and the characters won't be doing anything with their bodies, hands, legs, just talking. Feels like the developers just didn't have money for cut-scenes for all quests, not even the main one.

- If you're done with the main quest and side quests (Sebastian, Poppy, and Natty) - you're basically done with the game too. There's no point in exploring the world, since all aspects of the game's universe are covered by the main quest and those three I've enumerated. You can of course go and purge all bandit camps, but that's only if you really like fighting. By the end of the game they will become too easy and bland. All caves and ruins are almost identical. The worst thing is that after finishing the game, you're presented with loot chests, that don't offer you anything of value. Very soon you become strong enough to just ignore all of them, because you don't need them. That ruins the point of exploring caves and castles. This balance problem makes it boring to wander around and explore the world. Probably the only interesting thing left are treasure hunts with maps. They do have some interesting quizzes. Exploring the castle in this case also becomes quite boring, since there's nothing hidden or new, that you haven't seen in the movie. Occasional chests with useless loot is the maximum.

- The game presents you with combat plants, however, I personally didn't find any use for them. You can buy them in stores, which is kinda okay, if you're a loot nerd and pick everything you can see (useless clothing can be sold for good money). Or, you can grow these plants, which is quite tedious. Besides, they don't give you much advance in combat.

- The game reacts to your dialog and spell choices in absolutely no way, with the exception of a faculty (gryffindor, slytherin, and so on). If you want to play as a really dark wizard - forget about it. Nobody will give a damn if you use unforgivable curses all the time, even in front of a professor. You also can't kill friendly or passive npcs, or animals. This point was a major drawback for me personally. I really did want to see the relationships change based on how I acted in combat and dialogs.

Hope I helped!
