133860731.review:
First of all, I need to say that I’m having a really good time with this game and my overall rating is positive.
The open world and the character design, with their vivid facial expressions, are stunningly beautiful. I’m enthused about the combat system; it’s a mix of Souls-like and a combinatory casting system so far unheard-of. And the idea of the Room of Requirement is genius and lots of fun! As to me, it is enough to roam the wizarding world, whose spirit has been exceptionally well captured, and seek out and knock down enemies, to give the game an overall positive rating.

However, I think there are lots of conceptual drawbacks and game design decisions, which I seriously mourn. With alterations, the game could have been so much more.

These include:

Pointless night/day cycles and lifeless NPCs are my number one immersion buster. In the beginning, I did not imagine NPCs without scripted routines necessarily a bad thing. The way it’s implemented in Hogwarts Legacy, it is. Regardless of the time of the day, you run into a shop and receive a cheerful welcome from the always available, smiling merchant, at your service. At – supposedly - 0300 in the night. Given that you can have an instant nap on the floor and swap day/night at any time, it wouldn’t have been a hassle to make the shopping system more believable.

Then, isn’t there a curfew at night? Every now and then NPCs debate about it. Despite one rather flimsy sneaking mission, the curfew is completely omitted. You run free around the castle at any given hour unhampered by anything and anyone. Surely some ghosts or at least Peeves could tell on you. Nothing. Run into the forbidden section of the library with a roar. Infiltrate the teachers’ quarters at night and do a little dancey around them standing lifelessly in the middle of the room. Break into some poor family’s home to find them enjoying a posh cupper after midnight while you perform a tap dance on their table. Not to speak of looting all their belongings right in front of their eyes. Seriously?!

What’s most disappointing to me is the world itself being unaffected by night/day- or it’s so minor that it has slipped me. Isn’t the forbidden forest a dreadful location spreading fear among students and grown witches and wizards alike? Quite on the contrary, do your little joy walk in the forest at any time of the day and stay unimpressed by the occasional handful of spiders. Even the centaurs roaming the forest are completely unresponsive to you, even if you cast some crucio up their ****. I remember my accelerating heartbeat when, years ago, in Ocarina of Time sundown was close and I was running for my life to reach the drawbridge, before it would lock me out with the night horrors. If you dared take a step off the roads, doom arose from the ground around you. In Hogwarts Legacy, nothing like that, the world wants to please, not challenge you.

Somewhere I read that it was a conscious design decision to omit a morality system. To me, frankly, it sounds like an excuse for an approaching release deadline. It just doesn’t make any sense, if you, while being head-over-heels in a fight with dark wizards together with your caring mentor or some innocent school mate, surprise them with a crucio out of your pocket and they give you the same demented look as they always do. Come on, they’re unforgivable, please send me to Azkaban for this! Likewise, so far, I did not see any obvious effect of the choice of dialogue options. Be it the friendly or more rough option, the dialogue always seems to continue in a diplomatic way, advancing the quest in a one-dimensional way. My opinion on this is preliminary, as I haven’t yet completed my first playthrough; maybe there’s the big reveal and day of reckoning in the end? I doubt it, though, but will be happy to update my review if I’m proven wrong.

Also, a very big deal to me is the overall difficulty of the game. I started off in normal mode, so I’m hoping for a spicier experience once I switch to hard difficulty. As for now, in my 50 or so hours of gameplay, I might have died a handful of times- usually because I took a clumsy step and fell off a cliff. Enemies don’t pose a challenge. Usually you run into a dungeon – well, dungeons don’t really exist, rather small caves with hardly any ramifications – obliterate every soul that’s inside, interact with something, and track back out. The lack of challenging fights goes hand in hand with brainless puzzles: with Revelio you see what’s interactable, you interact, done. Sometimes you need to push a crate, rotate a portal or whatever, but it’s almost offensive how little thinking and trying is required to solve a puzzle. And on top of that, my character doesn’t even leave a any chance of making my own thoughts: usually within the first second after approaching a puzzle, the character tips off the full explanation about how to proceed. Such a killjoy! Other games at least leave you the choice whether or not you want a hint. Also a big bummer: bosses – in terms of looks and attack patterns - seem super uninspired.

And lastly: invisible walls and you-cant-do-that-stuff everywhere! I fully understand that even an open (game) world needs restrictions to provide a smooth gaming experience. No dev wants every player easily glitch out of the map. But in Hogwarts Legacy, openness is a very generous term. Oftentimes you can’t even walk behind huge statues, jump over tiny walls etc. There are other means to confine a world without breaking immersion! Look at Elden Ring, for example: if you’re not meant to go somewhere, place an abyss or maybe enemies or traps way to tough for you to proceed. That gives incentive to explore! Not being able to climb the smallest rock because of invisible barriers is simply disheartening. Some restrictions of the game seem justified: being unable to unmount a broom in very narrow areas seems plausible. But why can’t I land on the castle’s roof? Gosh, put in some student nerd patrol that drags me to the headmaster if I do something frowned upon, but don’t give me a “you can’t do that” message box! Argh!

This being said, it makes a lot of sense that not every area of the open world can be entered on a mount. Imagine the traffic chaos in Hogsmeade! But what’s the deal with all the areas in the open wilderness that are surrounded by an impenetrable “magic barrier”? Of course, I tried to get on top of the highest mountain as soon as I got my broom. Why the hell not! Why, then, is there a barrier preventing me from doing that? Did the devs lack time to finish this part of the map? In Breath of the Wild, I wouldn’t be able to do that at first due to lacking climbing skills and stamina, or because I’m dressed inappropriately for the chills in higher areas. Very believable restriction! But like this? Shame!

Ach, I forgot- the fast travel system is way overdone. Virtually every few meters you stumble across a fast travel station- who got them installed in the depth of the wilderness? Since you can access fast traveling from the map at any given time (you don’t even need to seek out the next travel station), you find yourself hopping from node to node and continue your rather short walk from there. Kills every incentive to explore. Makes using your mount most of the time pointless. I think I only once left or entered Hogwarts by feet- I have seriously no idea how the castle connects with the rest of the world, let alone the insides of this otherwise masterpiece of game art design. Such a pity! I know, why don’t I just walk? Well, because sometimes I’m as well attracted toward short-term-solutions and appreciate incentive.

Reading through my review, the emphasis on criticism makes it look like there’s more cons than pros to this game- it is not! The game design has a lot of beauty and novelty and a lot to offer!

However, to me it’s rather a wizarding world travel and socializing simulator, than an adventure.

This is probally GOTY 2023 for me.

The collectibles they give you are addicting, I have 80 hours played and completed the game 100% on everything. (Excluding achievements, not a fan of those)

Music: 10/10

Graphics: 9/10, slight annoyance that you have to sharpen the picture quality everytime you boot up the game. (DLSS) Might have to drop some settings duo to optimization issues. Overal would recommend to ANY Harry Potter fan or just a newcomer that likes Open-world RPG's with great graphics & collectibles. No microtransactions or bullshit cashshop. A full game worthy of you're time. 

Its worth the FULL price! Dont wait/sleep on this game, you wont regret it!

133857972.review:
After spending little over 100 hours on this game I must say that I love it. It really feels new and different from many games that are already out there and really threw me for a loop even if I had quite high expectations for this game.
The combat is great. The environment is beautiful. The characters you meet and befriend are likable, relatable and most of the time interesting. The mechanic with taking care of beasts almost had me in tears the first time I walked into the vivarium,

BUT! And there is a big but. There is a reason I do not give this game 10/10. 
First off...In the beginning and middle of the game your character feels REALLY... Mary Sue ish... Your character goes to learn a spell, learns it on the first try and everyone is in awe. I mean really compliments you like you are Jesus born anew. You go to retrieve something at the bottom of a lake. Have you ever dove before? No? Everyone is in awe of your ability to be able to dive so well on the first try. At beast class you pretty much befriend all beasts by looking at them etc etc. Your character is SO perceptive and intelligent and can do no wrong. It kind of ticked me off to be honest. 

Also the fact that it felt like the developers already had a character in mind for this story, how they would act what they would be like etc. The only thing you really control are some choices, what your character look like and whether this character is an ahole or not. I mean what if my character love spiders? Pretty much every time when you defeat spiders the main character comments how much they hate spiders. What if I want my character to be more like Hagrid? 
And I wanted my character to be an all loving beast freak and it felt like my character was not allowed to because the developers already had put up a frame of what my character should be like. 

The Mary Sue thing gets better by the end portion of the game but God I almost wanted to punch all characters that treated me like a messiah. I mean I know the chosen one trope is kind of a given but the chosen one can have layers, make mistakes etc. Just take Mass Effects commander Shepherd. 

*SPOILER ALERT*I mean commander Shepherd fails a couple of missions, and he sucks at dancing, not everyone agrees with his decisions and sometimes for good reasons, he even has to work with the bad guy for a while and he is still "the chosen one" with a lot of skills etc. And you still feel like you can mold commander Shepherd into what character you wish for him or her to be like. So Id have like more choices for your character.

Then we have the mini games... Or specifically the alohomora mini game...Guys seriously... Alohomora is supposed to be a convenient spell that opens doors quickly... Who thought it was a brilliant idea to make a mini game for a spell that is supposed to be the most practical and convenient spell?! I mean it is not a hard mini game and it does not take up much time but when you have to go through that mini game to open 50 different doors it gets old pretty fast... And again the spell is supposed to be the most practical and convenient spell and you just managed to make it tedious as f to use.... I sighed every time I had to unlock a bloody door.

Then we have the Merlin trials...I actually really liked them. I really really liked the concept and thought it was fun before I found out I would have to do them almost 100 times if I wanted to complete them all. Seeing as I like to complete as much as possible in any game I play, something I liked and enjoyed quickly turned into another thing I sighed about every time I saw that leaf icon pop up everywhere I went. I get it you don't have to do all of them. But it still bugged me that they could not have implemented some of these challenges into the game without needing to do them almost hundred times to complete them all.

The story is also really nothing special. It is not bad by any means and they could have done way worse on that front. It is fine and somewhat creative but not a story I will remember for years to come type of deal.

Having said all that I still love love LOVE this game. It is a magical experience to say the least. The magic that is implemented in the exploration aspect is so much fun and everything in this game is simply wonderful and feels magical (except the things I mentioned above.) The quests never got boring and the side quests themselves where a joy to play through, exploring the world and Hogwarts for hours was a wonder and delight and just yeah. This game is great!

133856097.review:
First off, I would like to say I love this game. I very much enjoy it and do recommend it, especially to fans of the Wizarding World. However, there are a few things I feel could greatly improve the game, at least in my opinion. 

Spoilers ahead of course, so be warned.

As much as I like open-world games, I feel like it was unnecessary for this game outside of Hogwarts. Exploring the castle, Hogsmeade and Forbidden Forest was perfect, but I feel the rest of the map wasn't needed. It was my thought that as students we were confined to the castle grounds for our own safety, so exploring outside of it (out of curfew hours might I add) seemed extremely reckless considering our character is literally being hunted by Goblins, poachers and dark wizards. I did find exploring the wider world cool on my initial playthrough but after I found it to be tedious and mostly didn’t bother apart from to do side quests. There are far too many Merlin trials and collectables out in the world that are so repetitive and give you nothing but an achievement for completing so felt very pointless. Exploring Hogwarts was definitely a treat and I loved finding places I had forgotten about or were new to me. The only downside was that it would have been more immersive to have prefects and professors roaming the corridors at night making us have to sneak past them. But other than that I wouldn’t change it.

As for classes themselves, they were fun the first time because they had mini-games of sorts, but that was it. After that is just a quick cutscene. They could have done it like in Bully, where you get two classes a day to attend and play a mini-game, and depending on how well you do will determine your score. Just look at the potions mini-game in the Half Blood Prince game. It could even contribute to our O.W.Ls at the end of the year. And lastly make it so we have to attend a few before we learn a new spell from the professors, so it actually seems like we’re attending school.

When it comes to fellow students and professors I feel like we didn’t get as much time with them as we should have. We had one initial class with the professors then were given a couple of assignments to complete to learn new spells but that was it. Apart from Fig, they weren’t really included in the story, which I found disappointing as I like them all. And considering two of those professor’s were an ex-auror and an unspeakable, our character would have been way more prepared to face Ranrok if they had been in-the-know instead of us having to do everything ourself. Even our fellow students, who we help with their own quests, don’t come with us. It would have been cool if after helping them they would all come with us on our quests, each with their own unique skill. Despite being classmates before we came along they never seem to interact with each other at all. Would have been cool to have our own little group like Harry, Ron and Hermione.

Lastly, a morality system. Having dialogue options did basically nothing other than kind-of-but-not-really show your personality, but even then our character is pretty much always good. Would have been cool to have personality dialogue like in the Dragon Age games. There are no consequences for your actions which makes it a little boring. If they had introduced a points system it would have made it interesting trying to stay out of trouble. Even at the end of the game after you have made a few choices, there is little to no mention of them.

There are probably a few things I’ve forgotten to mention but those are the main things I feel could have made a big difference for me. Overall I do like the game and hope we get a sequel or some DLC in future to improve it.

133854060.review:
Could this be...Merlin Trial?

I like many aspects of Hogwarts Legacy; I wish Steam would allow for a "meh" rating. It is a great game, but there are too many missed opportunities for it to be a "once in a decade" game. It is more action adventure than action RPG.

There is this beautifully detailed world with a impressive art style and intriguing mystical music. You'll have plenty of things to do and many places to discover. The story is intriguing, many characters have depth and the Room of Requirements is one of the best features I ever discovered in my gaming years. The combat is fun and you can combine spells in many ways to find your personal fighting style. Also, there is the possibility to reduce the amount of UI - which I appreciate. The graphics are great and clothing customization is just top notch!

However, many environments (dungeons, camps) and game mechanics are reused way to often (Merlin Trials, Alohomora Puzzles, Collectibles, Scripted Events, ...). Don't get me wrong, all mechanics are fun at the beginning, but this wears of rather quickly. You have the choice to ignore repeating elements and I would recommend you to do it. It mostly isn't worth it to grind them - I found they are most fun when stumbling upon them on occasion.

You want to feel part of Hogwarts? Well, after initial exploration it feels like a staged scenery: You can't sit anywhere, you can't sleep in the common room (which really has no relevance after the beginning), there is no house rivalry, you don't attend classes besides for missions. Also, the "RPG" elements don't suffice for me to feel connected to the world. They should have focused on more immersion rather than a large world map with dozens of bandit camps. The game would provide a solid basis for that.

Now, some bullet lists!

What could have been:
- More immersion, smaller world (Classes, Morality System, Penalties, House Competition,...). It does not have to be a full on simulator for that: Look at Bully and Shadow of Mordor
- Actual character development (e.g. Disco Elysium)
- Using Dark Arts should have an impact on how people react to you
- More choices that matter, feeling that they have an impact and consequences (less linearity)
- More depth to the Goblin Rebellion and the choice to side with them
- More sophisticated potion brewing (e.g. Kingdom Come Deliverance)
- Having companions outside missions
- End game content
- NG+
- Overall, the main character should be less godly (you can not make any mistakes, your character does everything perfectly and this is also communicated in dialogues)

How to improve Quality of Life:
- Less repeating voice lines (e.g. floo powder, discovering trials / dungeons, visiting Hogsmeade)
- Mark items in inventory to bulk sell them at vendors
- Be able to look up and down when flying
- Being able to sell potions and ingredients
- Skip Alohomora puzzles with a higher level Alohomora spell

133853956.review:
tl;dr:
7/10 - must buy if you're a fan of the Wizzarding world, wait for a sale if you're not. 

The wizzarding world was the constant franchise of early 2000's. For people like me who went to middle school around the time the books and movies were released, it was a pop culture phenomenon. It was everywhere, you read the books, saw the movies, played those early EA video game adaptations back when they were good. And after the 8th movie came out you were around the same age as the characters, you were done with school and heading out into the real world. This franchise means a lot to the 'millennial' generation and I'd say Avalanche has done a great job capturing what made the franchise so special all those years ago, while still taking into account that the target audience isn't twelve anymore.

Fans of the franchise will love this game. Hogwarts has everything you'll recognize from the movies, and even stuff from the books that never made it to the silver screen. The smallest things, like the potion ingredient store closet or the jail cell on the roof they kept Sirius Black in for all of 2 seconds in the third movie. The House Elf kitchens and the ghost ballroom from the books, they're all there for you to discover. It's a nostalgia trip and that alone is worth the price of admission, IF you are a fan.

Avalanche has done everything it can to make this game appeal to all, unfortunately they listened to the twitter side of the internet for what would appeal to them. The response this game has gotten online is nothing short of hilarious, the very people this game is made for are trying all that they can to stop people from playing it. Their whims are being catered to at every turn. From the for 1790's Scotland laughably diverse student body and faculty, merchants and townsfolk, to the sexuality of every side character seemingly being non-straight. You'd think they'd eat this game up, but no. I hope that sends a message to the industry that you can not please these people. 

For people less familiar with the source material, or those who never really cared that much, this game must seem a bit mid. When you get out of Hogwarts you are greeted with a massive overworld that is completely littered with useless stuff. Mostly consisting of what are called Merlin trials, which require you to do a tedious little puzzle to trigger an animation. This gets you inventory upgrades, so you'll have to do at least a few, but there a dozens of these menial things everywhere. 
As well as the caves, which are all copy pasted from the same handful of templates and get you nothing other than a piece of gear which is always worse than what you already have. You can completely ignore these but they will always clutter up your compass, map and minimap.

Combat is simple and can be trivialized with potions and plants, I finished the whole thing challenge dungeons and all on normal difficulty but it never actually got difficult. Maybe that changes on higher difficulties, but the combat isn't what makes this game worth playing anyway.

This game shines in it's presentation, like I said, if you are a fan of the wizzarding world you will love this game. But it doesn't quite capture the (pardon the phrasing) magic of going to a magic school and having your own adventure. I think most of that is to do with the lack of interaction with your classmates. You do your main adventure mostly on your own being aided only by a professor. Your classmates are relegated to side quests, which I think is a shame. Because what connected the audience to the story of the books and movies was building this bond with new friends and together becoming stronger than any adversary. Here you are the chosen one who could've done it all by themselves.
Portkey games has this phone game 'Hogwarts Mystery' that does that way better. I hope they decide to port that to PC in some from or another now that this is such a rousing success.  

Who you are in this game is vague, your origins are not revealed. Who are you? Why are you only joining Hogwarts as a fifth year? Where do you come from? It seems there's a prelude missing and kind of an important one. 
The choices you make along the way also don't matter to the story one bit.  

Avalanche clearly want you to spend the bulk of your time in Hogwarts. You get a whole room all to yourself for you to interact with animals, build the perfect pen for them. Create your own space decorated to your liking, you can sink hours into just that if you wanted to. 

Technically it runs well enough. It runs on the Unreal 4 engine, so there's still pop-in everywhere when you're outside zipping through the map on a broom. It also does a small frame drop every time you charge into a different area of the overworld map. Inside Hogwarts that all goes away. It does have to load a second or two at doors at times still though. So you can see the seams in this seamlessly connected world, but they didn't really bother me.
Enemy AI is single minded and dumb, when you blast someone of a platform or just remove them far enough from their path, they have to run all the way back to where they started. They won't attack you during their little hike until they get there. None of them will ever dodge out of the way.

The amount of content here is nothing to sneeze at, and considering the success of this game I'd be surprised if Warner Bros. didn't come out with some cut content as DLC. There's a screenshot of a dragon on this very storepage that is just not in this game. The made character models fro dementors that are only used in one cutscene for one Hufflepuff specific quest in Azkaban. We only hear about stuff happening in the ministry. Definitely room for expansion.

For fans of franchise this is an absolute must-buy. For everyone else, you should probably wait for a sale. It's a fun romp, but like I said, without the nostalgia trip it loses a lot of it's appeal.

133851023.review: My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

133842888.review:
Easily one of the best games I've ever played.

I've been waiting for Hogwarts Legacy ever since they've announced it, and the long wait is worth it! This game is set in the late 1800s, and the entire plot revolves around a mysterious power that you (the character) wields and the goblin rebellion that has been terrorising the wizarding world. 

It is an open world concept, so very BOTW-like. Only difference being your weapons don't break (obviously). As you progress in the game, you get to rear and cultivate your own plants and even beasts/animals that you can keep in the Room of Requirement.

Locations in the game like the Room of Requirement and even the locations of the common rooms are very spot on. Even way before I am able to access the Room of Requirement, I already had an inkling of where it is when I happened to pass by a large painting of a man teaching trolls how to dance on the seventh floor. And when I went exploring around the school, I found the locations of the other three common rooms (I'm in Ravenclaw), though obviously, I can't access it. But the locations are very spot on.

Conversations between NPCs too tells you more of the world than what is told to you. There is one occasion when I entered a classroom only to witness a student being told off by a Howler which adds some humor to it.

You can also explore Hogsmeade and befriend the villagers and even do side quests for them.

The only complaint (not really complain) that I have, is that there doesn't seem to be a curfew for our character at all. I can still explore the school at night, and there doesn't seem to be any consequences whatsoever. 

Combat too is very straight forward. You sling spells at your opponents and could put up shields and dodge. Though I almost had a heart attack the first time I came face to face with a group of Inferi which gave me lots of unwanted flashbacks to when I was watching a friend play Resident Evil. Setting them on fire has never felt so satisfying before.

Overall, I give this game a 10/10, and it definitely has replay value, not unlike Skyrim. Hoping the devs will include Quidditch playing in a DLC though.

I played this game on the Steam Deck, and it runs perfectly, tho I need to set the resolution so that screenshots I took actually looks good.

The game is well worth playing through once. It's quite pretty, it's UI is good, it's well optimised, and some of its missions and characters are quite appealing. It's also got good aesthetic choices regarding the fashion so you can - if you want - be incredibly anal about what you choose to wear though you'll look mostly look either very stupid or very out of place if you don't dress like a normal Hogwarts student.

it's not perfect though. For one it's not even remotely immersive. 1800s Britain was not flooded with foreigners and even today it's rather rare to find them in the Scottish Highlands of all places. The combat is easy and there are very few enemy types. The dungeons are incredibly repetitive. The dialogue makes it feel like the side quests are open and non-linear but they are - in fact - incredibly linear. The loot is universally useless given the combat is too easy to demand stat hunting and the equipment is all skins with stats attached. The rest of the loot is miscellaneous crap for decorating your room. House choice doesn't matter at all apart from aesthetics. The Forbidden Forest is basically just an area and doesn't really distinguish itself much. Your crusade to 'save' all the animals is pretty much just a nicer version of poaching. The only worthwhile mount is the broom and most broom skins suck ass. 

Gets an upvote because it's fun to play through the story but don't expect 100% ing this game to be anything but very tedious. Could very much use some DLC, mods, or expansions that add new enemies.

Fantastic game, far better story, world-building, and depth than I expected. The devs could have easily coasted on the Harry Potter IP and made a game that tons of people would pay for, but chose to make a truly rich, deep game with tons to explore. PC performance is a bit too inconsistent to not mention, though. Thankfully, the performance during the most important parts was great. I would get a rock solid 120 FPS during major battles, but then drop to a stuttery, inconsistent 40-50 FPS (with clear frame drops regularly) during some overworld tasks or in seemingly basic, enclosed spaces like stairwells. Seems like the devs put a ton of attention into getting performance right where it mattered, but it's a bit disappointing that areas that would seem on the surface to be extremely easy to render have less than half the FPS of other areas. I suspect in time this will be fixed, but for now it is something to keep in mind. Regardless, if you don't have more than 16GB RAM, don't even consider playing this at 1080p or higher, even with DLSS at ultra performance mode. This is truly a "next gen" game in the sense that it is totally unplayable on old hardware.

The performance issues are extremely easy to ignore however, because the game is fantastic. The normal difficulty is honestly probably a bit too easy, but maybe hard mode is a significant step up. Idk, haven't tried it yet. I have about 85% completion of the game in total at about 40 hours of game time, which seems like a perfectly reasonable game:price ratio. Highly recommend.

133838947.review:
This is the Hogwarts based game that HP fans have been dreaming of since the first HP game. Make a wizard or witch, explore the entire castle to your satisfaction, cast a bunch of spells  (including the unforgivable curses) and save the wizarding world from a big threat.

I do have a few complaints. Mainly that the characters and your relationships with them seem pretty superficial overall. A few standouts (Sebastian and Poppy) really add to the world but overall it's somewhat hard for me to find real investment. Example: a friend of mine asked me which professor was my favorite and I really struggled with finding a reason to pick one over the others.

A related complaint is the lack of depth to character relationships. Several lines from NPCs gives me the impression that romance may have been intended at one point, but was abandoned. Though I can't be sure of that, the relationships you form do seem to be pretty shallow.

Quests likewise lack a meaningful impact.

But this game really shines in exploration and having the world feel like a completely natural translation and expansion of the universe. I especially like some touches like moving the Slytherin sink (the entrance to the chamber of secrets) bathroom to a location that fits the books more accurately, while keeping the exact look from the movie. The entire world feels like a true representation of Hogwarts, and the wizarding communities that surround it.

I disagree with some of the decisions they've made here, and while I love the characters, I wish interactions and relationships with them felt more meaningful. With all that said however, I would gladly rate this game a 9/10. I truly hope they release DLC expansions to this, and that any potential followup includes at least a basic multiplayer component.

I like the game very much.  There are some points that I think could have had a bit more thought behind it.

133834567.review:
As someone who has very little experience with the franchise, I never felt too lost playing Hogwarts Legacy. There are a few idioms that characters use that contain setting-specific creatures I was unfamiliar with, but other than that, I felt the game did a good job of keeping me in the loop. Portkey Games has done a wonderful job in making the game feel fantastical, down to small touches like the animation of picking up potion ingredients in the world, and it's made me interested in finally getting around to the Harry Potter series.

The story is rather average - While I didn't get invested enough to care too much about most of the characters, I wasn't bored either. The beginning of the game is a slight bit slow, but once the game opens up a bit and lets you explore, there's enough freedom to feel free to explore the world and side missions, and forget about the story for a bit. Exploration is a treat for a good while, but a fair few become repetitive due to little variety. However, they typically aren't too tedious. Perhaps the story would be more fulfilling if I were a big fan of the franchise, but it's solid enough that I didn't mind.

The combat is simple to pick up, but remains enjoyable through to the end. The sixteen combat spells are more than enough to provide a solid arsenal, and the pace feels on the faster side. Unfortunately, there isn't any challenging content to test your skills once you've hit the maximum level and are geared out. With no DLC in the works, it doesn't seem like that'll change either. I played on normal difficulty, and didn't see much need to use potions or plants in combat, though hard difficulty might change that.

For all the plentiful praises that the game deserves though, there is plenty that could be improved upon, and I hope Portkey games takes lessons from it. The way gearing is handled is one of the more glaring ones, as it feels clunky. The number of inventory slots is oddly low, especially at the beginning of the game before you've had the chance to expand it, and even then it's not a huge improvement. Better gear mostly means more Offence or Defense stat, which isn't all too exciting. Upgrading gear simply ups these unexciting stats, and cost materials from the Room of Requirement, so some might not upgrade at all until they're replacing gear less often. Gear traits allow you to increase the damage of specific spells or increase your resistance against certain enemy types, but they give you no numbers to work with to give you a solid understanding. Significantly more damage for Diffindo? Great, but how much is "significantly more"?

TLDR: Hogwarts Legacy has a fair few flaws, but the positives outweigh them by a large margin, and I would recommend giving it a try. I look forward to seeing the next project Portkey Games works on, and hope they can improve on the flaws from this game and build upon it going forward.

I'm having a great time with this game! It's truly open world; not to the level of Skyrim or even Witcher III, but those are awfully high bars. 

Hogwarts is absolutely GORGEOUS.  Each area is decorated in a different style or with unique details, but it all creates a cohesive, spectacularly beautiful whole.

The Room of Requirement is fun to customize, as well. 

I do wish the NPCs were more aware and intelligent. The fact that you can let yourself in or even lock pick and house or store, and pillage any chest you find right in front of the occupants, and they don't mind - or even notice - is a bit immersion-breaking.

I found the PC controls for flying (i.e. on a broom) difficult and unintuitive at first, but I remapped he speed toggle and descent keys (to Mouse 3/thumb button and Alt, respectively, in my case) and now flying is great fun.

Overall, it's a visually beautiful game that's a ton of fun to play. Highly recommended.

Hogwarts Legacy is a compelling and immersive game set in the wonderful world of Harry Potter created by JK Rowling. Avalanche Software have managed to capture both the books and the movies so well in all aspects from the incredibly interactive castle and easter eggs that aren't rubbed in your face and fit well into the environment they crafted (it held its own unique take too, the statues that got into a fight made me laugh. You can tell so much passion went into crafting Hogwarts and the surrounding areas are honestly really good however not on the level as Hogwarts, there is so much to explore and discover which I'll let you find out for yourself.

This game is everything I've always wanted from a Harry potter game bringing back so much nostalgia and memories there's nothing more i could of wanted. The sound and music design is impeccable while it's no John Williams it had it's own charm to it. The narrative was honestly for me rather enjoyable and for the most part really good, the side quests with the companions were really good and the main narrative while I thought was decent, did lack a little bit/speed through it while missing the opportunity to delve more into certain characters and motives and so on, but for what it was it didn't subtract from the experience and I enjoyed it a lot, I often found myself wondering off from the main quests for collectables and exploring, man the collectables and so on are awesome, gave me vibes of a lot of older games in that sense, still need to 100% them but so far enjoying finding them.

The gameplay was enjoyable, I found myself enjoying the gameplay loop for the combat and the crafting and so on (on normal mode) however I do think the gearing could of been fleshed out, felt a little to easy and gear felt meaningless as i progressed and got all my spells and talents. I enjoyed using potions and plants I had grown in herbology and potions while mixing it in with the core wand spell gameplay. 

Side note the transmorg system could use an option to save an outfit appearance instead of having to redo it manually everytime especially with all the constant new gear upgrades.

The room of requirement is honestly fantastic giving you your own space to customise and make yours while have LOADS of customisation options and crafting stuff, and the beast zoo's are wholesome, that whole system is such a fun side activity. The flying on the broom and mounts was great, took a bit of getting used to but afterwards I was able to re-enact
harry on a broom or gliding along the black lake on my hippogriff. (Quidditch DLC pls)

On a side note I'd love to see future DLC added for story like the tri-wizard tournament or going under the black lake with the merpeople and so on, also a sequel going through the 6th and 7th year! Trading cards soon?

Overall very happy with my gameplay experience here was well worth the purchase and am very happy to do so to support it. I would honestly give Hogwarts Legacy a 9/10, as I honestly loved it that much however there were a few issues for me, but nothing that took away from the experience, this has honestly been the best singleplayer game since Red dead 2 for me. I recommended it to all harry potter fans and those who haven't delved into this world it's defiantly worth it! Thank you Avalanche for this truly magical experience.

133830840.review:
Let's address the elephant in the room first: JK Rowling's attacks on trans people sicken and anger me. I pre-purchased this game before I was aware of that whole mess, and I seriously considered not playing the game once I did look into it. I'm still not very comfortable with my decision, but my love of the Wizarding World that JKR created and that hundreds (if not thousands) of other artists and craftspeople have brought to life outweighs my repulsion at the author's personal views. 

Now on to Hogwarts Legacy. While I have a laundry list of things I'd love to see expanded or added to this game, I've been enjoying the hell out of it as is. Everything that is in the game is well thought out and well executed. As a middle-aged guy whose reflexes are not what they once were, the combat system has just about the right amount of difficulty, I had to work at getting good, and I could still be better, and that's all exactly as it should be, IMHO. 

I'm aware that people have some performance issues, but the few that I've encountered (while playing at the High  graphics setting) are minimal - the occasional stutter or a bit of tearing. Your mileage may vary. Overall, though, I've found the game stable and breathtakingly beautiful. I frequently eschew Floo Powder for my broom or travel by foot, just to enjoy the scenery and the atmosphere.

The story is top-notch, as well. There is a bit of road-railing in a couple of the subplots, and I'd love to see more options in those and other areas, but I never expected Hogwarts Legacy to be a sandbox, anyway. (Though a sandbox rpg or mmo in the setting could be awesome!) Everything that happens in the game seems appropriate and logical, and all of the plots that I've played through so far have had satisfying development and conclusions.

So Hogwarts Legacy may not fulfill all of my dreams, but it does a great job of meeting my expectations, and I'm totally ready to purchase some DLC.

I really do love the game a lot and have over 200 hours of playtime, I guess it's time to write an honest, yet simple, review:
+ the graphics, the views, I can get lost running or flying for hours and always stumble on something new.
+ the story, I think it's well thought through and I really enjoyed it.
+ I love how big it is and how many hours you can spend enjoying it
+ how many aspects there are of the Wizarding world. The magic, the shops, all of hogwarts, the fiends, allies, beasts. It really sucks you right into the world.
+ there are so many unique quests to enjoy with each a little story.
+ fast travel points are always amazing, yet I rarely used them this game since running around is so much fun

- I wish choices would actually matter and give us a different outcome. Sometimes I would make a choice and it would do what the other choice would have done.
- on that topic, make relationships matter, right now it doesn't matter if you are kind or not. Make the decisions have consequences. Or just give us something showing the relationships we developed, good or bad.
- there is so much multi-player potential (broom races, duelling, or even just stats). But none of it is used
- the game keeps mentioning OWLs and I was hoping to do like little tests, quizzes etc (and maybe take the relationships you build into this too) and get an outcome of what you accomplished
- a lot of repeating in the end. Mainly the merlin trials, it probably wouldn't be as bad if there  wasn't the same cutscene over and over.

Other:
1. I wish there was a picture function since the world is just so beautiful!

2. I really do hope they change their minds on dlc's, there are so many possibilities to add! Owl's, quidditch, relationships, and if there's a sequel I just hope it continues the story.
3. Yes there are still bugs, but my game has been playable and they seem to really be on top of fixing them.

133827448.review:
Personally not too crazy over the Harry Potter universe, but as a lover of the open world RPG genre this game has been a top tier experience for me. There is SO much to explore in Hogwarts castle alone (the rest of the map is surprisingly big as well) and the castle feels very alive with a variety of funny npc interactions and moving paintings, suits of armor, ghosts, etc.

The combat is pretty in depth, and I REALLY wish there were difficulties above "hard". There is iframe dodge rolling, shield parrying, color coded shield breaking, and a variety of spell effects that let you really feel like a proper mage with a variety of abilities at your command. There were only 2 moments where the game felt a little challenging and I purposefully died to restart that segment over and over because I was having so much fun! (Health pots made the game too easy so I avoided using them)

Only experienced very minor graphical bugs, but nothing major or game breaking in my playthrough. There are still many things that could make this game better, but I still highly recommend Hogwarts Legacy to anyone who loves open world RPGs.

133826653.review:
Hopefully this will create a streak of great Potter games. This is a very good game, not without faults but solid overall. The story will keep you entertained for 32+ hours which in itself is a decent playtime. To me, it is easily worth a full price as it has already kept me entertained for a good amount of hours and I plan to grind some more completion percentage still. Keep in mind that not every game that comes out has to be a 10/10 or 1/10. Long story short, this is a perfectly fine 7/10, would recommend. 

Addressing the story first. I saw some complaints that it’s foolish that we start as a 5th year wonderchild. What exactly is wrong with that? Yes, we are sort of a “chosen one” character but that applies to nearly every game, movie or book protagonist in a fantasy genre. Also, I do not think that grinding through early years of Hogwarts as an eleven year old learning leviosa all day would make a premium gameplay. Setting the story in 1800 was a great move. So refreshing to play a Potter game without references to you-know-who. You can focus on an original story and don’t have to care about the books. As a drawback I would list that there was no morality system where using curses can actually have negative consequences. Casting Avada everywhere does not make anyone raise an eyebrow which is quite a shame.  Additionally our choices do not really matter all that much. Story sort of shows us why exactly are we special and is decent overall. Nothing spectacular just a fun, decent, entertaining story. 

Moving on, the combat. Spellcasting is extremely fun and satisfying. Keep in mind, this is not a Dark Souls game so it is pretty easy even on Hard. Combat is a casual yet fun experience with enemies being thrown, transmuted, ignited, slammed against the walls left and right. You can just fly to a bandit encampment and unleash hell. Fun and satisfying. Gear doesn’t really matter all that much, it is mostly cosmetic, there are Defense and Offense stats but you can finish the game without giving these too much thought, just equip higher stat and move on. 

Lastly, to keep this relatively brief, the world. There are basically two places in Hogwarts Legacy. The extremely alive, vibrant and well detailed Hogwarts and …. rest of the world. The rest of the world is just there to feed us some bandits and side quests. While the visuals are stunning outside and there is magic in flying on a broom or a mount above a snowy countryside, the world outside of Hogwarts lacks depth. The stores are open at night and some people seem to be active 24/7, it is your usual sandboxy open yet not very detailed world. There are a lot of typical sandbox repetivie side quests and activities i.e. solve a puzzle, kill X, save X, go to X etc. Hogwarts castle, however, is a world in itself, with students, ghosts and portraits running amok and secret doorways around every corner. The level of details the Hogwarts represent is stunning. I’ve already spent hours running around the castle just to explore and admire the effort the devs put into this part of the game. 

To sum up, decent story, fun and satisfying combat, visually stunning both inside the Hogwarts castle and outside on the countryside.

133820696.review:
Unlike a lot of other people, I had absolutely no expectations for this game. Actually, that's not entirely true, I had 1 expectation which was that I wasn't going to play Hogwarts Legacy. And no, I didn't hold that expectation because I couldn't bear the thought of playing a game loosely based on the works of a bigot, it was due to the simple unavoidable fact that I do not care about Harry Potter. Despite watching every single 1 of the I don't know, 5? or so movies and reading half a book, I never truly got it. It's just a wee lad magicking around, presumably in his imagination as he needs to escape the hellscape of his living situation under his uncle's stairs. Add to this the LEGO Harry Potter games not being anywhere near as good (IN MY OPINION) as the excellent Star Wars and Indiana Jones games, I was left in no way hyped for this game, and yes I know this isn't a LEGO game, which honestly minus points. 

After apparently entering some sort of trance and adding this game to my wishlist and then watching a friend play through some of the early sections I decided to buy it. After owning the game for only 12 days, I already have over 60 hours and 100% of the achievements. You really wouldn't think I have a full time job. I know J.K Rowling is getting a lot of hate lately and rightfully so but thank fuck she decided that Hogwarts would be in Scotland. This game really wouldn't be the same if it were in England, granted some areas of the country could be made to look pretty great, the world we get to explore throughout this game is truly spectacular and incredibly well designed. Also, having gone to school in England I know first hand that the character who's eyes we experience this game through would actually just have been bullied the entirety of their first year after joining school late. Actually, that would probably happen in Scotland as well, going to have to mark that down as a severe inaccuracy within this game. Why are all the students so nice to someone who shows up a few years late to school and generally just nails everything? Every time I wake up in the dorm room, I am expecting another black eye or maybe a lewd drawing on my forehead, but no.

After reading through the list of achievements, I expected I would need to complain about needing to reach the map room on all 4 houses, however as this only added an extra 3 hours of gametime, I didn't mind doing it, plus I got to do more Herbology lessons. Whilst on the topic of achievements, although I have no qualms with replaying the early levels, I really wish I didn't have to live through all of the Merlin Trials. Not because I found them too difficult, but due to the gall of Merlin forcing me to sit through 95 unskippable cutscenes. What a prick that man was, and truth be told I'm glad he's fucking dead. Even when I am stood on top of the centre of his little leaf outline, I do not appear in the cutscene, how self-important do you have to be? The world doesn't revolve around you Merlin, you fucking useless pile of bones, it revolves around the sun, maybe if you spent more time learning science instead of being a cunt you might have been able to notice that no one fucking likes you. At least I am only forced to see him being made out of leaves, because if I had to see his presumably hideous face NINETY FIVE times, I probably wouldn't have completed the game without prying out my eyes. Seriously, this guy makes me want an entire 9 hour storyline about the adventures of Peeves and Ignatia Wildsmith. That would be infinitely more enjoyable than hearing "Not so tricky after all, Merlin" one more fucking time.

I don't know if it was hidden within the digital deluxe version that I didn't pay for or maybe it is in an upcoming DLC, but I couldn't seem to find Dogwarts. Did this get cut or I just missed it? I thought it would be in the room of requirement but alas, 'twas only Deek and that would ruin my immersion.

The lack of quidditch didn't really phase me too much, because again, I don't care about Harry Potter.  Besides, the story and various side quests give you enough of an opportunity to become the best student at just about everything else so adding another thing to the list of activities the playable character naturally excels at would probably be overkill. I mean, you already get to beat Professor Ronen at Summoner's Court so there's not really a higher peak in that regard. The guy is practically a god, and I wholeheartedly believe that he let me win that game just to boost my pride. Obviously I am not saying that Ronen is truly some omnipotent being, I just mean he is fucking cracked at grabbing balls from across a big plank while in competition with children.

The story reminded me of the Mark Twain novel A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court, which for the uneducated is a fantastic read, and the subject of a wonderful 1949 film starring Bing Crosby. Now I'm not saying that the writers of this game copied from this book in any way, but their decision to make Merlin the primary villain of the game is a tad suspicious and should really be investigated as to where they came up with that idea. My word is Merlin a colossal waste of space. I hope he is not resting in peace but instead burning in hell like the evil piece of shit he is. I cannot stress this enough, NINETY FIVE UNSKIPPABLE CUTSCENES. It really puts Ranrok's crimes into perspective, I mean, what did the guy even do? Want a little bit more power so he could presumably enslave humanity? Big deal, were the machines truly the enemy in The Matrix Resurrections or was it the mere existence of the movie? At least I could skip that by never watching it, which isn't an option when it comes to Merlin's moon-sized fucking ego. I cannot believe when seeing the first Merlin trial completion I thought "huh, that was pretty cool" because after Merlin trial number 72 I was ready to shoot the cunt like he shot Hank Martin in A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court.

That prick aside, the characters in this game are very well written as well as the interactions the playable character has with each of them. It is a shame that at times you are forced into more linear storytelling as early on you can keep your experience with Fig a secret. Later in the game the character just blurts out to everyone that will listen that they can see and use ancient magic which completely negates the option of hiding this information from people in the first place. What if I don't want to trust everyone in Hogwarts?

Now onto one of the best aspects of this game, and no I am not referring to Professor Garlick, but of course the music beautifully composed by Chuck E. Myers, Peter Murray and J Scott Rakozy. You don't really need to know that they were influenced by the work of John Williams, because of course they were, he's the best. Just kidding, of course I'm talking about Professor Garlick. It really is a shame that this game isn't more like Bully with you regularly attending classes to improve your grades, but instead you attend probably under 10 classes in total with a handful of additional assignments. I think it would add to the enjoyment of the game to feature more time in the classroom but primarily because it would mean attending more Herbology classes and as a result getting more time with Professor Garlick. I don't think I really need to go into detail as to why getting to spend more time in that classroom would be a bonus. If the sequel to this game isn't the story of you playing the replacement for Professor Fig, and you get to spend the entire game attempting to seduce Professor Garlick, I will be severely disappointed. There are already far too many stories in the Wizarding World focusing on kids.

All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed this game, almost as much as I enjoyed writing this review and would have to place it firmly in my top 7 games on Steam. But seriously, fuck Merlin and everything he stood for.

133819821.review:
Hogwarts legacy is a solid 9/10 in almost all regards that a fan of the Harry Potter universe might want from a game set in that world. 

There are some technical issues but none (in my experience) game breaking or disrupting and these are the kind that usually get iron out within a few months of launch. Additionally I don't know anything about whatever controversy people are riled up about but frankly with the amount of scandals in the gaming industry these days I'm just too tired to care and I'm not gonna let people being people get in the way of me having a good time in the fantasy world I like.

So about the actual game. Hogwarts castle and surrounding areas are rendered beautifully. It's a nearly transition free open world on foot or broom or beast and engaging with the game feels smooth at all times. There's a good number of Red Dead Redemption style open world set-pieces to make it all come alive and you can visit most of your favourite spots from the books/movies in one way or another. Combat isn't too challenging but it does have a good amount of variety which is a sweet spot for me. Professors giving you game tutorials feels a little weird and I wish that was laid out in text and masked more but it is very helpful to figure how everything works. The story is... Fine, a bit of a mish mash of things that were good in the book stories to capitalize on that IP but really the game is about the world you get to explore and it truly excels in that regards.

Now add a Quidditch DLC (Yeah you can't play quidditch in this game), fix the technical hitches and you have yourself a 10/10 title

133818956.review:
I just finished this game.

[u]Good things:[/u]
- Character customization is pretty good
- Graphics and animation
- Voice acting
- The story for the most part was enjoyable and captivating. Sometimes I found I could not pull away
- Ample side activities to fill in your free time as you explore
- Attention to detail is astonishing. Everything we saw in the movies is there. Moving pictures, statues, ghosts, you name it.
- Random things sometimes happen as you explore, even if they become old after seeing it more than five times.
- We can pet chain-smoker cats!
- You can keep pets (beasts) and brush them, feed them.
- Gear customization caters to the player's personal preference and does not force you to look like a clown that just left the circus as you wear the strongest gear you could find. You can choose the look of any outfit you found so far on any gear.
- Large open world to explore
- Combat isn't like Dark Souls. Controls are easy to learn, combat isn't overdone, which serves to make you feel powerful.
- Some side-quests are actually quite enjoyable and captivating

-------------------------

[u]Now the bad things:[/u]
- The developers say that you can choose to be a good or evil wizard. Thing is, with no morality system in place, this is simply a lie. NPCs couldn't care less about you blasting combat spells around them, or picking the lock to their house, steal the stuff of a family sitting by the table, or whichever choice you make at the end. None of these matter. Not even the options you pick in dialogues. The story is as it is.

- The attention to detail is indeed astonishing but it is clear they focused too much on this and not on other aspects of gameplay, like allowing our character to live in the world they are put in. You cannot even sit down in a chair, sleep in your bed, eat with the other students in the Great Hall, no curfew. No interaction at all. You simply exist in the game but don't live.

- There are a lot of side activities indeed and the map is full of them. But there are the same 6 or so types you can do like 50 times. Good luck completing them.

- Ending is a let down. Without spoilers... It doesnt matter what you do, what you choose, what you say... Nothing matters. The ending is meh. Not at all fulfilling. No consequence, no difference. It almost seems like it is incomplete.

-------------------------

All in all, I did enjoy playing it. But the lack of morality system, the lack of consequences or changes to the plot or flavor of the game depending on your choices was ruining it. Still, I give it a thumbs up because it gave me a good time. I just wish they would have spent less time on the castle and more on developing gameplay.

How to classify this game? Very mediocre and good at being mediocre. Wait for a sale. 

A solid 6/10. Does many thinks okay, a few well but nothing stands out that makes me want to come back to the game, or even finish it. 

The world building is great, I genuinely felt like I was at Hogwarts and everything worked well together, this is because the graphics and sound and music in the game are spectacular. 

The game works with linux and the steam deck right out of the box. Which honestly is wothy of a point all by itself. 

The story is okay at best, how am I supposed to believe I am the protagonist when I'm going around killing mass droves of goblins and "dark wizards" as a 5th year Hogwarts student? It doesn't make any sense. It's explained away with mediocre story telling and plot.  The game itself is not that enjoyable. You're a Hogwarts student who barely spends any time in class and the teachers are somehow okay with that. The plot elements are long, drawn out and there's just not enough to keep me interested or entertained. It's just OKAY at best.  There's a lot of elements in the game that mark lazy or bad story telling. Like having a room in the castle thaty you can keep beasts in so they mate together and you can sell their offspring for mad profits so you can better equip you're character to go murdering scores of goblins. It's all not believable. I found myself saying "REALLY?!" more than anything else. 

The combat is okay at best too. There's really only 4 enemy types, wolves, spiders, humanoids, trolls. They all share very general attack animations and attack types, and the goblins and dark wizards are really just a re-skin. There's not enough complexity to keep anyone interesting, the camera angles make combat more frustrating than it should be. 

The sounds and graphics in the game are great, it helped with the immersion into the game and I enjoyed it. 

The puzzles in the game are more annoying than they are interesting and lack any sort of cleverness or way to keep you interested in solving it. 

I sit back and my time with this game I had more negative things to say about this game than good. I'll probably finish it (at some point) but I grew disinterested rather quickly and there's not enough in the game to really make me want to come back and finish it.

First off, I as a member of the trans community felt incredibly guilty buying this game that I had been wanting for so long. But I had to know what it was like. So I tanked the guilt and played it and I gotta say… Not worth it. 

It’s a beautiful setting, with a lot of stellar programming on making the world effectively magical. But once you get to the choices and story, it kind of falls apart. Your choices matter very little. It was like playing a ghost, moving through the world without feeling like I was affecting it. There were some great characters, whose stories intersected mine, but I never got to change the outcome of those stories. Especially with Sebastian. (Also what happened with the “Slytherin doesn’t mean evil” that I was expecting?) If these were my friends, surely I should be able to talk them through or out of bad situations. Like in Mass Effect or Cyberpunk. But no. I was merely an all powerful golden child lead character, who followed along the plot like someone was dragging me by the nose. 

Outside of the story, the combat was pretty great, but the rest of the gameplay was bogged down with fetch quests, collectible hunting, and crafting. Things that have gotten really old and boring by this point. Aside from the occasional entertaining puzzle, it was a by the numbers big budget action adventure. And I’m sorry to all the developers who were responsible for those bright spots where the game shined. Because they really did a great job in places. But it wasn’t enough to make this game the epic experience that we were promised. Even if you take out the fact that buying it contributes to the absolutely awful transphobe Rowling.

133862213.review:
LOWER END SYSTEMS:
I'm only 20-30 hours in, but the game is extremely unoptimized at the moment for lower end systems. I'm using a 1660Ti, 32GB ram, and without "performance mods / fixes", the game crashes every 10-15 minutes (ie: you have to install Ascendio from nexus mods, modify the Engine.ini & CChromaEditorLibrary64.dll, turn on GPU "Hardware Accelerated GPU Scheduling", & change some Nvidia Global Settings). After the above performance fixes, the game (mostly) stops crashing, but I have to run it on 720p, with AMD 2 Upscale, Good Preset, (RTX off obviously). Anything higher, and the game crashes every 10-15 minutes again. Every time the game updates, I have to reinstall the performance mods. Denuvo DRM continually runs in the background, in short it scans your system looking for any tampering in the game files. Empress (a cracker) who recently removed Denuvo DRM completely, showed the game jumped another 20-30fps. For those of you running the game at 120+ fps, this is negligible, But I barely run the game on 20fps. It constantly stutters during cutscenes, and when loading new scenes. 

Don't get me wrong, I've really enjoyed the game post-fixes, the world is beautiful, and feels far more expansive than the movies, and for any Harry Potter fan -- it's nothing short of a childhood dream come true. But I would not recommend the game right now, or at full price. There's many other issues like the female models all use a copy-pasted Male animation rigs & weights, causing unexpected results, like the female models grimacing, making malicious, witch like faces in-game (Google it), and running around like a hooligan with no grace or femininity at all. There's no White / Pale Caucasian or Black skin tones, it starts from tan & ends at a dark brown. All these bugs are listed on the Hogwarts DB and will potentially be worked on in future, but modders seem to be addressing them way faster than developers are. I'd say give it 6-12 months and wait for a sale, hopefully WB removes Denuvo, and the game is in a much optimised state after updates & fixes. Otherwise, we're going to have to rely on the modding community to better the game. I will amend this review once the game is in a better place and I only discourage it in it's current state, and on lower end systems.  

P.s If you have a higher end system, have FOMO / fear of missing out, and want to talk about it with friends, by all means get it.

133861306.review:
Well.... After finishing the game, I'm disappointed. I've waited for it to shine but the more I followed the plot, the worse it got.

The plot is a huge pile of cliches. Hey, devs, can we stop making overly epic games about chosen ones in 2023 please? Once again, you're special, there's some ancient secret, you need to face trails to open some ancient vault and there those who want to take this power and use it for evil purposes. Serioulsly, so lame. Seen it dozens of times. Villains lack screen time dramatically. You barely see them throughout the game after the first quest and until the very end of the game. Your fellow students and teachers are no better tbh. Side quests are mostly garbage that you won't ever remember. Only Sebastian's questline somehow stands out. But it could have been better too. Oh and yes, it's all linear. There will be almost no choices and exactly zero consequences.

Overall I have a strong feeling that devs tried to shove every single activity from HP franchise into the game. And they failed to make any of it deep and entertaining. The game tries to be everything and remind you about all the movies. But it's just reminders.

If they wanted a game about Hogwarts similar to early HP books/movies, they should have focused on studies in school, building relationship with friends, some school rivalry like with Malfoy, cosy time in common rooms, sneaking around the castle at night, quiddich, house cup etc. And the plot needed to be more down-to-earth. And currently with all this open world stuff it all feels odd. Nobody cares if you attend classes, nobody cares if you're in your bedroom at night (or slaying goblins miles away from the castle). You can spend all time out of Hogwarts for almost entire game and it doesn't really matter. The game doesn't have the vibe from early books/movies.

If they wanted a wizarding world adventure game with cool magic fights and open world, they should have made an adult protagonist and probably even remove Hogwarts. Currently a 5th year student that just started his magic education and can already kill 10 dark wizards in battle feels out-of-place. Overall too much fighting is weird for a game about Hogwarts student.

Now to good things:

Hogwarts is visually amazing. You can literally spend hours exploring it in search for locations from the movies. And you'll recognize them right away when you find them. It's very nostalgic.

Battles are alright and even fun. Even at the end I stopped sometimes to clear a camp of wizards/goblins. Unfortunately, there are not so many enemy types. Diffiiculty is also a bit lacking. I played on hard and hardly ever needed buff potions or things like Mandragora.

Room of requirements and magic creatures are pretty cool. The only problem that it's not needed unless you just want to do a bit of farming activities. You need collectibles from these creatures to upgrade your equipment but it's just for numbers, so it's pretty boring. And you'll do just fine without upgrades.

So it's a big piece of fanservice for HP fans. I'm a fan too, so I liked many of it. But as a game it's mediocre and I don't think I'll ever re-play it.

133847408.review:
This was a promising game that I approached with an Open-Mind. I personally have only ever briefly read the books as a child, and have never watched a Harry Potter movie. I can say for certain that this was a very mediocre game, if it wasn't for the fact that it was in the Harry Potter world it would have bombed with negative reviews.

My plan was to 100% complete this game to give a proper review, however I simply couldn't bring myself to complete repetitive Merlin trials, bandit camps, loot rooms-All copy and pasted mind you, nearly every single one of them. Most of the side-quests lacked world building, excitement, or even entertainment for that. The 3 main side-quests tied to achievements however I enjoyed very much, such as Sebastion's quest line, Poppy's quest line, and Natsai's quest line.

The story for me was a 7/10 it wasn't bad, but I simply wish I had more control over what happened in the world. The feeling of choice was extremely lacking in this world, and the fact that I could use certain spells and not have consequences tied to them. The voice acting on the part of the main character you control is god awful, I couldn't tell if it was a real person or AI-Generated, simply boring voice work.

The developers put 90% of their effort into building the world/environment, and 10 percent on everything else combined. The graphics in my opinion are also lack-luster. Looking at other games released before its time, it's optimization and graphics in general felt 2015 era. Not in all cases however, the world and game is beautiful regardless of that.

The combat on the other-hand is okay, however the fact that trolls and bigger enemies, can TELEPORT to you across the arena to hit you in an instant without you being able to react to it is INSANE. IM A WIZARD... SO HOW CAN A BIG MOB TELEPORT TO ME WHEN I TELEPORT DASH AWAY?

Apologies if this review is all over the place, I may change my review in time depending how this game's DLC and future look. But for now it will stay negative. People need to stop allowing game developers to half-ass games, especially on a franchise as big and beloved as Harry Potter. 

TL;DR 
Lack-Luster game design, gameplay, copy and pasted quests/locations/characters, Lazy voice acting and build design. Not worth 60$.

133843723.review:
Hi Friends Hogwarts Legacy on its own if I were not comparing it to other games is a great game; however like many of you I've played tons of hours on open world games and I can say while it's great I dont believe its worth the $60 Price tag.

-The World it's set in is beautiful. The things in the world (Puzzles, caves, bandit camps, etc.) feel really empty, like a heavily watered down Skyrim, the things you interact with feel mundane and repetitive.

-The Combat is mildly interesting. It's like an EZ mode Elden ring, it does get a little repetitive and I don't think any of the fights were really all that challenging or rewarding to be victorious.

-The Talents skill tree in general feels lackluster at best with some of the options being things that should be included in base kit; the talents in general don't really feel that impactful to the game. The potions and herbology mechanics feel hollow in this same way.

- The Rewards are probably my biggest gripe, you could spend hours being a completionist getting all the various side quests, collections, explorations done and your rewards will generally be a mediocre cosmetic (Here's a Cool Shelf) for your room of requirements. Sometimes the only reward is a steam achievement but almost none of it will be anything that impacts your game play.

- The Story is fun. It reads like a book, (A Very Campy Book) your decisions don't really have all that many consequences and the dialog options don't really impact very much aside from a few lines and maybe your ability to learn the dark arts. The game makes you feel like you're about to make an impactful decision but in the end the result is almost always the same.

- The Gameplay took me about 30 hours to get through the main quest and about 20 more to go through all of the side quests. I don't understand how anyone could claim this has more than 100 hours of gameplay even if you did all of the empty meaningless collections there's no way it's more than 80. I dont Think I'll ever pick this game up again after having finished it,

- In Review they got me to buy it through my love of harry potter and if you're buying it for that reason I would recommend it. If you're buying it because you want to play a great open world RPG I would recommend waiting for the price to come down as it doesn't hold a candle to several open world games.

This game is a YES BUT.
I'd recommend it, only at a discount tho.
