133832027.review:
Here are the positives:

The game looks great, has a wonderful atmosphere and the combat feels like a fun power trip. Exploring Hogwarts is wondrous and flying around with your broom is the bees knees. Playing wizard/witch dress-up is also fun.

And for the negatives:

The core game is very, very shallow. Every single "rpg"- mechanic in this game is a half baked. 95% of the time you get underleveled gear and the models are dupes so no new transmog. Choices don't matter much at all, the story plays the same whatever you choose to do/say. The story is interesting at certain points but the pacing is sluggish and because of the illusion of choice it doesn't really change at all because of your actions. There is no Quidditch and you can't really score house points. At the end of the game you just get rewarded the generic 100 house points and win the house cup automatically. Bummer.

The world is quite large but the lack of variety really brings it down (the puzzles, the potions, the spells, offensive items, enemies and the creatures lack variety/purpose).  You don't get any new offensive items like wands so it narrows the reward pool down significantly. This means exploration is worthless 80% of the time. You can cast unforgivable curses without nobody batting an eye. Tried to be the most evil slytherin prick and at the end i was greeted as a hero.

The game also tries to introduce new systems and mechanics till the half point, but nothing new comes on the table after that.

This is the "definite Harry Potter game", but it's still a mid tier open world game with (very light) rpg mechanics. For the content that is here it would've worked better as a 20 hour semi-open world Potter- game, not as a 100 hour open world exploring snooze fest.

I regret paying full price for the Deluxe Edition. These lazy niflers at Portkey Games and WB stole my effing galleons, yo

133825643.review:
I fear the game is lacking on to many ends to be recommendable. 
tl;dr 
+ great castle design - absolutley the best part of the game
- bad skill bar system
- boring fights
- very bad/ annoying item system
- irrelevant crafting system


Hogwarts Castle is by far the best part of the game - it's simply amazing to explore this labyrinth. The design of the castle is stunning!
However that cannot make up for the lack of the rest of the game. The facial expressions are simply wrong most of the time - the world is in great danger, your life is threatend and your avatar is basicly smiling and grining all the time. 
The fighting system is shit, every fight feels like the one before. The skill bars with only 4 skills each are clearly designed for consoles, for PC they are simply a joke. It feels realy clumsy to fight with these and also you have to swap skills every now and than, as there are only enouth slots to fit the fight skills, but if you have to repair, light, summon items or interact with animals for quests quite often. 
The map looks like it is overrun by  goblins but hardly anybody is taking notice. The story is also lacking imho.
Treasures are totally irrelevant, as chests are everywhere and the reward is mostly crap. Tombs, caves, riddles and so on are very generic so you know know most of it within 30 min exploring the map outside of Hogwarts (if you have the basic skills at least) The item system is annoying - you have to run to the traiders very often so sell crap, or destroy it so you have slots free when you find better gear. But you don't know what it is before you pick it up. And the process of removing items is driving off, so I startet skipping chests. 
Last but not least the crafting system is mostly irrelevant. Apart from potions you don't need anything apart from quest. You get it all in an infinit amount when you use seeds. Hardly any ingredients need to be farmed.

133823105.review:
This game is a wonderful experience, very fun to play and has a fantastic progression model, you get things slow, so you have time to play/learn how to use them. The cosmetic stuff is ridiculous and very cool at the same time. You can at almost any time make yourself look how you want to, which is a very nice touch, imo. Combat is engaging and the story develops in a very fun way (the parts I got to, at least). Combat can get a little repetitive, but in a way that still makes you have to pay attention and flip through your spells to keep on top of the bad dudes.

I'm giving this a thumbs down because there was some update that happened somewhere between February 16-18, I took a break for a few days to play some other games during that time. This update corrupted my 57 hour playthrough, along with many other people and I am not wanting to go back through the grind of everything I did. I spent a decent amount of time trying to follow some steps to recover my game file, but none of the guides were helpful. I absolutely would have played through a 2nd time, maybe more, I don't know, but this left a really sour taste in my mouth and I tried again today 2/28/23, to see if the Devs addressed this, and nope. So, the lack of care there makes me quite disinterested. I may come back at a later date, but, that was a lot of time lost for no reason.

Hopefully this doesn't happen to anyone else, but this was my experience.

133870932.review:
Moin Moin, meine Freunde der gepflegten Zauberkunst!

Nach 72 Stunden ingame Zeit und ganzen 106h auf Steam wurde das Spiel erfolgreich beendet, nun zur Review:

Die Graphik von Hogwarts und Umgebung ist sehr gut gelungen und wunderschön geworden, es steckt sehr viel zum Detail und jeder Harry Potter Fan wird viele Sachen wiedererkennen und sich darüber dezent erfreuen, nur manche Texturen von kleinen Objekten in Läden lassen zu wünschen übrig.

Das Kampfsystem macht sehr viel Spaß, zu viel, denn warum sollte ich schleichen und mir den fun nehmen, einen Zauberduell aus dem Weg zu gehen? Es gibt viele Möglichkeiten seinen eigenen Kampfstil zu adaptieren, vorallem mit den Talenten.

Die Mainstory ist ganz gut, jedoch wird sie von den vielen Nebenquests komplett in den Schatten gestellt. Das Spiel schafft es immer wieder sich selbst zu übertreffen, immer wenn man denkt "Geiler wirds nimmer!" kommt irgendwas neues um die Ecke und stellt es in den Schatten.

Jetzt zu den negativen Punkten:

-Performance, die Mindestanforderungen sind kein Witz und manchmal gibt es extreme FPS Drops und Ruckler

-die Map, sowohl das Design als auch die allgemeine Steuerung wurde von Praktikanten erstellt

-Das die Schnellreisepunkte reden, schädigt ab einen Punkt die mentale Gesundheit des Spielers exponentiell, BITTE SEI RUHIG


Zusammenfassend: Das wahrscheinlich beste Openworld Game welches ich gespielt hab, eine eindeutige Empfehlung für jeden der Singleplayer games mag, endlich mal wieder ein Spiel mit Herz. 

9,5/10 für Muggel, für alle anderen: addiert einfach wie sehr ihr Harry Potter liebt

N'étant pas un fan d'Harry Potter, ce jeu ne m'attirait pas forcément au départ. Puis au final, c'est vraiment bien. Je m'amuse réellement à explorer un univers qui m'est inconnu, et je trouve que la magie donne un vent de fraîcheur aux jeux vidéo, puisque nous sommes tous habitué aux fameux épées/bouclier. Par contre, je trouve certaines quêtes secondaires très "Ubisoft" (va chercher telle chose et reviens me la donner, trouve 30 lunes de demiguises pour au final ne rien avoir à la fin) et le loot devient tellement inintéressant et répétitif que je n'avais aucune envie de continuer à chercher des coffres. Pour continuer dans les points négatifs, les chutes de frame rates tous les 5 minutes parce que tu ouvres une porte à Poudlard, ce n'est pas top, et beaucoup trop présent pour ceux avec une mid config comme moi.

Bref, je conseille le jeu aux fans de l'univers ou à ceux qui ont envie de se lancer dans un univers extraordinaire, mais ne vous attendez pas à mieux niveau open world qu'un monde d'Ubisoft, parce que c'est exactement la même chose.

133869859.review:
Antes que nada, voy a dejar las polémicas a parte. Ya cada cual que valore sus opiniones propias y actúe en consecuencia. 
Dicho esto, el juego. Yo no soy muy fan de Harry Potter. Y debería, soy del tonto que siempre se pilla el mago en todas partes y el único alelao que todavía juega mago arcano en el WoW. Pero por alguna razón, la trama, seguramente, Harry Potter no me llama mucho, así que iba a dejar pasar este juego pero, por cosas del destino, he acabado jugando. Y menos mal. 
Es un juegazo, pero de largo. Y la historia, aún sin ser tampoco un Last of Us o un Final Fantasy VII, es buena. En mi opnión, hasta mejor que la de los libros y pelis de la saga homónima. Quiero decir, pequeño spoiler, hay una misión en la que destapas una trama de lucha ilegal de dragones. Aquí llevamos al clásico personaje de RPG genérico niño, niña o niñe (chúpate esa, Rowlings) que ni sabe ni entiende de que va la fiesta, pero por aquello de ser el elegid@ puede contra un ejército de magos oscuros, se come a los trolls de dos en dos y se hace a un dragón antes del desayuno, mientras sigue de forma rigurosa su carrera académica en Hogwarts y cuida sus pokémon. 
La jugabilidad, ya sea volando en escoba, en grifo, pegándose con magos, duendes o intentando salvar el pellejo contra infestaciones de arañas gigantes (y cuando arañas, digo arañas, y cuando digo gigantes, digo gigantes, ojo si como yo padeces de aracnofóbia, lo vas a pasar mal) o practicando magia en las clases, es la leche. El combate a varita va mucho más allá de "¡Flipendo!" de aquellos juegos de Harry Potter de la plei y tiene combos, parry y al menos dos docenas de hechizos que usar para hacer de todo a tus rivales, desde hacerlos volar, machacarles la cabeza, prenderlos en llamas, torturarlos, dejarlos secos con el rayo de la muerte o convertirlos en un jarrón (literalmente). El nivel de personalización del personaje está bastante bien, sobre todo con las ropitas, hay cien mil abrigos, togas, máscaras, sobreros y pantalones o faldas que puedes vestir en varias combinaciones muy vistosas y majas. 
Los gráficos son óptimos, y el nivel de detalle del mundo es enfermizo, un deleite para los fans de la saga, sin duda. El housing es magnífico (si, tiene housing) y si acaso, falla algo en los diálogos, donde apenas hay opciones reales. Y en que no hay furbo con escoba. 
Si eres fan de la saga, ni lo dudes. Si no lo eres, igual tampoco lo dudes mucho. Yo no soy muy fan y lo estoy disfrutando como un gorrino en una charca.

133869755.review:
+Einige Aspekte von Witcher 3, wie heutzutage häufig oder auch Star Wars Fallen Order übernommen (beide Spiele empfand ich als sehr gut), sehr detailreich und grafisch stark, extrem viel zum Sammeln und kleinere Rätsel, ob Harry Potter Nerd oder Neuling, für beide Gruppen gut spielbar. Ordentliche Anzahl an Quests, man hat immer was zu tun, Tierwesen ganz nices Feature, wobei diese Gestaltung des Raumes der Wünsche für mich eher irrelevant war. Kampfsystem ist gut, aber könnte besser, die vielen verschiedenen Zaubersprüche sind nice, vor allem, dass auch die Flüche dabei sind.

133869600.review:
Je ne recommande pas ce jeu.

C'est le premier jeu que j'achète dès sa sortie, sans même regarder les avis, ça sera aussi le dernier.
Je ne suis pas fan de HP mais ma nostalgie a voulu me replonger dans cet univers que j'avais beaucoup apprécié. Malheureusement, à part la représentation fidèle du château, il n'y a pour moi pas grand chose d'autre de bien. 

Attention SPOIL :

- L'histoire est inintéressante, les personnages également. Le fait d'arriver en 5ème année est dommage, en fait si vous vous attendez à suivre des cours, vivre comme un étudiant à Poudlard : c'est raté. Les cours sont à peine vus, on fait tout pour vous faciliter la tâche pour que les sorts soient appris vite.

- Les combats sont toujours les mêmes, pas d'originalité ou de style vraiment particulier à adopter : vous lancerez des sorts principalement. Pourtant l'univers de HP offre un potentiel fou en terme de gameplay. Mais si vous souhaitez jouer métamorphose, potions, invocations... c'est raté. Les monstres à attaquer sont peu nombreux et n'ont aucune particularité distinctive (que ce soit araignées ou serpencendres, le combat sera presque le même), 

- Les objectifs secondaires sont toujours pareils : les épreuves de Merlin sont ennuyeuses, les quêtes secondaires aussi... j'ai eu plus de fun en me baladant dans le château à la recherche de petits détails cachés à débloquer.

- On a la possibilité d'être bon ou mauvais, mais à vrai dire ça ne change rien à la finalité du jeu. 

- Les habits et accessoires à porter pour avoir plus de stats sont juste AFFREUX ! Voir mon personnage et ses grosses lunettes à œil de serpent/dragon pendant une cinématique relativement triste m'a complètement sorti du jeu, c'est un détail mais c'est dommage.

- Aucun rappel de l'univers de HP : à part les endroits emblématiques, on ne nous parle jamais des personnages clés de l'histoire d'HP. Ici le grand méchant est un gobelin, ce qui à mes yeux est ridicule contrairement à la réussite du personnage de Voldemort, les profs sont peu importants...

En fait tout est relativement insipide d'après moi. Même les dragons ne me hypaient pas plus que ça car on ne les voit que dans les cinématiques, tout comme l'élevage d'animaux qui est pour moi plus une corvée que quelque chose d'amusant. C'est peu varié et dynamique ; c'est dommage, car vraiment le jeu n'est pas si loin d'un bon jeu, surtout graphiquement parlant !

133868704.review:
Let's be clear, this is no 'Masterpiece'. It's not a 10/10 game. It's not perfect. But! It is a fun game, and a lot of heart was poured into it.

Just from spending the first 15 minutes in the game (assuming you're not still desperately trying to customize your character to the best of your abilities), you can probably tell whoever worked on this game is at the very least nostalgic, or appreciative of JK Rowling's 20-year old franchise. You could definitely say that based on the recent chain of abysmal what-should-have-been-direct-to-trash-dvds, there's at least someone who somewhat understands what made the Wizarding World great - it's attention to confusingly stupid but overall interesting lore.

There are weird creatures, spells that are way too devastating to teach to teens, and insane, childish factions and faction leaders that hold too much power and very little brain capacities, which is exactly where all the fun lies. You'll encounter so many OSHA violations within Hogwarts and its surrounding to make a lawyer's day a good one, and it's where this insane silliness and pure chaotic potential that meet and make this a fun world to explore. The attention to details from the needlessly many media projects is there, and it's glorious.

But aside from the fan-service, references, and funny details, what does this game give us?

Well, for starters, there's a peculiar spell system that allows you to make your wizard (or witch) spew devastating combos that would fling your enemies around and make short work of any dark wizard or evil monster that would dare cross their paths with you.
There're also lackluster RPG elements, where instead of being able to build your character towards a certain offensive, stealthy, or utility builds, your character, for the most part, will end up looking the same after 40 levels, although I would assume most players would stop playing after reaching level 37 or so. I applaud the attempt, but the time I spent rescuing a beast I did not need to rescue, or delving down a dungeon that didn't really feel interesting enough to warrant the effort to go down it... all that could have been redirected towards a better RPG experience within the world that was so lovingly crafted. It's a bit of a waste if you ask me.

Yes, dear reader, after about 40 hours this game suffers from what most Ubisoft games suffer as well - a large map that offers too much of the same thing. If the devs scaled back on the pointless collectible stuff, we probably could have gotten better character interactions and more in-depth character builds.

Oh! The story! What could I say about it? I remember only one story line, the one that actually has something interesting happen in it, and you know what? It's not even the main one. I feel like if the writers spent more time generating fanfics for houses other than Slytherin, we could have gotten more interesting plot points. Without spoiling anything - the stories are meh at best, aside from that Slytherin side plot, which is somewhat predictable, but shocking nonetheless.

Well. There's that. I could go more into details about the Room of Requirement, but I don't feel like it was really that necessary - it added an odd farmville minigame on top of what is otherwise a decent open world action game. That include the pet rescuing and item upgrade/improvement system which was... okay? You could honestly finish the game without worrying too much about materials, support items, or your petting zoo.

Alright. That's it, right?

Whoops, almost forgot that this game lines JK's pockets, so there's THAT elephant in the room. So, I guess I have to address it, right?

Well, I happen to be Jewish. Have been for a good 30+ years, and I don't plan on stopping now. From what I experienced I saw no antisemetic propaganda of any kind. Sorry chaverim sheli, but I just can't seem to what the fuss was all about, at least in that regard. Of course, if you dislike Rowling and don't want to line her pockets, that's your choice! I fully support you on that decision, and more power to you - but that specific notion is unrelated to how much fun I had with the game, and, for the most part, I had more good time than I had a bad time.

Final Score: 7.5/10 - It COULD have been better, but I'm satisfied with what I've got.

133868631.review:
[b]Ah, sí... el revelio simulator. [/b] Las primeras horas son muy entretenidas mientras te mantenés en los terrenos del castillo y de Hogsmeade, está lleno de detalles y ataques de nostalgia. Abrís el mapa y ves que tenés un montón de terreno todavía por descubrir y te emociona. Pero una vez que salís a descubrir el mapa te das cuenta que es todo repetitivo, ningún misterio ni secreto por descubrir, solamente coleccionables y desafíos de Merlin que se tornan en una tarea tediosa de hacer si querés platinar el juego.

La historia principal no tiene nada especial, tenés que frenar a Ranrok, el líder extremista de una rebelión goblin, que quiere aprovechar el poder de la magia antigua (magia que aparentemente es más fuerte/especial que la magia común y solamente tu personaje y algunos pocos más pueden usar). No hay nada profundo, ni conflictos morales ahí. La línea de quests secundarias de Sebastian Sallow tiene más profundidad que la quest principal.

Tus elecciones no tienen ningún impacto, salvo en el destino de Sebastian Sallows (creo que es la única vez). Así que el juego podría no tener opciones de dialogo y seria exactamente lo mismo en cuanto a la historia. El único motivo por el que creo que podrían haber puesto opciones de dialogo es si querés sonar más bueno o "malo".
Podes usar o no magia oscura/imperdonable, no tiene importancia, no afecta en nada, al final del juego tu personaje va a haber masacrado a más humanos y goblins que cualquier otro mago que haya existido, sin que alguien haga un comentario al respecto.

Los gráficos y la ambientación son hermosos. Ninguna crítica ahí.

Los puzzles se ven entretenidos, lástima que tu propio personaje te spoilea la solución siempre. Es frustrante, te roba entretenimiento y ese momento de [i]"aha!"[/i]. Una vez fui a abrir un cofre que estaba justo antes de una sala de puzzle, y mi personaje me dijo la solución incluso antes de entrar a la sala.

El combate es entretenido, aunque no muy difícil. Lo mismo pasa con las carreras de escobas, estaría bueno si tuviera más desafíos para ambos.

Le doy 6 revelios de 10... y un revelio honorífico por Ominis.

L'étiquette "Harry Potter" est fantastique les premières heures, mais passé le charme le jeu en lui même est très bof.

En bref:
-L'exploration devient rapidement ennuyante puisqu'on ne le fait que pour ouvrir des coffres à cosmétiques qui sont très nombreux.
-Les énigmes sont beaucoup trop facile/répétitive/nombreuses pour être agréable et relèvent plutôt du rituel. 
Notre personnage est creux, n'a aucune histoire ni personnalité.
-Les quêtes/tutoriels sont écrits avec beaucoup de paresse. Il y aura sans arrêt un PNJ pour vous tenir par la main et vous expliquer ce que vous devez faire, là où il y aurai eu matière à créer des scénarios sympa. (Je pense notamment à l'accès à la salle sur demande). Mais de manière générale les quêtes ne sont pas mémorables.
-Poudlard sert de zone tutoriel pendant les premières heures, mais très vite on n'y met plus vraiment les pieds pour aller tuer des gredins et aider les villageois avec leurs problèmes personnels. Les combats sont très sympa et offrent quelques libertés de style, mais on devrait pas plutôt être en cours ? Peut-être qu'il aurait fallu faire un jeu dans l'univers HP sans jouer un élève, ça aurait été plus cohérent et évité les attentes qui vont avec le fait de jouer un "apprenti sorcier à Poudlard".

J'avais envie de finir le jeu rapidement même si je reconnais qu'il a son charme.

133876194.review:
Overall, excellent game if you like the Harry Potter universe. My initial play through was filled with wonder and joy. This is the game Potter fans have been waiting for…

Strengths
True to the spirit of the Potter universe. Graphically, it is beautiful even if there is some optimization work still to be done and the usual initial launch glitches.

The plot works well within the universe, and establishes a foundation for a franchise that can last many years with huge potential for DLC and follow on releases. It would be great if they followed in Mass Effect/Witcher footsteps and provided for the import of saved characters from one game into the next.

I appreciate the less rigid morality tied to (use of) the unforgiveable curses or at least hope that is the developers’ intent.

I loved the combat system and the dueling challenges for each baddie which essentially teach you how to vanquish all foes. It was challenging both as a new player in a normal run, and as an experienced player in hard mode.

Weaknesses
Character customization is severely limited and oddly bland. I ended up using the same model for each play through, tweaking only hair style and eye color because essentially, that’s all you can do to your selected head model although there are a couple of dozen to choose from. I find this a curious approach given that the Hogwarts Legacy world is beautiful, except for the people in it.

Relationship quests aren’t terribly meaningful and I found them for the most part superficial. Neither the MC nor supporting characters are developed to any real depth. Essentially you’re the chosen one with no backstory, doing the hero’s journey. 

In brief moments along the way, you make one friend from Wakanda, one from PETA, and one who possesses the emotional control of a six year-old. When you find out that’s who they are, you’ve discovered all there is to know about them. There is no more.  I liked Natty best but spent so little time with her.

Alohomora should not be a puzzle after achieving level 3. Even in hard mode, this puzzle isn’t challenging and the repetitiveness of it makes it non-canon and tedious. 

It was disappointing that if I needed equipment upgrade supplies or potion ingredients, there are vendors from which to buy them, but once I was overrun with these items, I couldn’t sell them and make some extra coin. Given that, the expensive cost of buying them and virtual worthlessness of them once you have too many makes no sense. On the other hand, I sold a couple of hundred (thousand?) critters off and got paid the same price regardless of how difficult they were to catch, or how many I had sold previously. 

The part I liked the least was the linearity of acquiring spells. Yes, you can get some spells through side quests as soon as you trip the requirements, but the major spells are all main quest driven, no matter what side of the good/bad arc your character rests. 

If you’re paying attention, the main quest isn’t terribly long – but you are driven to doing side quests if you want the full spell battery and all the fetch missions if you want max level. Hogwarts Legacy’s experience/leveling system is dependent on these fetch missions, which bulks up the play time, but in the end has an ample portion of grind to it.

All in all, I loved it, and immediately started my second play through after completing my first. It’s a strong foundation, and here is to hope that WB Games builds on it.

133928564.review:
Very good game for its story, graphics, music, ambience, easter eggs, fan service and combat gameplay. It is also lore friendly. It has a good longevity (I beat it 100% in ~100h on hard difficulty with all collectibles). However, the game is far from perfect and not exempt of issues.

- Secondary quests that are not companions one or treasure maps are very forgettable fetch quests.
- No quidditch mini game, it's a shame for a game set in the Harry Potter universe.
- It is barely an RPG game, more like an open world action game, quests are very linear, with meaningless choices. Weak NPCs interactivities. Also, there is no morality system. This leads to poor replayability.
- Itemization is among the worst I have seen in a game like this, just random gear with random stats, nothing exciting.
- Some activities are too repetitive like Merlin's tasks.
- Game is missing some QOL improvements, in exemples, transmogrification only applies to items and not gear slots, no separate keybinds for utility spells or mounts.
- Performances are bad, with stuttering and frames dropping (Spec : AMD 2700X, 32 GB RAM, NVIDIA RTX 2070, Samsung M.2 860 EVO).
- It is very easy, even in the hardest difficulty. Once you perfect the timing to dodge, you have won the game.
- Some translation issues in the French version of the game, albeit very minor.

All in all, it is still a good game, especially if you're fan of the license, and I had great times with it but it isn't stellar.

Хорошее приключение с, хоть и простой, но интересной основной историей и не менее интересными сайдквестами. Есть мнение, что игра для фанатов ГП, и отчасти оно верное, но лишь отчасти, так как сама игра опирается на мир, который описан в книгах и фильмах. Визуал у игры потрясающий. На столько, что 16гб ОЗУ иногда будет мало, но оно того стоит.

А больше и придумать ничего не могу, действительно хорошая игра, даже несмотря на то, что за последние годы было буквально 2 игры с хорошим открытым миром (за последние 5 лет точно). Геймплей приятный, персонажем управлять одно удовольствие, разве что боевка немного (полностью) основана на циферках, а точнее урон наносимый и урон получаемый. За исключением некоторых моментов, за 50+ часов регулярных боев душно было только вначале, когда мозг пытался принять факт, что щит на врагах висит постоянно, на на моём персонаже лишь секунду, и вообще Протего - это скорее механика парирования, чем защитное заклинание, но игровая условность, хаваем без выбора.

Сам открытый мир чуток разочаровал. Конечно полной симуляции я и не ждал, но в местной общяге ночью НПС просто исчезают, все кровати пусты. Однако, как декорации все выглядит почти убедительно (есть персонажи, для которых можно выполнить квест, после которого они реагируют на ГГ, когда он проходит мимо них, а сама их реакция зависит от выбора в конце квеста (можно отыграть мразоту, но тут нет системы репутации, так что это будет просто фраза и не более)). А ещё тут можно использовать Авада Кедавру, прикольная штука, жаль, что запрещена.

Кстати, я проходил игру за Пуффендуй (лучший факультет, сори факт).

133913027.review:
Então, vamos la. Não confundam, o jogo é bom. Os graficos são lindos. O mundo é gigante, e cheio de lugares a serem explorados. Mas ele custa 250 reais.

250 reais em um jogo que em 40h foi possivel terminar todas as quests principais e secundarias, e boa parte dos eventos repetitivos e massantes que tem ao longo do mapa. Uma historia onde, apesar de você poder fazer escolhas menores ao longo do jogo, pouco elas afetarão o final dele, ja que tal final é simplesmente decidido pelo jogador entre duas escolhas, na ultima quest. Apesar da historia interessante (mesmo tendo seus problemas), tanto da principal, quanto das sidelines (Te amo Sebastian), não existe uma grande possibilidade de escolhas, e isso me deixa desconfortavel, ainda mais tendo o The Witcher 3 como base para um jogo mundo aberto com enredos lineares, mas bifurcaveis. 

A imersão é muito boa, e isso se faz pelos efeitos sonoros, graficos, e animações de alta qualidade. Dizem que é todo jogo que um fã de Harry Potter gostaria de ter jogado, e sinceramente, talvez seja verdade mesmo. Mas ele não vale 250 reais.

Vale a pena jogar, mas se quiser jogar, a Empress ja crackeou. Não me arrependi de ter comprado por ser um grande fã da franquia. Mas comprar o jogo sem ser esse grande fã, vejo como um desperdicio de grana. Com um preço mais acessivel, recomendaria de cara com certeza, não somente para os fãs da franquia, mas para todos aqueles que gostam de jogos mundo aberto. Mas 250 reais é simplesmente salgado demais para o HL.

I haven’t finished the story yet, but at first glance it is a bit typical. Main character is somewhat of a male “Mary Sue” who starts years after everyone, but also manages to outshine them with ease. It’s ok. Not great not terrible. 

The exploration is fun. Hogwarts is full of charm and the countryside has a lot to do. Puzzles of varying difficulty galore. The environment is full of charm and references. Very fun to explore.  

Combat is very versatile. You can hang back and let plants, potions, and ranged attacks clear the field or get right in the middle and dance around the enemies dealing rapid damage. You need to decide your playstyle somewhat early though as the skill system is permanent. However, I really like the combat system. Currently a potioneer/gardener build. It’s very strong and nearly impossible to kill even on the hardest difficulty.

LOVED this game from start to finish. My love for this game is definitely complimented by the fact that I'm a huge Harry Potter fan, but even so I believe non Harry Potter fans will still have a lot to love.

- The story is kind of cliche and generic but it's still a blast to play through and never has a dull moment
- Soundtrack is magical and perfectly crafted
- Environments are stunning and really draw you into the world
- Combat may be seen as boring due to your character mostly remaining stationary to cast spells, but I see it as extremely punchy, satisfying and gives the player a lot of creativity with combos and things like that
- Lots and lots to do and explore with various collectables and side objectives that reward players in multiple ways; from in game items to dandy little pieces of world lore
- Your own room to customise and pets to raise

Maybe wait for a sale due to the high price but for me this was worth it. If you're bored and love exploring and puzzle solving this is the game for you. Absolutely loved it.

133911394.review:
Hogwarts Legacy is every Harry Potter fan's dream come true. 

After 80 hours, I've finally finished the game completely on Hard Mode, gotten 100% on both the Wizard's Field Guide + The Collection, unlocked all the achievements (aside from the 3 that require you to play the game up until a certain point as a member of the 3 other Houses, because screw that, I'm not making 4 characters total and playing the same thing 4 times.) There's nothing left for me to do, as such, I feel like it's time for a review.

Hogwarts Legacy is an amazing masterpiece, however, even masterpieces are subjective. I think what the game excels most in is the combat, the world-design, graphics and how it's relatively bug-free, it's a complete game, which is seldom seen nowadays if we're being honest. There's also the factor of its success being due to the Harry Potter Series, most people are playing it because they're fans.

Firstly, the combat, it's amazing yet so simple. You cast spells of course but in between you're using basic attacks to build up a combo that replenishes your Ancient Magic abilities. It's like you're dancing but in the form of magic and casting spells. 
The world itself is undeniably amazing, instead of references from the books or movies, you can literally immerse yourself in Hogwarts Castle and the world around it. You won't just be walking around, you'll be flying around on a broomstick.
The graphics looks great, even on low quality, there are optimisation issues in populated areas but that's to be expected.                
The side quests mostly follow the same formula as you'd expect, fetch something, kill something, rescue a magical beast. They're decently written but quite shallow, you won't remember any of the characters unless they're a part of the companions quest line that involves other students at Hogwarts. These companion quests follow their own story arc that is specific to one companion and it develops over time like a story. Sebastian's quest line is undeniably the best and has insane moral dilemmas. The others companions have quite tame quest lines which are perfect if you're roleplaying, if not, they're still decent.
The Houses are irrelevant, whether you're a Gryffindor or Slytherin, it doesn't matter in the end as the story is linear.
The voice acting and animations are done quite well, there's only 1 badly voiced character and it's Mr Moon.
The diversity of enemies are quite impressive but they are recycled at the end of the day, just different name and appearance but abilities stay the same. 
You WILL be casting Revelio non-stop, it's a meme and it's true, it's unfortunate and tedious but at the end of the day, you need to spam it if you want to get through the game.
The story is subjective, you'll either like it or you don't, but it does "pass" as the main bread and butter of the game is being a wizard/witch where you're casting spells and solving puzzles. Almost every quest will involve one or both of these things and for me personally, it wasn't a problem, but for you...

If you're not into puzzles, you'll find the game tedious. Especially when the solution is one that you've done half a hundred times.If you're a completionist, you've certainly got a lot of work to do. A lot of back tracking, a lot of wandering around in frustration, a lot of repetition. There are 150 pages you have to look for, each one contains a random snippet of lore. 140 decorations for your beast vivariums, 80 different unique appearance costumes to collect, 67 enemy types, 95 repeatable boring puzzle trials and the list goes on and on. The game is heavily congested with collectibles everywhere you go and it's all justified by lore or a short side quest. As a completionist, it was a total hell for me to go through so if you're likely to get that itch to get everything, good luck!

To conclude, despite what I've written up there, simply put; if you're a fan of Harry Potter and the Wizarding World, book, movies or other prior older games, then you'd be missing out if you didn't play Hogwarts Legacy. If you're not a fan, you might want to do some more research and decide for yourself if the price is justifiable based on what you've seen. Overall, I'd say this is easily one of my favourite games of recent years, am I biased? I guess, but I haven't been disappointed and they delivered what they set up to give us.

If you're a fan of Harry Potter, then Hogwarts Legacy is a freakin' must-play game. The graphics are insane and really transport you to the wizarding world. I mean, Hogwarts castle looks like it's straight out of the movies!

The game's content is massive, with loads of side quests and stuff to do. You get to attend classes, learn spells, and explore the wizarding world. It's an open-world adventure that you'll easily get lost in for hours on end. Eterniy even!

One of the best things about the game is that you can fully customize your character. Like, seriously, you get to choose your house, clothes and even your wand! Even the flying is pretty good!

133906241.review:
I was so excited for this game! An open world Hogwarts experience! Amazing.....

But WOW... what a dull game. I can't believe with all the source material they had, this is the result. Hugely disappointing. There is so little creativity here. Its not really an open world either. 
They created a beautiful Hogswarts, and then didn't actually know what to do with it. It feels really rushed. 
Saying that. whilst Hogswarts looks amazing, it actually feels like a museum. It doesn't really have a boarding school atmosphere. No kids, just lots of young adults. It's quiet, has a million display cabinets and nothing is really going on. I don't think the devs actually visited a school for research, they just went to the British Museum. 
I'm a new (insanely dull) student, but I know everything already it seems. I might as well be a teacher. It wouldn't make any difference, and actually would make more sense.  
The dialogue is painfully boring. The story is painfully boring. The gameplay is painfully boring. 
Combat is ok. Nothing special. 
Potions and herbology, yawn. 
Endlessly upgrading gear is tedious. 
If you like running about, collecting pointless stuff. This is the game for you.
Have no fear if you're anti JK Rowling. All the normal wokery is ticked to offset your delicate sensibilities. 

Conclusion; A massive wasted opportunity. D-  FAIL

133904692.review:
Main story is well written, intriguing enough to make you want to continue, but in some aspects it deserves more length and depth, especially the side quests related to the four student friends. Only the quests for Sebastian and Poppy are particularly well-crafted, on the other hand, the quest for Natsai is a bit left out sync with the other quests and is not really engaging as the other 2, also the quest regarding Amit is kind of useless as it only affect 1 story quest and doesn't really continue after that.
As for the combat, everything is very well thought out: using spells in the 4x4 spell wheel is especially ergonomic, allowing you to switch between the 16 spells that can be included in the wheel quite easily, the whole point is to find the best combination possible to make your life easier. Combos and effects on enemies are also well thought out, in line with the effects of spells described in novels or films. Other spells are also available in specific contexts, making the game even more cohesive and exciting.
4/5 just because it feels like the game is short, yes you can explore and do all the collectables and Merlin trials, but it feels like the main story and side quests fall a little bit short for a game prices at $80, it only took me around 30 hours to be done with main story and another 15 to clean up any unfinished side story quests.

i'm not much of a reviewer kinda guy but had to leave one for this. Being 48 years old, my kids grew up on Harry Potter so I've had plenty of exposure to the world and found this game to be very immersive and a lot of fun overall. Sure, it has its pros and cons like any game, plenty of deep dive reviews for that so I'm not going that direction. 133903757.review:
If you're a Potter fan this game is probably a must buy as it would have always been your dream to explore Hogwarts without running into an NPC who looks like their face had been squished with a Looney Tunes frying pan. Even if you're not it's a solid game to play with tonnes to do, and a massive map to explore. Although admittedly, some collectable objectives are a little boring after a while, there is PLENTY of them though so feel free to sink into that if you're a completionist!

Honestly though its got a really engaging combat system in my opinion, especially with the easy to master spell combos, which add to the satisfaction of depulsing someone off of a cliff for a fitting killing blow. As someone who normally button mashes on Mortal Kombat instead of learning combos, that's saying something. I've had a thoroughly great time with it, the Story was great, not perfect and felt kind of rushed at the end, however the characters are good and are very likeable from my point of view, even when they're stubborn and do stupid things. i wont name names. 

Performance is a bit of on issue on higher settings, with frame drops and stuttering, especially around and inside the castle, at least until you've fully loaded in the area, it gets better after a while but you still get them occasionally to a lesser extent. Still i managed to get solid highs of 110 fps exploring with lows of 70-80 during heavy combat scenes on medium settings 1080p with a OC Kaby lake i5 and 3060, the game still looks beautiful on low settings however!

[spoiler] I would have loved there to be more options for dialogue and greater options for morality and consequences for the story which is very linear, which was a little disappointing for me, it doesnt seem to matter if you choose the good or bad ending. There are essentially no consequences for being a d**k head or using curses either which is also disappointing. In fact you actively get rewarded for using the bad dialogue option and extorting more money out of people... because you get to have more money without consequences. [/spoiler] 

Still. It is a great game, well worth AAA price and it will give you many hours of fun if this kind of Singleplayer RPG is your thing... Especially if you love or even like Harry Potter!

133903738.review:
I have played a fair few hours now and feel it's time to write my review.

Start off with saying Hogwarts Legacy is an incredible game and is the game i've been waiting for, for 21 years. I'm shocked that such a great game has been developed in this age of the game development industry and am so surprised with how good it is to play. The sounds, music tracks, visual effects, story, mechanics all feel really good and play perfectly into the wizarding world. The pure number of "WOW" moments is enormous and feels so good and if you are even a small fan of Harry Potter then you need to experience this game and i highly recommend it.

The game however isn't without issues, there are quite a few bugs usually UI elements not closing correctly, i had one where my camera was stuck on one of my magical beasts and my character could walk around behind them. For the most part the bugs aren't game breaking, in the 50 hours i played i've had to restart twice because of bugs so not a huge problem. But they are there and i'm sure the devs are working on a fix for the majority of them.

The combat is another thing, when your fighting 3-4 enemies my god does it feel good. The combat is fluid and spells feel awesome and impactful with such detail that makes you feel like an expert wizard/witch. When there's 5 or more on the other hand it become a shit show of dodging and not having enough time to plan or attack or do anything except dodge, it gets to the point where you're having to dodge roll out of every attack because they are coming at you so fast you don't have time to decide if you can protego it or not and most of the time i end up just "roll, roll, roll, roll, screw this i'll run away come back sneak attack them all and be done with it" which puts a huge downer on it.

Sneaking is another thing, when you transition between areas or cutscenes it will drop your invisibility pretty much everytime so your going through dungeons/buildings being all sneaky then the enemies will just see you and the game ignores that you was trying to sneak.

There is also a pretty big issue with the protego/dodge alert icon above your head to not display correctly or sometimes not display at all, i've also had it switch from yellow to red mid attack.

Some attack animations will play before you can dodge/block them which makes it so they start the attack animation i cast protego, it does nothing then they attack and hit me. Which sucks and feels bad especially because 80% of the enemies the block signal and animation line up.

The final issue i have is the filler, there's a huge number of things that just wastes time (opening some chests, merlin trial animation, crawling through tunnels and under things, swimming, etc, etc, etc.) Out of the 50 hours i've played 8-10 hours of it would of been spent on waiting for animations to complete or me rocking on my chair screaming "HURRY UP, Get on with it!"

I'm not one to keep playing a game for the sake of it and i will quit a game in the first 10 minutes if there's something i'm not keen on but Hogwarts Legacy keeps me coming back and each time i put the game down i'm left with thoughts and feelings of the world i just left and can't wait to go back to it.

Conclusion If your not into the Wizarding world it's still a good game and if it's on sale i recommend trying it, if you are a fan of Harry Potter or even just enjoyed a movie or 2 then buy it, buy it now! They did such a good job with this game and even with the issues i can't recommend it enough!

133903146.review:
[h1] TLDR/Verdict [/h1]
Overall a good game. It plays sort of like RDR2 with similar graphics and gameplay, and a similar depth of character customization. I would classify it in between an RPG and an action-adventure game. If you liked Fable, BOTW, RDR2, TW3, etc. and are a fan of the Harry Potter universe, then it's worth a purchase. It should be noted that the game's depth as an RPG isn't something like what you'd expect from traditional build-centric RPGs like Diablo, et al.

[b] Graphics [/b]
The graphics are great if you play on ultra, but it's worth noting that below ultra doesn't look great for a 2023 game. The lighting system on ultra is absolutely breathtaking and has similar graphics/vibe to RDR2. Ray-tracing is not worth it in this game, it's a massive FPS hit and there are some technical issues (potential memory leaks) that really kill performance even on great hardware. There is a pretty bad stutter issue primarily during cutscenes which make the game less than playable.

[b] Flying [/b]
Unfortunately, flying in this game was very poorly implemented. The controls are whack on PC. You will have to fix the controls to something more tolerable, but it still just doesn't feel right. I was able to change the controls to make it "feel better", but I still find the key bindings counter-intuitive. It would have been better if they modeled the controls after BOTW, or some established game that already solved this problem. Flying exploration is really nice because you can cast Revelio to reveal points of interest on the minimap and on the screen, but it doesn't give you the sense of awe and curiosity that you get in BOTW. Flying in this game feels more like interactive fast-travel. I never found myself curious or interested in exploring with my broom, and I always considered it a means to an end -- to get to the next map marker.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
Game plays well for an action-RPG/adventure game. The combat is fast paced and entertaining, but you will find yourself converging on only a few key strategies. As an RPG, the game is not very rich and you will not have a ton of options to customize your "build". Builds don't really exist in this game. You don't get a weapon (your wand is purely cosmetic) and armor is very one-dimensional; min-maxing isn't really a thing in this game. This is why I would classify the game as more of an adventure game like RDR2. That said, the game is filled with well-designed, entertaining minigames, challenges, and treasure to keep you engaged. Similar to BOTW, you will acquire a handful of physical spells which allow you to interact with the world to solve puzzles, acquire treasure, and collect collectible items. The more physical puzzles you solve, the more challenges you unlock, and these challenge milestones gift you with additional skills and bonus content. It's not nearly as intricate or complex as BOTW's puzzles, and the "puzzles" in this game get repetitive and grindy. As such, the exploration in this game isn't as rewarding as in BOTW, but it does add to the overall quality of the game since there's a lot to do. You won't feel "bored". While the game has a similar vibe to RDR2, the mob exploration in this game feels less organic than that in RDR2. You stumble upon poacher/bandit/spider camps, but it doesn't feel organic; it's all just the same camp copied everywhere. At least in games like RDR2 or BOTW, the mobs felt organic, unique, and not carbon copied all the time.

[b] Vibe [/b]
This is the strongest aspect of the game. It successfully immerses you into the Harry Potter universe, which is why I would highly suggest the game if you were a big fan of the books or movies. The attention to detail on the magical wizarding world is very well done, and you will feel the magic and nostalgia while playing the game. Some of the elements of the story are fairly regurgitated from the original source material, but this is to be expected. The additional tidbits of lore in this game seems very true to the source material to the point where the game itself could be considered as original source material. 

[b] Character [/b]
From a cosmetic standpoint, you can customize your character quite a bit. There are probably tens of millions of unique outfit combinations with high variance, and your character's looks are often front-and-center in custscenes and during normal gameplay. I found myself excited to get new cosmetic gear, and constantly trying new outfits to see what vibe I wanted.

133902786.review:
I really wish there was a "meh" review button.

The first 10 hours were very fun until reality set in and I realized that all the fun stuff that you see in the movies is mostly scripted within missions. Outside of missions, the world is boring. There is no curfew outside of missions, which is a thing that I expected to be in the open world. Quest givers are  in the same place 24/7 (it can be 3AM and a 2nd year student will still be in the hallways asking for help). Shops are open 24/7, so nobody goes to sleep. The only use for day/night cycle that I saw is that there are some beasts (capturable, not enemies) that spawn at night and you can only use your telescope to look at the stars during nighttime. You can use unforgivable curses, but npcs don't react to that (again outside questlines tackling that), so yeah, the world feels pretty much dead. Combat was fun enough in the beginning but after awhile, you get bored since enemy variety is lacking.

Overall it is an OK game, but if you have played any open world game in the last 10 years, this is basically it with a Hogwarts skin. Its worst crime is that it makes me think of older games that did what Hogwarts Legacy does, but better. I'd say it's a 6.5-7.0 game, but the reason I gave it a thumbsdown is because I cannot bring myself to return to the game and finish it.

There are some bugs and glitches but they didn't occur often for me. When they did show up I had to load the last save to be able to progress though.

Things to be aware of though:
- You will probably need a pretty hefty rig to play it without issue.
- Although the puzzles are reasonably varied, completionists and achievement hunters might go insane since there are so many of them (and they do get repetitive).
- Your choices doesn't seem to have much impact making the story seem quite linear.
- Don't get too exctited about riding a hippogriff (or thestral) since the broom is superior in almost every way, and the graphorn is just useful for one quest.

Despite those flaws I enjoyed almost every single minute I played it. The combat, characters, story, side-quests and setting made me fall in love with the game and overlook any flaws it may have.

133901134.review:
Ok, this is my first time writing some kind of game review, please be gentle.

Amazing game of Harry Potter RPG, finally I can realized my dream to go to Hogwarts, shooting magics out of my wand and exploring Hogsmead and the surrounding on my brooms. Fighting the cabal of dark wizards and goblins that we encountered on our adventures. The characters we meet on the grounds of Hogwarts and beyond are amazing with their simple yet effective backstory. You can choose who you want to be.

But, as an RPG game, disregarding Harry Potter points, I must say the game is lacking in lots of things. Spells that we can access are very limited, and three of them can't even be used outside a specific area, and one of the spell (Alohomora) are locked behind collection quest. The thing I hate the most from this game is the bad item management. Why can't we put items in our common room instead of being punished for forgetting to sell items to vendors?

The main story is too short for me. There are no effects on what you do besides some dialogues (a character will call you friend or extortionist based on your choice of returning her diary or not), nothing changes the story's conclusion whether you are a sweet cinnamon roll Hufflepuff or dark artist murdering spell happy Slytherin.

I really recommend every potterhead in existence to go and grab this game. For you non-potterhead, go buy the game when there is discount.

tl;dr 7/10 for non-potterhead, 10/10 for potterhead

133899671.review:
If you're a fan of the Harry Potter world you'll more than likely love this game. The world building in particular really stands out; at least as far as the Hogwarts castle and Hogsmeade are concerned. The design of the castle is so well thought out and immersive that exploring the halls feels like you're in the movies. It is amazing how everything feels familiar and connected while still being new and vast. With that said the world outside of Hogwarts although visually stunning quickly begins to feel redundant as there are lots of puzzles and quests that play the same or similar. This makes grinding for 100% incredibly tedious. Even the castle itself starts to get old as you run around spamming "revelio" in search of the last few field guide pages you've probably passed by a dozen times already without noticing or having the required spell.

Despite the large and beautifully built world, the characters seem to fall flat. Most of the story and dialogue is told through cut scenes, this wouldn't be so bad if the characters' faces and movements weren't so flat. It often felt like watching two walls talking. To top it off the dialogue options were incredibly limited and seemingly made no difference to how the game or other characters interacted with you. It was often tempting to just skip the dialogue and cut scenes entirely. This is especially true the second time around as the game has little to no replay value.

The combat system is great and unique, you can manage a lot of different spells and have the option to dodge, block, or even parry enemy attacks based on your own play style. It can be a bit overwhelming at first to more casual players, but it shouldn't take long for most players to get the hang of it. The game isn't super punishing or difficult either even at the harder difficulties so mastering the combat system isn't going to make or break the game. Everyone can have fun as they learn to become or more powerful witch or wizard. 

All-in-all this was a really enjoyable and beautiful game with plenty of content to keep you entertained for hours on end. It's only really missing Quidditch and co-op.

133897613.review:
This game has some issues on PC. It hangs really bad whenever you move to a different area but God forbid you jump. Despite having a lot of people in random places all over the world the game feels kinda empty. The people aren't actually doing anything, and outside of quests nobody even really acknowledges you. A perfect example that really illustrated to me was a dragon swooping down into a field and snatched a sheep and flew off with it. It was unexpected and neat. Then I noticed 20 feet away were a bunch of farmers in a field and not one of them reacted to that at all. Mindless drones.

The writing is really awkward too, and it's way worse with some characters rather  than others. Natty is probably the worst, I don't know who wrote her but they did a terrible job. Oftentimes, several times in a row, you will hear the same lines repeated, just written a different way. It seems like the game thinks I'm an idiot and need certain details just pounded into my neanderthal skull. It's patronizing and irritating. The skip button in conversation basically skips when it feels like it too, which makes conversations you don't want to have very irritating.  The game needs more polish for sure.

As for the story, there are parts where it's fun and times where it's mindless fetch quests and chores for the sake of padding the game time I imagine. The details of the lore are God awfully boring as well. The game devs shoehorned as much diversity into the teaching faculty as they could, then didn't have anything interesting about them beyond that. I was hoping magic would be different the world over and I would be enthralled and riveted with tales of Ugandan, or Japanese magic and how it was different. It's not, it's all exactly the same, which makes me wonder why they need a Japanese teacher when there are plenty of perfectly good Brits right there. Real missed opportunity to be interesting here. 

The combat is fun though, it definitely keeps you on your toes and I'm always playing with spells combinations. I think that's the worst part, is that they took a very fun and interesting combat system with some really good ideas and then built a mediocre game around it. It really feels like this game was designed by committee to be as safe and sterile as possible. No risks, no creative writing, and no fun. 

It's good to keep in mind that this company has made nothing but mobile games for the last 5 years, and it shows. It's not the worst game I've ever played, but I would not recommend anyone buy this at full price. It's got too many technical issues on the PC and it's at war with itself over whether or not it wants to be interesting.

133896620.review:
This game was a genuine surprise, in a good way. The developer behind this game out-did themselves and in my opinion this game is close to being an absolute masterpiece. The Hogwarts castle itself is reproduced in an astonishing amount of detail; the details that the developers paid attention to is one of the things that makes exploring the castle worth while. When I started this game, I put in a lot of time just simply exploring the castle, before breaking and exploring the greater region around Hogwarts. I would place this game up there with Morrowind, Skyrim, and Breath of the Wild as to the amount of area that can be explored and the attention to detail as your exploring. 

Combat is interesting and is unique. There are multiple combos that can made and interesting ways to apply certain spells in combat. You can effectively "force push" enemies from ledges and send them spiraling to their deaths (using the Depulso charm), disarm them and then throw their own weapons back at them (expelliarmus and then ancient throw), and even learn and use the unforgivable curses. My favorite combo is accio (bring the person to me), then expelliarmus (disarm), and then depulso (basically a force push). Forces the enemy to run back to me to pick up their wand or weapon. 

Casual gamers will find the combat difficult. More seasoned gamers are going to want to play on "hard" mode.

You do need a decent gaming machine to run this game. This is a game you will want to max out the graphics as much as you are able to afford. I have a Radeon 6800 with a Ryzen 9 7950x, and can play at a smooth and consistent 60 FPS (I have the cap set at 60 FPS) at Ultra settings and 1440p with FSR2 upscaling to 4k. Honestly this is a game where a RTX 4090 or a Radeon 7900 XTX are going to shine and are worth their weight in gold.

133894561.review:
Best way to sum up this game is that the target audience matches the age of your main character: 15. The game is beautiful and well-done, but rather shallow in every regard. Story, quests, NPCs, combat - all are solid but don't go very deep at all.

Mechanically, none of the features are difficult to master and the game isn't hard either.

Roleplay-wise, the same problem. You never really feel like a student at Hogwarts. You only get to attend a handful of classes and only for story reasons. You only get to engage with a handful of students and again... only for story reasons. Meaningful side-quests are sparse and there are no real extracurricular activities that make you engage with the world. If there was ever a place to put minigames, the classes, clubs, and student relationships would've been it (please remove Alohamora minigame).

Hogwarts is merely the backdrop to your (fairly easy) quest to greatness that oddly feels very segregated and detached from the world. Honestly, right off-the-bat you feel far more powerful than all of the students, and this doesn't go away the whole game.

All that being said, it's a solid game that is enjoyable and very beautiful. Just don't expect it to be a deep magic-school roleplay or have a  grand story like Harry Potter did.

Additional notes: This game is absolutely amazing! You can do everything HP related here: fly brooms, make potions, go to classes, explore the grounds and the forbidden forest, shop at Hogsmeade, death party with ghosts, duel. Then there's so many clothing options that you pick up everywhere and pick up talents/skills which are beautifully illustrated.

The second best thing about the game is just the magical accents/like the movements for spells and the way the objects twist and turn. The effects are spectacular.

The third highlight is that the characters/people look so good in the Unreal Engine. It's my favorite rendering of people. The cinematic scenes are so nice.

Some of the fighting/enemies and sets reminds me of God of War (the reboot) while the wild areas remind me of Witcher. That's how tough it can get right from the start battling enemies. It caught me off guard. It doesn't feel like an RPG but really like a good open world.

133891021.review:
I can barely stand writing this because I just want to get back in the game!

I LOVE it.  Its a polished, creative, GAME.  Lots of stuff to do.  Main quests, side quests, pages to collect, 8 million Merlin Trials, treasure caves, potion brewing, plant growing, combat trials, etc etc etc....  and just the sheer fun of exploration!  The quests have nice little story lines and great voice acting. 

The controls are intuitive and make things fun instead of frustrating.  The combat is wonderfully fun....  Pulling enemies toward you and igniting them with flame.... Wonderful.  OH!  And I could beat wolves out of their fur for hours and not get tired of how their pelts howl when i loot their skins.      

When you think it can't get better you learn flight, get mounts and get your own customizable room.  

Now, you know I can't stand divisive narratives being pushed in games.....  This game gets the all clear from me.  There are a minority of NPC characters who are LGBTQ, in the 1800s no less, but it doesn't bother me because the story isn't about forcing someone's identity and sexual lifestyle down your throat and trying to destroy you if you misgender.  Their identity comes about naturally as you encounter them in the story, for example, when one refers to her wife, or where one has a deeper voice than you'd expect.   Its not announced in a pride rally with dongs being flung around children while demonizing Christians or white western men.  What a breath of fresh air to see my fellow human beings from different lifestyles being portrayed as just people instead of mentally fragile activists hellbent on sewing discord.  Thus, the story stays focused on the story, and in no way grooms or marginalizes one segment of the population!  

Mostly, the game is GREAT at immersion.  Why has it taken THIS long to have a good game come out?  My character looks like the Invoker from DOTA2, I'm having a blast playing through Hogwarts as the one and only Kael'thas Sunstrider.  I've said enough, the game is great, not some cheap release like Cyberpunk full of bugs and woke story.   This game is pure, polished entertainment.

133890741.review: I love the game, love it enough to take the time  to give it a review. I am now level 36 and getting to the end. The game is addictive and thrilling, but I do not see myself going through it again. I am mostly going to talk about the cons and what the developers need to do to keep its fans happy. The combat system is great, but the player is vastly overpowered in late game. Upgrade each clothing three times, put level 3 enhancements on each, and you can basically beat the game with basic cast alone. Now throwing in ancient magic and unforgivable curses, I can basically put down a goblin rebellion single handed. Unforgivable curses are unforgivable for a reason, if everyone throws AK and Crucio around like candy, there will be no wizarding population left. The most frustrating thing about the game is that whatever choice you make, whether it's your house, your choice of friends or actions, your spell set, it doesn't matter in the end. You can AK everyone in front of teachers, students and bystanders, and it doesn't matter one bit. You can go around picking locks in daylight in front of the owner. Actions need to have meaning and consequences for this to feel like a real magical world.

133887732.review: Hogwarts is a good game. It's a relatively smaller open-world RPG. I really enjoyed it. Beat the game at something like 120 hours. It was fun to master combat playing on hard with it being difficult at first but then getting progressively, and then exponentially, easier. There are quite a few puzzles that take some brain power, and its fun to find little hidden additions to the game. Like the student who quizzes you on trivia. I'm not sure that the decisions you make throughout the story have much of a bearing on the outcome of the game. Probably a few of the bigger choices. The subject matter is probably entertaining for adults as well as younger people. And there's nothing explicit. I had a really good time overall. Of course, I'd be interested in a sequel, a larger magical word/map, and DLC's.

133886635.review:
Full disclosure, I'm a big fan of the Harry Potter series so my opinion on this game is heavily biased by this.

TLDR if you're a Potter fan seeking an environment rich in exploration opportunities, this game is 10/10. If you care much more for story over exploration, it's still well worth the price. I can't speak for non-fans of the series, but I've seen several friends with no interest appear to be thoroughly enjoying the game.

I came into this game with low expectations. Given the low depth of past Harry Potter games, and recent history of various game devs over-promising and under-delivering I made a point to assume this game would be awful so that I could be pleased no matter what. Out of the gates I was absolutely floored.
The scale of the game is enormous. I was expecting the castle, Hogsmeade, probably the forbidden forest, and then maybe a little bit of fluff in between. Imagine my surprise when I opened the map and found that it not only zooms out (several times) but also seems to scroll down forever. The map isn't barren, either, it's fairly well packed with puzzles, easter eggs, camps, etc.


The exploration in this game is, for a Potter fan, the absolute peak of this game. I've genuinely spent hours just walking around Hogwarts with the mini-map disabled, wandering aimlessly specifically to get lost in new places with new secrets. Finding a small reference and going "hey, I recognise that" and then being able to mentally place that reference next time I encounter it in a re-read of the books has greatly enhanced the game and the series as a whole for me.


The combat is a neat new idea that I think has managed to feel unique without feeling too gimmicky; however due to so much exploration I tended to out-level and out-gear most content meaning sadly I haven't engaged as fully with the combat as I would have liked. Is it the best combat out there? Definitely not. But I wouldn't call it a negative either.


I think the story is fine for the most part. I don't personally follow game stories too deeply, so for me to actively pay attention to this one is probably worth something. The side stories generally feel better quality than the main story, but I thought the main story was still above average. Thankfully the story isn't propped up by references to the original series; there are a couple of namedrops here and there but the story in no way assumes that the player knows the reference nor relies on it.

133882927.review: The story is set up for an early teens player base.  The game is fun and has some fantastic moments.  If you just focused on the main story this would be a very short game. Definitely going to want to do the side quests. It's amazing walking through Hogwarts and I usually found something new to explore every time I focused on exploration. 133882797.review:
Hogwarts Legacy is a love letter to the Harry Potter universe.  It is obvious from the very first moments that the developers, programmers, and artists are very much in love with the HP universe and have done all that they can to put you into it.  The world is quite large and the number of fast travel locations is quite adequate.  That said there are a few fast travel locations that dump you very close to enemy spawns.
Gameplay is nothing spectacular in terms of the mechanics, but it is nothing awful either.  There is room for some strategy in your approach to enemy fights, but you can also make it through by simply spamming attack/dodge until the enemy are dead.  The only exception is infiri which you have to set on fire before you can damage them.  Although be warned if you are using the stealth mechanic you can one shot minor bosses.  Spell selection is nice but I found myself most often falling back on 3 or 4 favorites for most battles.  You can have up to 4 sets of 4 spells that you can switch between on the fly which adds some variety, but it is strictly on you to make use of it.
The puzzles in the game are, for the most part, fairly intuitive and can be figured out with a little thought.  The story is good, not spectacular, but quite serviceable.  Most side quests are well done, and a few are multi-part story lines that are fun to see through to the end.  Exploration of the world is fun and you will encounter many locations where you just go 'yes' that is exactly like it should be.

The good:
Decent gameplay with a fair amount to do.
Exploring the world is enjoyable and there is enough variety that you want to keep going to see what is over the next hill.
Combat is challenging but no too difficult.
You get to explore Hogwarts, Hogsmead, and the world around them.
Flying on a broom is a fun way to get around, although Hogsmead is a giant no fly zone (no idea why)

The bad:
Too many people are trying to make a political statement out of the game instead of looking at the game as a game.
Many of the treasure locations take about 1 minute to complete and are total cut and paste jobs.
A number of collectibles are tied to specific missions and only show up in the world after that mission is completed.
Revelio helps you find stuff, but you have to spam it to find some items as they are only revealed at very close range.  Fortunately there is a ping sound that lets you know they are around, but it is a spherical search area so the item may be above or below you.
Replayability is minimal and the only real difference between playthroughs is which house you select; which affects only a very small portion of the game.

All in all at 70+ hours in I have been having a lot of fun and Hogwarts Legacy is definitely worth the money.

133882232.review:
I do recommend this game... However I feel that a lot of content in this game was either half removed/made and or not optimised.

- Good amount of quests that also played on your morality.
- Fight scenes were fun, Remove the lock target and you'll improve the fight scenes greatly (I used controller). 
- The puzzles and side quests were engaging and fun.
- I played my only play through on the hardest difficulty, I have not 100% the game but its already taken about 69 hours.

The things I feel they need to add into the game or fix:

- Fully bring in the curfew system.... Literally only two missions forced me to sneak around. Using invisibility was almost unused for at least 98.5% of my game play. With this I also feel your house/dorm room really isn't utilised at all. I think i spent less than 30 minutes there the whole game and that was mainly at the beginning. 
- Why is my character the only one wearing a different style of house robe? It would be nice to see other students wear a variety... I did see a single student wear a quidditch outfit, which was very out of place (because its its banned at hogwarts this year).
- I won't get into a quidditch rant, obviously thats been touched on many times over.
- Some voice lines get very over used, mainly the Hogsmeed one (we all know what this is). 
- I would also love to see more races/time trial's for the brooms.
- More duel's would also be awesome!
- The evil ending didn't seem as flushed out as the good ending, it was very glazed over it seemed (I did both endings).
- Maybe a year 6 DLC?

Over all, I would be happy to come back to this and see if their has been more updates to the game play, maybe some optimisation. I don't feel like its game of the year but I had a very fun time playing it! I'm Excited to see what the future holds for this game!

133881645.review: Recc. I'll only say things I don't think have been said before. A great game to play once; I think only a completionist may really enjoy a second playthrough. That is because, for better or worse, resources were put into making a large world outside of Hogwarts, rather than putting those resources into more narrative branches or more House-specific content. The choice of House is mainly cosmetic, but I'm glad its there, and it adds to immersion. The emphasis on combat is bizarre; I think a more puzzle-based adventure-RPG hybrid or even taking a note from the Persona series would have fit more in line with "Magic School: The Simulator." As such, this is every Open World game, but with the Harry Potter IP. And it's very good, but the best parts of the game were the character quests, the dueling club, and the castle secrets. Imagine if we had gotten even more! Would have loved for this to have been character-driven rather than plot-driven. More school duels, less Troll-smashing. More conversations, less collectathons. But saying all that, they wanted a Hogwarts Open World, and what's here is a fun and charming one. Would love to see some DLC.

133880927.review:
Not a bad game, per se.  Could do with a lot of improvement though. 
Very 6/10ish. 

[Good Stuff]:
+ : PETTABLE CATS
+ : Reasonably pretty game, assuming your computer can handle it.
+ : Open world with plenty to explore.
+ : Fairly satisfying combat.  Especially once you get Descendo.  Who even needs the killing curse when you have the "mash face into ground" spell? 
+ : Fantasy RPG.  I like Fantasy RPGs. 
+ : Probably enthralling if you like Harry Potter... for whatever reason. 
+ : No Quidditch.  Thank fŭck for that. 

[Bad Stuff]:
- : Stupidest setting ever.  That is J.K.Rowling's fault though. She sucks at worldbuilding,  so just about everything in the setting is utterly nonsensical even by fantasy standards.  Basically everything has to be magic because it makes things fancier, nevermind if the nonmagical solutions are simpler.  But apparently mundane solutions or logic are for muggles because the entire cast come across as a bunch of upper middle-class twäts who can't do things with their hands because they might lose a cufflink or scuff their precious fingernails.  But I guess if you're a brat who choffs caviar with a silver spoon and want magic to tie your shoelaces because your personal maid had enough of your sh!t, then this is definitely the game for you. 
- : Sh!t plot.  Really.  It is.   You just do a bunch of puzzles and then decide if you want to be stupid, insane or evil. The side quest plots are also similarly stupid. Not even joking.  The "good" ending basically involves being Smaug. 
- : The characters are shallow, two-dimensional things... which I guess is normal for toffs. Quest-givers generally only have one thing on their minds, and those uninvolved with any of the quests or plots have nothing on their minds whatsoever.  Background conversations between NPCs are reminiscent of Oblivion in their awkward disconnectedness. 
- : Over 90% of the game content is split between the same few puzzles repeated ad nauseum, and tons upon tons of collectibles.  Even most of the plot quests are the same.  Still, I'd rather be doing puzzles in the countryside than dealing with the NPCs.  And since I have no interest in decorating the room of requirement, NOR in learning any more about the setting, the collectibles are just a nuisance. 
- : Significant frame drops in some places, particularly around Hogwarts itself.  Others also report stuttering and various other graphical issues, though I've had less of those myself. 



...  And yes, I realise the negatives section was bigger than the positives, but I am prone to grumbling.   
It was, overall, a positive enough experience that I didn't end up hating it.

There's a lot to like about this game imo but not everything is perfect and great.
Like, personally for me, I don't like the lack of growth. You know, working your way up,
becoming that bada** wizard and feeling a certain sense of pleasure and pride in pushing through it.
Yet, imo, there's really no sense of building yourself and growing. Everything just feels handed to you. 
Definitely expected a more personalized experience where the story is influenced 
by your actions outside the main questline. Kinda expected a diverse storyline too where you have 
a lot of choices and depending on your choices determines the outcome.. 
and although there is some sort of choice in this game, it still feels linear 
and straight forward. The exploring, the puzzles, the combat, the character 
customization's, as well as the brooms and mounts are all awesome. 
I love the environmental details, the moving paintings, statues, armor sets, etc, etc
There's a lot to like with this game imo. There's just a few things I wish they did differently. 
The game could use a bit of survival elements too. Like maybe add that for harder difficulties? 
More immersive weather and atmosphere's would also be nice.
The 3d sound also needs some work. I hear conversations in directions that aren't accurate way too often.
Overall I've enjoyed the game thus far and I still recommend playing it
