133991308.review:
I've been thinking about writing a review throughout my entire playthrough but I kept running out of words to describe the game. Magical feels overused but that's exactly what this game is. There is so, so many magical things and details from which you can see how much love went into this. I've finished the main story now, played almost a 100 hours and I still keep gasping and tearing up at every corner. 

This game made me laugh, cry and everything in between. I'm not a completionist but this game makes me want to complete every single thing just so that I discover all of the astonishing details to the environment and the characters. I'm someone who skips through dialogues in games because it's hardly ever interesting or well written and I haven't skipped a single sentence here. I hate combat that counts on your reflexes because I have anxiety but this game made the difficulty so well balanced I actually enjoy being able to react.

But my absolute favourite and by far the most unexpected game mechanics is the room of requirement and the ability to decorate so much space. As someone with hundreds of hours in Sims 4 spent mostly building houses, I have to tell you that I cried every time the room expanded and gave me more space. Honestly, it's even a bit overwhelming and I begged it to stop but I guess it knows what's in my heart.

Do I have things I wish the game had? Absolutely. Do I still think it's the best, most intricate and most magical game I've ever played? You bet. The amount of gameplay and the size of the world makes up for any details I would've welcomed but I do hope we'll get some future content because I want to continue living in this world. Though to be honest, I'll continue to do just that even without the content. Still so much space to decorate, so many sunsets and sunrises to see and gasp at and so many cats to pet!

TL;DR: This game made me laugh at all the little details and cry literal tears over some others. 10/10 would cry again. Also, they kind of had me at petting the cats.

133990620.review:
Hogwarts Legacy was a brief, fun, short-lived game. 

I played it out and it was super fun at first. It seemed like the story had tons of layers. It ended up being only about the main story and like 2 in depth side character quests thus I found the game to actually be superficial.. If you looked any deeper it was like... wow, really? My main gripes is that the currency/store is awful, most items are awful, dungeons were terrible (no really, why bother adding something so lackluster to the game) and even something like collecting all the merlin trials was useless. I at least thought there would be a side quest or a cinematic there but no, they really dropped the ball on this. I also wish that decisions actually mattered like they hinted in the story.

Anyway, I have to hand it to them, the models and animations are fantastic and there were times I was just gawking at a bookcase watching the animations for books. Like thats crazy, someone animated that. The castle was beautiful! I found myself admiring the tapestries or statues because they were beautiful, inspiring even. I loved designing the room of requirement and having so many cute magical beasts. I enjoyed going to the classes at first (later they I feel like they just turn into cheap commercials). The magical aura of hogwarts kept bringing me back! I think I enjoyed the main questline but I just wish there was more depth and content as it was too streamlined. I hope Hogwarts inspires developers to make more high fantasy games. 

All in all I did have good fun with hogwarts legacy and can admire the work they did put into this game.

133990500.review: Feels very immersive and there are plenty of side quests with interactions. Really feels like I'm a student in Hogwarts!

133990472.review:
(Actually Play time: 29 hours.)

Okay so yes I liked it BUT this game has a lot of flaws that really start showing up after about 20 hours in. 

I was immediately immersed in this world, and that's what I look for first in these kind of games. There is SO MUCH detail put into the castle that your first several hours of exploring it feel like how exploring Hogwarts should feel. You stop and stare and listen so much in this game I really felt like I was there. But as soon as you've done a once over on the entire place you start just feeling like you are running from point A to point B to complete quests. 

Which is honestly expected in most games. Even some of my favorite RPG's like Persona and Cyberpunk loss their luster after several hours. But they both had engaging plots and characters that kept me immersed, because it no longer became about looking at every tree and graffiti on the wall, it became about them, they were the immersion, they were the thing that felt real.

I don't think the story or characters in Hogwarts are bad. I really like Sebastian a lot, its really interesting to be friends with someone from a house was always considered "An Enemy" in the other source material. He is a very morally gray character who is driven and not just "evil" or "good" and that makes him interesting and makes me want to see his quest to the end. However the game frames his story, and the other major story points, as all very black and white, and thats where I lose interest. 

The big villain is BAD and is using magic that is BAD. You're the chosen one and YOU get to save the world! Blah blah blah blah. Been there, done that, a hundred times over in almost every form of media available. And there are great examples of this format done well. Mass Effect, or Avatar the Last Airbender for example. But the cast of characters and their dynamics with one another carry those stories. We want to see how THEY do it. 

None of the characters really seem to know each other outside of your main character being the most important thing to happen to anyone since sliced bread. And again, I like most of these characters indivdually, I like all the professors and there are some real genuine moments. But the way the writers handle the overlapping narrative threads and themes feels beyond sloppy, in fact it feels like there was no real thought given to them at all, and that makes the world feel bleak and empty, like its no longer a world for you to exist in, but a game for you to run around and do stuff in and feel like an overpowered hero. 

I still really enjoyed my time with this game, and I got my money's worth. I just did not feel motivated to see any of these stories, main or otherwise, to their conclusion. 

Overall I'd give the game a C+, it was good, and in some moments it was great. But that greatness becomes spread WAY to thin towards the end and I felt myself craving more, and needed to move onto other things. Hopefully with the success of this game the sequel will be even better.

133989102.review:
This is a SINGLE PLAYER RPG-ADVENTURE game.  No multiplayer.

LOTS of fun, lots of exploration and secrets and character customization.  And the map is HUGE - includes all of Hogwarts school and grounds, Hogsmeade village, and a sizeable chunk of the surrounding valley.  Combat is mostly intuitive, and you can setup more than one set of active spells (four spells in each set) which are interchangeable at any time.  So maybe put all your animal-handling skills on one set, primary combat skills on another set, secondary combat on a third set, and even then you'll have to mix in a couple of the utility skills from time to time depending what you need in the moment.  The RPG choices you make in dialogue [i]mostly[/i] lead you to the same point regardless of which choice you make... you can be mean-spirited or you can be friendly and nice for various flavor text.  But you should be very careful when dealing with your four main companions because some of those choices have irreversible consequences.  And plan ahead how to spend your talent points once you unlock that ability, because you CANNOT respec your talents once you've chosen them.

BUT the needs a beefy GPU to run properly.  Needs a GeForce 3080 (or equivalent) to run properly on "quality" or "ultra" graphics, which look fantastic but are very resource-intensive.  My FeForce 1080Ti system only gets more than 20fps if I run all settings on "medium" mode, which still looks okay but not as pretty as ultra mode.  And I still get parts of the textures flicker in and out of existence, showing shifting black polygons every half second or so.

Overall this game has been a pleasant experience and Granted I have not finished this game as I wrote this review but from what I have seen so far I think anyone who enjoys the Harry Potter franchise will more than likely love this game.

3. (This one is subjective.) The protagonist is a student at Hogwarts. This means everything is from a kid's perspective and involves a lot of school life experience. 133986595.review:
Hogwarts Legacy is a definitely a great game. Its not "ground breaking or revolutionary" but not every game needs to be those things in its genre, respective game play. If your a harry potter fan or like me grew up watching the movies this definitely brings back nostalgia or at least puts you in the atmosphere. 

From my understanding its 100 years or so before the movies etc so keep that in mind. Either way i feel the developers did a excellent job. There are so many little details spread all across the map, Hogwarts that reflect very well on the lore, books. 

My favorite things about the game are the potion making, crafting and using of these things as a "Battle Enhancement" they are not necessary but do give little edge in certain fights, situations. The spells and combat feel fluid and nice with many combinations to deal with your enemies. 

The only thing i found a bit tedious is the spell management. You have many spells for different situations and only 4 rows to alternate between which most of time have to be constantly replaced at least 1 or 2 slots in these rows on occasion. Im not sure how this would be fixed or a different solution.

Overall  there are so many side quests and even main quests etc still do, this game is quite fulfilling in the sense of things to do. I would rate the game a 8. Its solid all around and definitely beat my expectations. With many more hours i know im going to pour into it i know and feel i got my money's worth already. Its a steady buildup from knowing nothing to becoming a master wizard with powerful tricks up your sleeve.

133983224.review:
This game is beautifully made and the attention to detail is unparalleled. It is a true open world experience where you actually get rewarded for exploring. There really is something to do everywhere on the map, you won't be left wondering what to do as there is always something around the corner. 

PROS: 
Exploration: something to do everywhere
Combat: Always fun, just wish there was more of it, cool skill tree with rewarding talents, leveling up takes about the same amount of time throughout the game so you always feel like you're getting new skills and spells
Story: great story, love how it is set in the past so it has nothing to do with Harry Potter but also there are ancestors of characters you might be familiar with so it still gives you that sense of nostalgia
Voice Acting: really well done
Cut-scenes: I love how the facial expressions of characters really gives them a sense of realness and an attitude, I especially love Professor Weasley's expressions and it makes me feel like shes my mom
Room of requirement: I like how you can farms materials and the beast worlds are really cool but I also like how it's not necessary to do well in the game, all it really did was make me op and have way more potions than I needed but that's okay

Cons: this is just more of a wish list
-I wish there was more enemy types and more combat in general
-I wish the school aspect was more prominent since you basically just go through a class each of every professor and then go off and save the world
-Combat in general could have been more interesting but I just felt like I was button mashing and everything just dies
-I wish I could be more evil or if there were campaign options like a completely evil route that I could take with more evil choices, what would be even cooler if I could just start the game as a goblin and play it from that perspective with unique goblin magic or something, and maybe even a way to start the game from Rookwood's perspective (I just wish campaigns in general were in games more but I realize it takes a lot of work)

133965575.review:
Fair warning, there *is* a bunch of game-play spoilers in this review.

When I first started playing the game, I was amazed to the point of thinking "This has to be the Open World RPG game of the decade". I've since come to reconsider due to a couple of points that I'll point out soon. 

First and foremost I'll say the game is *definitely* worth getting. The combat is fun and quite intuitive, Hogwarts itself is *huge* and absolutely amazing, there's so much to discover and some nice lore included with a lot of the "points of interest" you find. I kept finding places in Hogwarts I hadn't been yet even after *40 hours* of playing. The world itself is also very pretty and it's quite satisfying to fly around on your broom exploring it. The story arc is pretty good, topped off with excellent side-quests following a couple of other students that on occasion ties in with the main story to varying degrees. I never found myself bored with these quests and found them fun and intriguing. The room of requirement serves as a kind of "player-made housing" area and is generally really cool in my personal opinion. Could spend hours there.

Now, the reasons I've come to reconsider my initial praise of "Open World RPG game of the decade". The game sports some classic elements and tropes of the RPG genre. Levels, talents, gear, potions, fast travel etc and in and of itself, that's not an issue, but I'll go over my critiques for the way they've been implemented in this particular game.

The leveling and talents of the game are quite fine in and of themselves, however they do provide a player with a *very* large increase of power immediately once unlocked. By retroactively providing you with talent points once you unlock talents around level 15~, you get ~15 talent points immediately that *significantly* empowers spells. This surge of power felt out of place and I think I'd rather they have introduced talents off the bat so we could 'grow' in power with them. 
It's worth noting that you will not hit a level where you've unlocked all talents. Even by avoiding for example the Dark Arts tree all together you'll end up having to sacrifice not unlocking every other talent. With all of that said, let's move on to the next point. Gear.

The gear system in this game follows the all too familiar tier-sets including the familiar colour scheme of "Common, Uncommon, Rare, Epic, Legendary". This is not inherently a bad thing and is easy to understand for veterans of the genre and newcomers alike. It also sports a type of 'enhancing/perking' system that in and of itself is unlocked way too late into the game, and this ties into my main gripe with this system. The main benefit of higher tiers of gear is it's capability of being upgraded further, and enhanced with stronger perks. Due to how late in the game you actually unlock the ability to upgrade and modify the perks of your gear though, it really ends up just being a game of "Which piece has the higher stat" for a very large portion of the game and makes gear tiers early on feel absolutely pointless. Couple this with visual overrides being a thing you can do whenever and wherever, and your gear choices feels even less like a choice. Perks are however incredibly powerful in terms of enhancing your spells/resistances and I think they wanted to rely on this to be where you'd make the choice of perk VS stat. The problem with this is the very vague information provided of how much a perk actually benefits you. It's simply stated that it "Slightly, Greatly or Significantly" enhances spell damage or damage reduction against X foe. Which brings the next topic, the combat scaling.

Whilst combat is fun in the game, it is way too easy for any veterans of the genre. Even on the hardest difficulty, it's too easy and I found myself not having need for the potions designed to help you in combat at all. Coupled with it being rather annoying to scroll through and use them in the heat of the moment, you end up simply forgetting they exist in the first place. Early to mid game you'll find yourself practically losing all your health in 1 hit, but you never get defeated from a singular hit. An enemy needs to hit you when you're at "0" health for you to actually be defeated. This means that when missing a block or a dodge, if you simply react fast enough and chug a healing potion, you're good to go for another hit. Whilst some enemies do 'chain' attacks they're rather few and far between and usually not an issue. 
Important note: The game does *not* sport the option to have enemies that would be below your level be scaled up to match yours to retain difficulty, meaning that if you like me enjoy to explore the world and doing side-missions, you find yourself indirectly punished in the rest of your combat/main story combat becoming significantly easier due to over-leveling them. On that, let's get into my main gripe with the game world.

Like mentioned at the start of this post, Hogwarts itself is absolutely amazing, and you can tell they've put a lot of time and effort into building it and all the POI's in it. The same could be said for Hogsmeade, but then there's the rest of the playable world. Don't get me wrong. It looks amazing and there are some rather nice POI's and puzzles around, however you quickly notice once you start properly exploring that it all feels very copy-pasted. The only really unique things on the map is the Hamlets and regions themselves. The dungeons usually sport the exact same layouts with the only variation really being which one of the 4/5 unique puzzles you'll encounter at the end. Top this off with very few of them actually housing enemies and they become very boring very quickly without any real kind of challenge or novelty. This is rather lack-luster for an open world RPG and ended up being quite disappointing for me. Even the ones that do sport enemies usually only have 2-4 of them which is an absolute breeze to deal with. The surface puzzles ends up being very repetitive as well and all in all it ends up feeling a bit empty/shallow. 

The game sports the very weird decision to unlock the arguably best mount of the three options first. This, combined with a very wide-spread fast-travelling system, makes later unlocks therefore feel pointless. You start off by unlocking the broom, which is a rather agile and fast way of flying around. You then unlock a Hippogriff which might be faster than the broom initially, but once you upgrade the broom, it matches and eventually beats the hippogriff in speed *and* agility. Last of all options you unlock a ground-based mount that doesn't really serve much use at all aside from gear materials. 

All in all I did enjoy the game for what it was and have no regrets in buying it. It's a really fun game and whilst it does on many occasions feel like the game's trying to be a jack of all trades at the cost of mastering few/none, I do believe that a lot of these pain points I've brought up are things that could be fixed. The open world *is* lack-luster, the exploration and puzzles does feel repetitive. However the story and quests are really, REALLY good, and combat for what it is is very, VERY fun albeit too easy. 

I feel like this game is set up for future DLC's to be added, opening up new areas for us to explore and new quests to do. If they put some more time and effort into actually making dungeons and puzzles more unique in those areas, and add the much needed option to have enemies up-scaled to match your level, some more clarification of what gear stats and perks actually provide, the game could very easily find it's way into my top 3 favourite games of all time.

133963444.review:
Hogwarts Legacy is an upcoming video game that promises to transport players to the magical world of Harry Potter in a way that has never been done before. Developed by Avalanche Software and published by Warner Bros. Games, Hogwarts Legacy has already generated a lot of buzz in the gaming community.

From what we know about the game so far, it looks like it's going to be an immersive, open-world adventure that lets players create their own wizard and attend Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. You'll be able to explore Hogwarts and its surrounding areas, cast spells, brew potions, and encounter magical creatures.

One of the things that has me most excited about Hogwarts Legacy is the fact that it's set in the 1800s, which means we'll get to see a whole new era of wizarding history. The game promises to have a deep and engaging story, filled with mysteries to uncover and choices to make that will impact the game's world and your character's journey.

Another aspect of the game that has me excited is the level of customization that will be available. Players will be able to create their own wizard, choose their Hogwarts house, and even select their own wand. This will make each playthrough unique and allow players to truly feel like they're a part of the magical world of Harry Potter.

Overall, I think Hogwarts Legacy has the potential to be an incredible gaming experience that will appeal to both die-hard Harry Potter fans and gamers who are new to the franchise. With its beautiful graphics, immersive gameplay, and captivating story, I have no doubt that Hogwarts Legacy will be a game that players will be talking about for years to come.

This was a game I was not expecting to enjoy so greatly. 

After the consideration when my friend had begun to play, I decided it was the right thing to do. I hadn't given myself proper retail therapy for a long time, and as the HP franchise is something I did grow up with but drifted away from, this was the perfect opportunity. 

The game is great! It's very simple in its story and reminds me of how games used to be. Not necessarily stale or linear, but enough so that you can easily follow along while still stopping to do side quests or to look for collectibles. The characters are quite memorable, and although Sebastian seems to have more of a spotlight, many of the other characters make up for it in personality. My favourite character is Ominis. 

The graphics are stunning, and even with a now outdated laptop, still runs quite well as the game streams its content in a way I'm not used to. Bugs happen, but that's the norm these days. The developers are working quickly on updates and seem very connected to the community, which is a great privilege considering the controversy surrounding the series. 

If you plan to play this game due to the controversy and wonder if it's worth it, I do recommend this game. Even if you expect it to not be the best, you may still find yourself having a bit of fun.

133959788.review:
After 81 hours of playing, not all of which was productive, I've completed all of the achievements. The game is a lot of fun and the world is fairly big. The fights can be a bit repetitive, but there are quite a few combinations of attacks and neat interactions with the enemies that keep it interesting. Getting all of the collectibles wasn't crazy difficult, but definitely the most time consuming part. I ended up getting a bug where it shows that you're missing a page in the Bell Tower section, but luckily that's just a visual bug and doesn't stop you from getting the achievements. 

As a completionist, this game offers a lot to keep it from getting old. I would recommend it to anyone who likes exploratory games, games with simple puzzles, collectibles, or Harry Potter in general. 

Also, a bit of a spoiler, but the game does change a small bit depending on the house that you choose. To get 100% you have to play as each house. I'm a native Ravenclaw, but I found its story to be the most lacking. Surprisingly, the Hufflepuff's was the most interesting. Slytherin and Gryffindor's were also both good. I also really liked that you could explore the common rooms if you joined their respective houses. 

8.75/10 overall score from me!

133958222.review:
Pro
- World building is amazing
- Great voice acting
- Really good audio
- Combat is smooth
- I like the story and characters
- Mod availability
- When walking with  characters, they will match your pace
- Garlick
- Able to be creative in the Vivarium

Cons

- The people aren't reactive, barely anyone reacts to what you do
- The puzzles are super easy, only have to think for one or two
- Game expects you to finish the story before roaming around the world (which is stupid), really easy to level 
- Unnecessary cut scenes for puzzles, and there are many puzzles (trials)
- Combat is easy, in the sense that you can even kill mini bosses in 2/3 seconds because of how powerful you become
- The gear doesn't really matter
- Your house only matters for one mission

Almost all of these problems are not that big of a deal, the game is still great. My only gripe is that the people in the world don't react..

You can use spells next to them and it will just go through them and they will just completely ignore you, you can use alohamora to unlock other peoples houses and people around you or even the people in the house dont react. they could have at least put the Auror to roam hogsmead and if she catches you, you get detention or something.

The restricted section is only restricted for one mission, you can go in there in front of everyone and face no consequences after the mission. same for the prefects bathrooms/ headmasters room/ forbidden forest (but that one is k).

The game not being a school simulator is kinda a bummer as well, would have been awesome. More mini games like summoners court or races would have been nice too.

Also game feels better to play on mouse and keyboard.

Rating for me

Since it's in the harry potter universe : 8.5/10
IF i don't consider what universe it's in : 7.5/10
If the game came out 10 year ago : 10/10

Hope they will consider all these in the next game, can't wait.

Its an extremely shallow game. Its obvious they cut out alot of parts to not have a delay upon release. Very limited enemy types, the worst loot system that I have ever experienced, and the most boring, repetitious puzzles that I have ever seen. Seriously, move block here, activate lever there, rinse and repeat.

The vast majority of the 'open world' is lifeless. You cant interact with the majority of the NPCs. You're force fed a storyline that you cant influence. You're a student trying to stop the forces of evil, yet you walk around killing goblins and dark wizards without a second though of the morality of the situation and have a higher body count than they could ever dream of. 

In the begining they captured the magical feel of the harry potter universe. But it quickly becomes stale when you realize there are basically 5 enemy types and they all act the same with the same spam attacks.
The majority of the content is collectibles. Find 10-20-30-50 of these and get.........nothing of any value.
The loot is random. Go through a dungeon and the last chest with a worthless item that is worst than any you have. find a chest in a bush outside somewhere randomly and find an amazing high tier item. It makes zero sense. There is no point in finding the treasure chests as their is only garbage in them.

I goit 30 hours out of the game and was interested for about 15 hours of it. The last bit, I got to my second trial and after the 3rd mob and fighting the camera as well as the boss, I uninstalled. This just isnt fun anymore and I have no interest. Wait for a holiday sale.

133955597.review:
If you're even remotely a Harry Potter fan and like action games, you will love this game. The story is intriguing and really has that Potter world feel to it. You don't feel like a side character, but rather the axis upon which events unfolds. The game has done an amazing job of giving the user a variety of things to do, people to meet, places to go, and dark wizards to fight. The combat is absolutely amazing. 133954744.review:
The attention to detail in the game is outstanding. From the Hogwarts castle, to the Forbidden Forest, to the bustling streets of Hogsmeade, every aspect of the game world feels meticulously crafted and imbued with the charm and wonder of the Harry Potter universe.

The gameplay is engaging and rewarding, offering a blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat. As you progress through the game, you'll learn new spells, brew potions, and interact with a variety of fascinating characters, each with their own unique backstory and personality.

Perhaps the most impressive aspect of "Hogwarts Legacy" is the sense of agency it gives the player. The choices you make throughout the game will impact the story and the world around you in meaningful ways. Whether you're choosing between houses, forging alliances, or deciding the fate of certain characters, every decision feels weighty and significant.

All in all, "Hogwarts Legacy" is a triumph of game design, a must-play for any fan of the Harry Potter series or anyone who loves immersive, story-driven games. With its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and richly detailed world, it's sure to cast a spell on gamers of all ages.

I have a little over 72 hours in. Absolutely love this game. I'm Gen X, a little older than the typical Potter fan, I saw the movies, never read the books. I am however a long time player of fantasy RPGs. I've been having a blast with this game. It's easy to start feeling like single player story-driven (with a lot of side stuff obviously) RPGs are dying in this age of live service games and constant monetization. I know I sound old, but even Dragon Age is doubtless headed that way.

This game is engaging, beautiful, and extremely enjoyable. Are there bugs? Oh yeah I've encountered numerous bugs, but fortunately they've all been cosmetic. My cape stuffed up in my face during conversations in the Map Chamber. Floating 4 inches above the ground when walking around a few locations. None of it game breaking or even really much other than chuckle inducing. 

Graphics? Great. Not bleeding edge but beautiful and engrossing. Music? Fantastic! Voice acting, almost all of it spot on. If you read the books or watched the movies and ever wanted to be a student yourself and go on wild adventures, I think this is a very satisying and enjoyable experience. I have dozens of games I've played for 3-15 hours and then just dropped. I'm 70+ in now with Hogwarts Legacy and have no plans of slowing down.

133953885.review:
I waited till completing this game to leave a review. I did a near completionist run of this game, gathering almost the entire collection so far and I do intend to go back to finish off the achievements. 
I loved MOST of this game. The visuals and characters are engaging. The world building is not only beautiful but a fascinating mesh of movie and book descriptions. The map of the game is truly awesome and the play-style inside of the world is fun. There were some key-binding errors where binding would respond to default binding despite showing otherwise in the settings, graphical glitches, and a few game anomalies but these were not too horrible to play around. 
The plot had some issues. I was disapointed that the entire game was exactly what I thought it would be upon the two minute mark of playing. The plot is very predictable and not often nuanced. As a writer, I was disappointed that characters like Isadora never had direct screen time beyond a short memory you view part way through the game. You never discover a key aspect of any video game which is who you are in all of this or why you are joining late, or why you can see this ancient magic that no one for hundreds of years are able to see. This is a crucial hole in the story I find, as it gives your character little purpose beyond "the chosen one." You also never wield the magic in any way like the keepers do beyond fighting and it did not get the attention I felt it deserved. I also found it predictable that Harry Potter style situations such as all Weasleys being nice, and the Blacks being rude were kept. I feel it might've made a stronger point that not all members of a family are the same across time, as well as making the plot a little less predictable. 
These things said I did still fully enjoy the game. Many side quests and main quest adventures keep you interested and engaged, and I grew attached to Ominous (a perfect example of a family-line break, well done!) and Sebastian, despite Sebastian's fall into dark tendencies, and found their plot the most interesting in the game. Characters were well diversified and even extras had interesting dialogue I found myself stopping to listen to. 
I would recommend this game to any Harry Potter fan and I did vastly enjoy it, despite my critics of the plot ending. I still intend to replay the game and am glad of the adventure this game provided.

133953372.review:
I recommend this game for both serious gamers and Harry Potter fans alike. The clean graphics, fantastic sounds and intuitive game play make for an enjoyable and unique gaming experience. Harry Potter fans will be rewarded with a beautifully rendered Hogwarts Castle, complete with classrooms, miles of corridors, winding staircases, secret passages, hidden rooms and more; all beautifully rendered with movie-worthy content. (Sometimes on a grander scale than the movies) 

The acting and interaction with the game characters are well done and very forgiving on any choices made in dialogs, so feel free to treat others kindly or rudely depending upon your taste. For serious gamers, the spell-based combat system works well and is both entertaining & challenging, while lower difficulty settings can give less experienced players some breathing room. 

After being sorted into your house, you will begin casting spells, such as Leviosa to make things/enemies float; and get plenty of combat practice attack dummies and wizarding duals. Aside from spell casting, players will learn how to craft and use potions, for healing, boosting stats and more. Additionally, players will learn herbology and learn how to grow combat ready plant-life like screaming mandrake root. Oh, and did I mention flying? Once you progress enough in your studies, you will take your first flight lesson and soon you’ll be soaring over the wonderfully rendered school grounds and surrounding lands. 

Finally, the Village of Hogsmeade fills in nearly everything else for a complete wizarding world. Your first visit to this village will be to get your first wand but will get lost in the wild angled buildings and cobblestone streets right out of a fairytale. Considered the world’s only Wizarding village, it’s the only place you can find chocolate frogs, a cold butter beer, or easily buy missing potion ingredients. So much more too, such as capturing creatures and your own pocket worlds to tame and breed them, along with mountains of side quests, puzzles, and mini games.  
 
In conclusion, it’s always nice to buy a game that delivers as promised, is well tested and bug free; but even better when it’s done with the highest quality and effort to bring a fictional world to life. While there is always room for improvement and with millions of copies sold, I’m sure there will be plenty of suggestions, Hogwarts is a solid addition to anyone’s gaming library.

133947831.review:
Overall, this is a good game. Great visuals, fair character customization and player choice incorporated into the dialogue. Love the variety of appearance customization available (although I wish there were an outfit creator). Exploration feels interesting enough and the story/characters kept me engaged. I really liked how the 4 different trials didn't feel like the same thing over and over. Definitely was happy to find out that #3 and #4 weren't just more archway puzzles and stone golems. But the best part is the combat--incredibly fun and plenty of room for many different playstyles.

My #1 complaint about it however, is the fact that playing as any other house besides Slytherin feels rather out of theme. There are two main reasons for this:
1. The Slytherin relationship questline is the longest and most well developed. This questline includes more house history/lore, more characters of the same house, and even includes epilogue conversations, making it feel like a much bigger part of the story than the other houses.
2. Learning and using Unforgivable Curses has no consequences whatsoever, and not even your professors seem to bat an eye at it. Additionally, they are overpowered to the point of trivializing almost everything when paired with the Dark Arts talents. It is by far the most powerful build from a strict combat efficiency standpoint. Based on what I know of the Harry Potter mythos, I really can't imagine anyone from any other house being okay with learning these curses and using them so liberally, or even with just killing so many people and things at all. 

So this game really needs a morality system that incurs some kind of penalty or impact on players based on the choices they make including whether they chose to learn and use Unforgivables or not. It also needs alternative combat resolution that would allow players to incapacitate instead of kill, and whether you choose to kill opponents or not would have an impact on the story. Something similar to Mass Effect's paragon/renegade system, where certain kinds of choices would contribute to a score that impacted which choices would be available in future quests, and how other characters react to the player. It also could have used more development/history for the other houses besides Slytherin. Especially Ravenclaw. We only go on 1 quest with our Ravenclaw friend. 

Anyway my advice to the prospective player is that if you want the most authentic experience, just play as a Slytherin, because this game seems to have been designed with a Slytherin protagonist in mind more than any other house. If you hate Slytherin too much, then just ignore the Unforgivable Curses and their associated questline.

133945989.review:
Aside from generally suboptimal performance compared to its better optimized PS5 build, as well as a handful of small nitpicks I have with the repetition of some collectibles and other minor game mechanics, I greatly enjoyed the 50+ in-game hours I spent in this world so far. The combat is highly enjoyable, though I would prefer greater diversity of enemy behavior. The main story isn't anything overly intricate, but the overall narrative is solid, and while many side quests do ultimately boil down to "fetch quests," I often found myself enjoying the story arc of these side missions enough to put off main mission quests for hours.

I highly recommend this game for anyone, but especially for those who grew up with the books and movies; the level of nostalgia is undeniable. Interestingly, this attachment to the source material can easy break the other way for those directly effected by the abhorrent beliefs of the original books' author. I understand this position and will never be able to say anything to lessen the sting of being of being betrayed by an author who wrote a wonderful story about inclusion, love, and good always winning in the end.

To conclude: I loved this game experience, and f*** J. K. Rowling.

133944263.review:
The game is great for reasons already well articulated in other reviews, but I'll negatively review it because it has a huge list of small annoyances copied over from Ubisoft games and it is my duty as a [b][u]true god gamer[/u][/b] to shit talk any game that keeps perpetuating these retarded game design decisions.

[h1]This game thinks you are a fucking idiot[/h1]
That's right, here are a few ways that the game is trying to tell you you are a [b]FUCKING IDIOT[/b] that cannot retain any information in your brain:
- Popups on a timer reminding you to do X. There's one that reminds you to equip better gear, even if you don't have better gear. What if I want to use shit gear?
- You can hide the whole UI, except for the combat feats UI: you WILL play the game the way the developers want you to play

[h1]The characters are all very sassy[/h1]
- Again, the ever talking characters: they must comment on everything, they must make the same observations for the millionth time over, the stupid fast travel boomer bitch must comment on your field guide every time, our main character keeps talking about Merlin trials - no, the Merlin trials are not a good surprise, and stop wondering if it's a Merlin trial you're looking at, it is, because we've done about 40 of them and they all look the same and the first 10 or so were fun but now they're fucking annoying.

[h1]The game should have been 30 hours long[/h1]
- Speaking of kinda cool things that become fucking annoying, this game has plenty of them: Merlin trials, Demiguise statues, treasure vaults with shit loot, the list goes on and on. This game does not have enough content to be a 40+ hour game, and it's clear they stretched as much as they could.


[h1]Hogwarts Impact? Genshin Legacy?[/h1]
- Speaking of Merlin trials again, their very existence kinda sucks in the first place. It's not because they're bad, I like the "puzzles" and they would've been fine if you did them only once or twice. The problem is that you do them for nothing, really. You have limited gear slots, and to get more slots you need to do the Merlin trials. So you must do these stupid things over and over again, and your reward is to loosen a limitation that adds absolutely nothing to the game.
- The game also imposes limitations on how many animal types you can have in your vivarium. Why? What's the reasoning for this? How does this make the game more fun? It does not even make it more challenging.
- The game has many more limitations, to the point where you have to wonder: was this game meant to be a live service game? Did they intend to allow you to buy time skips? Buy more gear slots? Buy an increase to the amount of animal types you can have in the vivarium? Buy more alchemy table slots? Buy more [insert any other game limitation]... ?

So good game, but filled with shit ideas, like pineapple pizza or some shit like that.

Pros:

-The story isn't particularly interesting but there are some really awesome missions.
-Lame character creation with embarrassing voice pitching options 
-Not much replay value unless you didn't do the unforgivable curses or just want to see the other common rooms and do the few short quests that are different. Player choice don't effect outcomes too much if at all.

133940779.review:
I waited for this game so long, and when I started playing it I felt excited. But then, it turned out to be a quite disappointing. For starters, I am a HP fan (books, movies, art, theories, merch, etc.) and I was so so so hoping that the game would be amazing. CAREFUL, SPOILERS AHEAD

THE SETTING 
As you may know, it´s 1800s something, Scotland. You have the castle, Hogsmeade, and locations around, and veryyyyy far away, I´d say. There are 4 Houses, as usual, and a bunch of teachers, and an annoying Headmaster. For 19th century Scotland, Hogwarts is pretty diverse nationality-wise: Korea, Japan, Uganda, Persia(?). I guess we all know why they were added lol. It is still a bit weird considering the history of the countries, but okay. But why leave the rest, I ask? Where is, for example, Laos lol? Eastern Europe? South America? Native people? Diversity for the sake of it, I see.

SCHOOL SETTING
The students that I saw looked like my age. I couldn’t make whether there were anyone from the 1st year or older. There are no regular classes. You attend only a handful of them, and mostly they are like short videos. And they are not even funny, every time all the students are amazed and smiling, and everybody completes everything. Even though there is a school uniform, you don’t get to wear it, because the gear consists of completely different pieces (headwear, robes, facewear, etc.) and, boy, are they ugly. I swear, there is any asylum mask as a choice, and I just have one questions: why? Why would you add an asylum mask as an option to wear over someone’s mouth?

Even though you get the sorting ceremony, it is short, very short. You can’t sit at the table, you sleep on the ground, at night, in the Forbidden Forest for the sake of waiting for someone. You can’t even go to bed. The only thing you get to do is to eat and drink, but that´s it. You can´t choose a pet (which would be great, but not in this game). There is no quiddich, but you do get to fly. You are not required to attend classes every day, and... there is no scoring system! Meaning, you broke the rules? You were awarded the points? It doesn’t matter, because no one keeps track of them. Will. Care. There is no fear of being caught (only when a quest needs it), so it makes the game pretty uninteresting. No cauldron duty, for pity’s sake! This is the most disappointing for me, because what was making HP exciting is also strict school system. Even I get that you can’t put the classes in the game and expect me to explore the mines without any consequences, but at least sneaking around the castle at night should have some sort of punishment. In books and movies we saw how teachers were patroling the school, and here it is absolutely absent. Oh, one more thing: you can enter teacher’s classroom and empty their trunks and chests while they are there watching you! You steal from your teachers so easily and nobody says a word about it. 

STORYLINE AND QUESTS
The main story is okay, it’s not the best, it’s not the worst, about 20 hours to complete it. Side quests are mostly boring, some of them are interesting and fun. >!Personally, I loved rescuing animals, but!< the majority are mundane and tedious tasks lie go and talk to someone, fetch this, find this, etc. They could have done better job with side quests, honestly, because there are lots of them (~ 2/3 of the hours are SQ) and they start to feel uninteresting pretty quickly. Almost all quests require some sort of a puzzle based on logic and observations, but they are very, very repetitive. It gets to the point where you do not enjoy it anymore, and they are not even that hard. As game progresses and your level increases puzzles remain at the same level. And what is more, even when you are accompanied by your friend they do not do anything. Absolutely nothing. They are like a dead weight and I would have done a great job without them. They can fight, but they do not do much damage, and most of the enemies will attack only you.

CHARACTERS 
Here I come, hold your seat belt. The characters are flat. Not just flat, they are FLAT. They almost have no personality at all, and their traits are almost identical. The only 2 people I can distinguish from the game are Sebastian and Ominous. Now, remember that the school is full of teenagers from 11 to 17. You will not see any behaviour like that from them. They behave and talk like super formal adults, even their gesture. Every time I see like my character clasps her hands together (every dialog) it makes me so irritated. Where are emotions? Where are bad words? Where is different personality through body language? Where is whining? 

GAMEPLAY
Combat is okay. Again, could have been better, but it is not bad. The spells are diverse, and you need to know which enemy reacts to what better. There are also combos and ancient magic stuff. You cannot cast a spell (only Revelio) while on your broom and while ducking, which can be pretty inconvenient at times. There is never enough space. I completed [/spoiler]Merlin[/spoiler] trails and expanded the gear, but it seems never enough. There is no storage room or something in the Room of Requirements, which is kinda weird - if it know what I need, why can´t it give me a closet? It has enough space to create [spoiler]reservations for animals[/spoiler], but my character doesn’t even get a closet. 

I have a big issue with Alohomora. I play on my PC, and opening every lock becomes boring quickly. It is the same mechanics for all three levels of locks, and there are a lot of them. Besides, we all know how Hermione used Bombarda to free Sirius, why not let us use the same spell for at least some lock of the 1st level?

Quests have location limitations, and if you left it, you will get 15 seconds to return. I fell of the cliff a few times during combat and had to crazily rush around in order to make. When I use Disillusionment charm and become kinda invisible, my character makes so much noise while jumping or climbing, that I suspect the goblins are all deaf in reality and use magic to hear sounds. The dialogs during walking and under the charm are super loud only for Sebastian to say afterward: silent as a grave. Animals and [spoiler]animal rescuing[/spoiler] are a big part of the game, but you are not allowed to pet them. They will have a toy (a ball) and you will use a magic brush to do the job, but you can’t actually play or pet them, and bond. Flying is a bit awkward. There is no quick save (I love quick saves). 

MORAL CHOICES
None. Nothing. NOTHING. The dialogs mostly have 2 options - be good or be bad, and neither influences on the outcome. You can cast all the Unforgivable curses ANYWHERE in front of ANYONE  and there will be no reaction, no punishment, no consequences. [spoiler]There is no option to become bad or even morally gray, you end up being good savior, happy ending, serve me my champagne.[/spoiler] Even though you kill people in the game, it doesn’t affect your character in the slightest. You get it?  [spoiler]Your character will go on killing mages and goblins, and wild animals, you end up being all fluffy and saint, while[/spoiler] HP is all about morality and consequences (direct or indirect) and how those choices will haunt you later on. 

GAME ISSUES 
It crashed 1 time. Sometimes, dueling feats don’t register the progress. Never had any stuttering. Some items like gold, chests, bags are half int the ground, and I can’t open them. Had some issues with the map, where it didn´t want to show the final route and I had to reopen it 3 times. 

(Not serious) And spiders. People, I hate spiders, I hate insects, and there are tons of those spiders in the game. Somehow, the spiders had more details that people’s faces and emotional displays, so I was shoooook. Needless to say, I was playing and eating my comfort food all the time lol.

DO NOT PURCHASE!!! (Until the devs release significant performance patches)

I can see what this game COULD be. It's got a beautiful open world, richly detailed and fully explorable Hogwarts castle and an intriguing spell combat system. 

HOWEVER!!!

In it's current state this game is unplayable on all but the most beefy systems. I'm sporting an i7 10th generation processor, 2060 RTX and 8GB of RAM and yet even on low settings i get awful screen teraing, stuttering and outright freezing.

It looks like the game has trouble loading the shaders and assets (especially for spell effects) and all in all the game becomes unplayable in all but the most barebones environments. 

They really screwed the pooch on optimisiation here and the devs need to bring out some serious patches before this approaches anything like an enjoyable experience.

133931905.review:
As a massive fan of the wizarding world, I was eagerly anticipating the release of Hogwarts Legacy, and I can happily say that it exceeded all of my expectations. From the moment I loaded up the game, I was transported to a stunningly detailed and immersive rendition of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, and I felt like I was truly living out my own magical adventure.

The gameplay mechanics are incredibly well-crafted, with a mix of exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat that keeps things fresh and engaging throughout. Whether I was exploring the Forbidden Forest, duelling with other students in the Hogwarts courtyard, or brewing potions in the dungeons, I was always thoroughly engaged and entertained.

One of the things I loved most about Hogwarts Legacy, however, was the sense of agency it gave me as a player. Rather than simply following a linear story, I was able to make choices that affected the outcome of the game, shaping my own Hogwarts experience in a way that felt unique and personal.

Of course, the real star of Hogwarts Legacy is the world itself. Every inch of Hogwarts and the surrounding areas are meticulously detailed, and it's clear that the developers poured their hearts and souls into creating a truly immersive and believable wizarding world. From the iconic Hogwarts Castle to the bustling streets of Hogsmeade, every location feels authentic and full of life, and I often found myself simply wandering around and taking in the sights and sounds.

Overall, I cannot recommend Hogwarts Legacy enough. It's a fantastic addition to the wizarding world, and it's clear that the developers put an incredible amount of love and care into creating an experience that truly captures the magic of Hogwarts. Whether you're a die-hard fan or a newcomer to the series, I have no doubt that you'll find yourself enchanted by this wonderful game.
